content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												I used to play The Force Unleashed so much when I was younger, and it made its debut as the first Star Wars lightsaber combat game on the Wii. And the The Force Unleashed II spat right in its face, and everybody hated it.But, honestly, we all like to hate The Force Unleashed II... but wasn't this game bad since the beginning?I don't know how this game performs outside of the Wii or PC, but I can say the difference between these two versions is night and day. The Wii has worse graphics and level design (as usual)... but the PC has a lot more issues than I was expecting.For one, the game is buggier than the Amazon rainforest. Throughout most of the game, I was battling the game crashing, floors disappearing, sound effects cutting out, and even lightsabers being turned on in cutscenes where they obviously shouldn't be on. By the end of the main story of The Force Unleashed, the game was so broken that there was no music- not even any sound effects- save for Starkiller's lightsaber and footsteps.This could be a symptom of PC getting some of the worst ports of games that were originally intended for consoles. This is especially evident when playing QTE's, since the layout for the buttons isn't laid out for a keyboard and mouse. It's mapped out more for the four buttons on a 360 or PS3 controller, so I found myself failing several times because of where Q, E, and Left-Click were placed on the prompt.And since this is the first time I've played the HD version, I can say it's much shorter than the Wii's campaign. I know that the Wii story had a lot more unnecessary padding, often involving random trips to the Jedi Temple to fight a random Sith lord before the story decided to start picking up again. But the biggest flaw in this game's story (and really with its gameplay), is its horrible pacing.The story feels forced. Every beat, from being betrayed, to meeting the girl, to the conflicted interests, is all something like a cop on the run who's out for revenge after being betrayed. And the game rushes its cutscenes so quickly that it leaves little for the already paper-thin characters to feel empathetic or feel any drama going on in the plot.The pacing in the gameplay is also very off. Many times, I was just thrown in a large area with tons of enemies and upgrades placed around at random, and traversing around could be a massive pain in the a**, because the game can be so chaotic that it becomes stressful to try and manage what enemies to get or what upgrade to grab first.Also, like three characters die in the story and come back to life. Seriously. Rahm Kota, Starkiller, and PROXY should be officially dead for what happened to them, and yet the miraculously come back to life later in the story. Even Kota reveals that he wasn't blinded at all by the end of the game, which seems odd, seeing as how he took a lightsaber to his f***ing eyes!Another new feature to this PC port, is that it isn't just your average Force Unleashed copy... it comes with DLC! Packed with costumes you'll never use, ever! Seriously? Why would I want to just dress up as Jango Fett, if all I do is talk and play like Starkiller still? I know it doesn't matter to some people out there, but literally anyone can make a skin mod. I find this part of the DLC lazy as sh**.But along with the mounds of useless character skins, there's also three levels tacked onto the main story. I thought all three would be a continuation of the dark side ending, but I was wrong. Only two do. And the game purposely has you play them in the wrong order. The game has Hoth listed before Tatooine, even though the events happening suggest that what's going on on Tatooine is happening before Hoth.The new skins and lightning color didn't impress me. Hoth was pretty decent for what it was worth, as was Tatooine. They were both just average. But for f***s sake, who decided to make the Jedi Temple, and why is it even relevant as DLC? It's just a random deleted level from inside the Force Unleashed's main campaign with some incredibly unintuitive design and horribly simple puzzles. In the words of my uncle, while getting robbed at gunpoint, "F*** this!"The Force Unleashed for the PC is bad. And boring. And predictable. It's got some incredibly simple combat within long, linear levels that don't award a player for their exploration, but more for accidentally running into a randomly-placed secret. It feels so unfinished, I expressed at one point that I was playing an unfinished beta. Do not play The Force Unleashed on Steam. It might be better for the last generation of consoles, but stray far from this game. I'm giving it a 4/10.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Star Wars: The Force Unleashed is a hack and slash third person action game where you play as Galen Marek otherwise known as Starkiller or simply the apprentice. After witnessing your father killed by Darth Vader at a young age you are taken by him to be his secret apprentice and tasked to kill the remaining jedi in the galaxy. Over the course of the story you experience betrayal and side with an early Rebel Alliance. The game tells a pretty solid story, but the gameplay gets repetitive overtime. The game makes you feel like a badass as you kill multiple enemy types and are given multiple force powers like force lightening and repulse. Pros:- wide variety of force powers and upgrades- skins and lightsaber crystals- excellent story- range of planets you visit that are each distinct and feel star wars- great voice actingCons- sometimes repetitive combat- mixed quality in level designverdict:Overall this game has stuck with me for a long time and the characters like starkiller have been very memorable. This is a game that I would highly recommend for the story and has decent enough combat to keep you entertained for hours.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												I really want to give this game a recommendation, I really do. When the game works, you feel like a true Sith. Throwing things at enemies, firing Force Lightning at them or just flat out throwing them off ledges/into walls is immensely satisfying. You feel like a god among men. The problem, though is that the times the game works are few and far between.Overall, the game just feels wrong on PC. The combat controls are loose and the camera is painful, even with an Xbox 360 controller. Several enemies have way more melee range than you do and are guaranteed a knock down. Their animations are also hard to interrupt, meaning the fastest way to defeat them is actually to use Force Grab and throw them off the nearest cliff/down the closest pit. Using Force Grab to throw things at enemies just does not work most of the time. It sort of works with a controller and about 30% of the time, you'll throw it at an enemy. The other 70% of the time, you'll either throw it off a cliff or into a wall about 30 feet to the side of the enemy. Trying to do it with keyboard/mouse is even more impossible.Force Lightning is satisfying, but only with the second upgrade where you can actually hold the button and fire lightning for as long as you have Force energy. The first level is useless for the most part as it only affects one or two enemies, though it's nice for stunning them.I won't comment on the combos because I'm terrible at combos in any game I play and thus consider them stupid in all games.The quick-time events (and there are a lot of them) are far too quick. You will have to repeat them at least once unless you have above average reaction time. This would be alright except that failing a quick-time often will heal the boss/miniboss, which is a terrible but effective way to pad out a fight's length.The biggest complaint I have, though, is that the game is riddled with bugs. The game crashed for me three times in the same boss fight. The only time it didn't crash, the boss' attack knocked me out of the world, trapping me outside the boss arena and making the fight impossible to complete. There are numerous other bugs I could add to this list, but those are the worst offenders. Having to restart a boss fight four times because of bugs/crashing is unacceptable and frustrating.

												Star Wars franchise had a lot of very good and very bad games. This is the latter and even more: it's god awful port of god awful game.30fps and crashes, ugly and no settings (there is like 1 tickbox, resolution and brightness). While 30fps lock can be fixed, the game itself doesn't worth it. It's pathetic attempt on mixing slasher and gravity gun mechanics. Controls are pretty badly designed, especially gravity throws that rarely work properly, there is no animation cancel, no proper avoid or block (both is there but basically unusable) etc. It's just primitive underdeveloped slasher with awful controls set in star wars universe. Feels very unpolished and underdeveloped. It is one of those games you play through just to see if it gets any better. And it does not. The game just doesn't function as a game which becomes more obvious the more you play it. It's just a bunch of cool concepts that wasn't developed into anything even remotely working together.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Pretty Good Game Review Considering (PGGRC) 9.8 Hours to CompleteTL;DR - This game is weird. Everything the game does should make we not recommend the game. But I still do. Here is why... Right out the gate you’re going to see simple textures, bad pop in and a 30fps frame rate. Yet I always had fun. The game is an excellent “simulator” of being a sith lord. Maybe this is the star wars nostalgic but this game even though is broken I really liked it. In depth: Performance - a 30fps frame rate. Funny thing is the game still felt and looked smooth. Not to mention the semi-destructible environments are a huge pro.Graphics - Below average in places. Right out the gate you’re going to see simple textures, bad pop in. Locations are beautiful from far and very different. Gameplay - Solid. II love throwing people into statues and watching them break apart or forcing pushing them up in the air, throwing my sabre into his chest and throwing him into a tree. Feels great. The camera is a bit of a ♥♥♥♥♥ and controls are a tad clunky but it did not annoy me too much. Bosses are challenging, Sometimes cheap won’t name any names but you will know don’t worry, and to beat a boss results in a QTE that if you fail punishes you hard. I hate QTE as it’s lazy but in this case it still was great as it felt like you kicked the living ♥♥♥♥ out of a boss and that was your reward to see your character look like a badass. It’s also very repetive but it did not feel that way due to the range of powers, abilities, locations plus the sandbox destructible environments.The story is actually quite interesting and decent. Fits in right between episode 3 and 4 and to be honest should be made into a movie. I love proxy and his relationship with the protagonist was unique. All the powers and combos vary up combat making you into a badass. The costume selection is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. I count like 40+ unique outfits being different variations of the protagonist or different characters in the star wars lore. The three missions outside of the main story are nice what if spin off missions and are quite good but familiar to main story. Some glitches only one was game stopping and one crash. Replayability - As you can unlock everything in one playthrough, if you’re good enough, it does lack here. Conclusion - Overall a game that’s weird but I really enjoyed despite bad cons which would break other games. Maybe it’s due to that I a star wars fan XDIf you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow my curator group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/FALLENV3GAS#curation

												One of the biggest disappointments for a triple-A title, let alone a Star Wars title, in recent years. This (obvious) PC port of the 360/PS3 Star Wars game is hopelessly flawed by lucratively overpowered enemies, broken maps, ZERO in-game graphics options, terrible camera angles, and glitchy controls. There is no checkpoint/quicksave system, requiring you to redo the insane boss battles over and over again. The battles? Boss battles should be moderately enjoyable, to be able to pull off some combo attacks. Well, no. Every boss has unavoidable attacks and will annihilate you before you have any chance to get the boss to 50% health.Stick to Battlefront II or any of the other fantastic Star Wars titles, skip this miserable mess.

content:
Posted: March 7
												Star Wars The Force Unleashed tells the (non-canon) story of how the rebellion started. You play as Starkiller, Darth Vaders secret aprentiance. The story is one of the best told in a Star Wars game. The game is mostly good. The gameplay is third person hack and slash. The only weapons you have is you lightsaber. You also have force abilities like force push, force lightning etc. The only changes that you can make to your light saber is the blades color/colour. As you play you gain force points (XP) and whe you have enough, you gain a level. As you gain levels you can upgrade you abilities. The graphics are amazing for its time and the environment hold up today. The character models are outdated and ugly. The bigest problem I had was this game was techincal problems and the Star Destroyer. I had numerous graphical bugs and one game breaking bug through one playthrough. The Star Destroyer part (Near the end of the game) took me one hour of retries to complete. That part is just plain bad. Following the button promts didn't help and I eventualy got through by trying it my own way. Its still a great game, but due to the bugs and age of the game I'll only recommend it at half price and less.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Have you ever wanted to be a Jedi knight or a Sith Lord? Have dominion over the force and use it to crush your enemies or unite your allies? Then this might be the game for youThis game was tremendous amounts of fun. I am biased because I like Star Wars but still, with a ton of force powers and duel lightsabers, this game was just fantastic. Even from the beginning you feel like a one man army, ripping ships from the sky and hurling them at anyone who stands in your way. The power trip you get from literally cutting your way through a horde of bad guys is something to behold.The setting is wonderful, obviously, as its Star Wars. The levels take place on many different planets and starships leading to a reasonable verity of settings and environmental challenges. The enemy design is fantastic and varied; from Wookies to Tie Fighters you battle them all. The game is not the best looking but it still holds up to this day as rather pretty. The characters and story were both very engrossing and I was compelled to see what happened to everyone and how it would play out in the end. It even adds some depth to the original movies, showing what goes on behind the scenes and adds to the feel of a living universe.There were a few issues however that hampered my enjoyment. This is not a good port at all. The controls can feel clunky and the menu operation is a pain. There were a few glitches, not so many that they spoil anything but enough to notice. There was one section that was almost impossible with the mouse and I had to look it up, it was really obvious once I found the answer but the game doesn’t do a very good job of explaining.I would recommend this game to Star wars fans and haters alike. Its super fun and a great time. Even at full price you will get something out of it.Have fun ^_^

												Note: I recommend yes for thos who have not played this game, and no for those who have.I used to play this game all the time on my Xbox 360, that being said this is actually a pretty solid game itself, of course all console ports are generally locked at 30 FPS so if you want 60 FPS I'd install a patch, although I've heard the patch can screw up the game even further.  In my opinion this game has held up decently, but the second game although short is defintely almost a direct improvement in almost every way to this game.[h] Problems with the Game: [/h]-Metric ton of glitches.-Bosses are incredibly predictable and mainly you lose because they just spam the same attack over and over.-A lot of button mashing and quick time events(The second game made these less frequent and actually fair)-Most bosses aren't difficult, but just cheap (Spoiler Alert for the few that haven't completed this game)  Such as Vader who despite how much you mash the buttons can't break free from his Force Grap attack -Lots of sound glitches (These can be fixed by a patch)-Less features than the other versions of the game (Same for the Xbox 360, even though it had a better system than the PS2, PSP, and the Wii). -Story that for the most part is boring (Except for Darth Vader and his Apprentice, and the whole founding of the Rebel Alliance thing (Which this game isn't canon anymore)Good Things: -A wide variety of enemies to face.-Each level is almost drastically different (With a few exceptions)-Fun gameplay.-An entire gallery of artwork for the game to look through.-Customizable clothing and lightsaber.-A variety of force powers to use.-About 17 different combos that can be used.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
Hate Leads To SufferingWhat to expect from this game?This game is about the adventures of a Sith apprentice of "Darth Vader." You will visit some unearthly worlds to gain experience and collect holocrons for game advancements. Throughout the journey you will combat Wookies, Wampas, Jawas, droids, lesser lifeforms, Rebel scum and other Imperial forces who get in your way. Will you be able to become the most powerful Jedi/Sith ever to live?What are the Pros of this game? Great Graphics/Visuals Exporing "Star Wars" locations (Star Destroyer, Death Star, etc.) Destructable environment (limited areas) Using Force powers at will Slaying lifeforms Hunting Jedi Fighting "Star Wars" Heroes/villainsWhat are the Cons of this game? Limited"Star Wars" locations are explored Very limited destruction areas Poor gaming controls/targeting system Force power is unbalanced (can move star freighters but not an AT-ST?) Very linear gameplay and storyline "Star Wars" Heroes/villains can't be destroyed Camera angles during duels are horribleWhy do you recommend this game?I only recommend this game for fans of the "Star Wars" universe, due to great visuals and loose tie-in story to the original "Star Wars" movie trilogy (Part IV - Part VI). This game had so much potential, but the game's playablitity is comical.  Not able to cut enemies in half or limbs off with a Lightsaber really bothered me, while unable to break enemies with a Force Grip.  (Maybe I am just asking too much, but "Jedi Academy" games got the combat balanced done right)[As a gamer, play "Jedi Academy" games instead or KOTOR]

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												An over the top TPS game taking place in the Star Wars universe. Some of the force powers you have are so strong that you can take down AT&Ts and later on a star destroyer, too. You do, literally, unleash the force in this game to its full potential. This also means that the focus is on the action not story telling so you may find this game disappointing if one of your favourite SW games is the Knights of The Old Republic or another RPG taking place in the same universe.Unfortunately, the game is horribly optimised. You install 25 gigabytes on your hard drive. Today this size is common but this is a 5-year old game. Additionally, there can be bugs and glitches and just because the Ultimate Edition is offered for purchase for PC gamers it's not an excuse for not looking into its issues. Personally, I did not find the story particularly interesting. I got that it was about Vader's secret apprentice but there are so many games out there taking place in the era of the old trilogy as well as the new one that I was already fed up with these.Anyway, this is not necessarily a bad game. It is an interesting concept and you really have some amazing power at your disposal. If this over the top approach does not deter you then I recommend this game but only the first one as the sequel was a very, very (and I mean very) short one and a complete disappointment.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Being a huge Star Wars fan, I can honestly say I loved this game a lot. If you're a fan of Star Wars, this game is a must buy! Even if you're not that into Star Wars, this game is still great! I liked how this game lets you "power up" skills, talents, etc... and it definitely makes your character interesting, as well as your ability to be able to customize your lightsaber. The game is definitely NOT boring and if you play on a harder mode, it will definitely be somewhat challenging. The boss fights are pretty neat, and each one you fight is slightly different. I also loved how at the end they made you choose between the Light/Dark side so there are actually two separating endings to the game. Either way, it's kind of sad how it ends though. Playing the game, you not only play as Starkiller but you also begin to connect with him (at least I did) and Juno and this definitely was a determining factor in me loving the game so much. Finally, the graphics are absolutely gorgeous.Now, the things I don't like. First off, the game was pretty short. I finished this game in 7 hours (did mess around in some parts) and I really wished it was longer. Another thing I don't like was how you can just run past a lot enemies to get to the boss fight for some missions and I really wish fights weren't so optional as to make the game a bit more challenging. As much as swinging around a lightsaber and killing enemies is cool, I wish the game wasn't so "hack and slash" and make enemies a bit more challenging so you can't just swing around your lightsaber all the time (it gets really boring).All in all, it's a game I would high recommend! Rating: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												This game is very overrated. I therefor was pretty disappointed by it in the beginning. The things that annoyed me:Abysmal PC-port. Capped at 30 FPS with physic screw ups when unlocked, no mouse control in the menus. Keyboard and mouse control is flawed, I managed to bear with it since i don't have a controller, but you may not want to bother with it.There are levels missing sound files! There is a fix available on PC Gaming Wiki, but it still is incredibly annoying.Excessive amount of QTEs. This one probably bothers me the most, especially when you are forced to go through the same one over and over again. Having to look at the button prompts while there is a nice scene playing out is infuriating.Pretty bad tie in of game mechanics and story. Instead of having a cutscene where the apprentice gets taught force lighting by Vader (which would be interesting since Vader can't summon it) or discovers the skill by himself there just is a text popping up at the start of one level.The game starts of slowly. Literaly. While it is cool to be Vader in the first level, he moves like a slug. That leads to the level way overstaying its welcome and almost had me quit the game prematurely.Now, why do I still recommend this game? Well, after getting a bit more comfortable with the game mechanics I had fun with this game:The combos and fighting in general. You really see where they put the focus when developing the game. My favourite thing probably is to charge up my lightsaber with force lightning. It looks amazing, feels amazing and also is effective.The level variety is phenomenal. From the surgical steel of an ISD to Sarlacc intestines you get to see a lot of one of the most interesting universes there is.The Story is nice. It really fleshes out Vaders character and his relationship with emperor Palpatin in a similar way Shadows of the Empire did. It is no longer "high canon" with Disneys new policy and may soon be overridden by the Rebels cartoon, but it still is worthwhile. It is not incredibly deep and sometimes not too believeable, but then again, has Star Wars ever been?The graphics were revolutionary when the game came out. As any game with photorealistc graphics they did suffer brutaly from age. What saves it is the quality of animation, it feels just on spot in so many situations. This ties in closely with the combos being so statisfying.So in conclusion I would say get this game when it is on sale and if you have a controller. Do not expect a masterpiece that will blow you away. It is a nice Star Wars experience with pretty sweet combat.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
Star Wars: The Force Unleashed - Ultimate Sith EditionA simple pros & cons overview follows below.I remember playing this back when it came out and thinking it was just awesome. The technical prowess of Digital Molecular Matter and the likes was enough to look past an at times overly melodramatic story, cringeworthy dialog and voice acting performances, clichéd characters, and an often irritating targeting system and gameplay mechanics. Unfortunately, close to 8 years down the line, I'm forced to realise that breaking stuff and making it look pretty is basically much all that TFU does well. As opposed to some games with a lot of heart that retain a certain charm even after a few years, The Force Unleashed doesn't seem to have aged all that well. The only thing it had going for it was that it looked good, and by today's standards that's just not true anymore. Sadly, this only serves to emphasise all of its original flaws. It also feels ridiculously overpriced at the time of writing this.In light of the above, I'd recommend catching up on the story and moving straight to the sequel which, if nothing else, looks a lot better with a slightly improved gameplay.Pros:Mildly interesting story set between episodes III and IV;Wreaking havoc with the Force is still pretty fun at times (especially once you've levelled up);Sith Edition includes a lot of additional content (levels, skins).Cons:Poor controls and targeting;Ridiculous amount of loading screens;Graphics haven't aged well;Some irritatingly overwhelming encounters;Some cringeworthy dialog and voice acting performances, clichéd characters.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Star Wars: The Force Unleashed is a 3rd person Hack and Slash game based in teh Star Wars universe. It is very similar to games such as DMC, Ninja Gaiden, and God of War. The story takes place in between episodes 3 and 4 and you play as Starkiller, Darth Vader's secret apprentice. The story is actually really good and has tons of set pieces throughout the 9 main story levels and the 3 DLC levels. You're tasked with assassinating several Jedi that survived Order 66, but later wonder if working for the empire is the right thing to do. The story has two endings, one that is the good/right ending and the other is the bad/wrong ending. The DLC continues off of the bad ending in which Starkiller goes full Sith and is tasked with hunting down several of the original trilogy's cast members, including Obi-Wan and Luke. The gameplay is pretty standard for a Hand and Slash/ Spectacle fighter game. The only new thing it has to offer is the force powers you can use in between Lightsaber combat. You get force powers such as force lightning and grapple. You can also throw your lightsaber later on. The game is locked at 30 frames per second and it does have a few bugs here and there such as the sound from blasters not playing or certain characters having textures that makes them look like the're covered by some sort of shadow. Overall though this is my favorite Star Wars game, yes even better than Knights of the Old Republic and Battlefront 2. I highly recommend you pick it up regardless of the price as it is well worth every penny if you are a big Star Wars or just looking for a fun action game with a good story.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2
												You don't know the power of the Dark Side!Star Wars - The Force Unleashed is a 3rd person action game where you assume the role of Starkiller, better known as the secret apprentice of Darth Vader. Your primary goal is to help the Empire vanquish all the remaining Jedi and stand by the Emperor's side, ruling the galaxy.Story: The Force Unleashed's events are set between Episode III: Revenge of the Sith and Episode IV: A New Hope. The game starts off with you controlling Darth Vader, on the Wookiee homeworld of Kashyyk, searching for Jedi to eliminate. There he finds a boy with an extraordinary aptitude for the Force and from that point on, takes him on as a secret apprentice to one day assassinate the Emperor. It is from that point on, that we assume the role of Starkiller for the remaining time of the game. As the story progresses, we get to see him form a close relationship with his female pilot, Juno Eclipse, and this eventually blossoms into a romance, which adds a dimension to the tale. Along the way, we also get to see the personalities of the Jedi we must hunt down, each one with an interesting insight to give on the ways of the Force as well as having their own unique powers and strengths. Last but not least, we also get to see alot of what Vader thinks of his protege's accomplishments and even the Emperor himself. The story is well-told and at times can even evoke emotion.Graphics: For a game released in 2009, the Force Unleashed looks good. The graphics are well detailed, with high resolution textures and vivid colour palettes. Some of the locales the player gets to visit are just bursting with detail, from lush forests to sometimes barren wastelands. There is always variety to be found in the areas Starkiller visits.Sound: All the sound effects Star Wars fans have come to know and love are all there, and done to the highest quality. From the iconic laser blasts from the rifle of a Stormtrooper to the ominous thuds an AT-ST emits as it lumbers across the battlefield. I have to give a special mention to the voice actors who gave Starkiller and Juno life. Their renditions of the characters are superb and really sell the relationship which these two characters develop along the course of their journey. Also, the voice actor behind the Emperor did a fantastic job and you would be hard pressed to find someone who sounds any better.Gameplay: At the time of release, The Force Unleashed's gameplay was heavily marketed as something cool and innovative. Up until that point, there was no Star Wars game which let you completely unleash upon your enemies these outrageous Force powers and made you feel like a god. The lightsaber combat although good and varied, sometimes feels sluggish and awkward. For example, if you were in the middle of a melee combo there would be no way to quickly cancel it so you would be left vulnerable to an attack from the side or from behind. This can be really frustrating when you are trying to finish off this one opponent, but someone sneaks up to youand interrupts your combo string. Now, moving onto the movement. Controlling Starkiller is fine for the most part, however, when you want to jump and dash it feels clumsy and unelegant. It feels like a chore to perform these maneuvers and this in my opinion, is one of the game's biggest flaws. However, the Force powers you get access to are awesome. Being able to Force push and electrocute large groups of enemies at a time feels satisfying, is efficient and makes you feel like a complete boss. The Force has never been represented better in a video game.Overall, Star Wars - The Force Unleashed is a good action game. Although it innovates in certain areas like the way the player can use Force powers, it is let down by the stiffness of the controls. Star Wars fans would love this game while others may only like this game.7/10.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Disclaimer: I am a massive Star Wars fan so I may be biasedStar Wars: The Force Unleashed is not a polished game by any means.  The framerate is locked at 30 FPS (although there is an unlocker which I strongly reccomend) and there are numerous texture issues such as pop-in and flickering. The keyboard controls aren't great either (I used a 360 controller).  However these issues aside, the game is damn fun.  You have multiple different force powers and tons of combos you can pull off as well.  The story so far is fantastic and the characters have genuine feeling and it is very noticeable that the voice actors Lucasarts have hired are seasoned veterans in the voice acting industry.  I would recommend this only to Star Wars fans or hardcore hack and slash fans and only those that own a controller, as that really is how this game is meant to be played.

Posted: May 4, 2014
												This game is a nightmare to play. I like Star Wars a lot, but this game's gameplay is just too frustrating for me to be able to enjoy it. Let me give you a few reasons why that's the case. First of all, the controls are terrible. Making fine movements is a chore, aiming for a precise place to land when jumping is close to impossible. The camera gets constantly in your way, stuck in objects, etc... Using the force is fun, but the aiming is horrendous. Half the time, you're grabing something else, throwing it somewhere you didn't want to, etc... The level design is monotoneous and questionable at best, I've died several times because I just wasn't able to differentiate whether the character can stand on what seemed like solid ground or whether he will slide down into a pit. Battle mechanics are VERY limited, get boring quick and some design choices are real head scratchers to me, like: why you always have to move forward when swingin the light saber? You can't hit somebody standing on the edge of a pit or you'll fall in too. Add bugs, crashes, an incredibly slow loading menu and you're in for a huge disappoinment.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												This game is fantastic. Not sure what the negative reviews are about; the controls are a little loose and tough to master but all it takes is a little practice.Gameplay: Really fun and immersive. It does get slightly repetitive, since about half-way through the game you've already met all the enemies. I did find three bugs and I had to restart the level to fix them but overall a decent port. The Force powers are varying and really fun to use. You're supposed to use combos to kill enemies but you only need to know one or two main combos to deal a lot of damage. Apart from 3PS murder there's quicktime events for takedowns (which are fun and at the perfect level of difficutly, since you'd land a perfect one about 50% of the time and towards the end of the game you have them memorized for easy killing) and one sidescrolling level that was a pain to do but enjoyable.The customization is one of the strong points of this game (even though the menus take forever to load). You can change costumes into droids, stormtroopers, clones, a variety of Sith or Jedi, and about ten alternate Starkiller costumes.  You can change lightsaber colors and also pick a passive effect for the lightsaber, such as health drain or added crit.The boss battle are fun for the most part. I had to restart the Star Destroyer boss level multiple times because of a reoccurring bug, but I encountered no other issues. Honestly, most of them were slightly too easy; I beat them in one or two tries. Graphics: Outdated; it's an old game. Still, they're not bad looking. In the cutscenes especially, the level of detail on Starkiller's face is amazing. Yes the graphics are old; no they are not bad nor do they deter from the game.Music: Really fantastic. A good mix of the classic soundtrack and totally new, dark themes full of powerful swells that really make you feel awesome. There were a few spots in the game where there was no music and that didn't feel right; the sounds of slaughter DO need accompaniment.Story: The story itself is quite good. Unfortunately, it's really low on character development; you can tell everything you need to know about a character simply from looking at them. The Force Unleashed books really fixed that; if you love the story its a good read and a slight improvement over the game's story. Still, its an epic saga and it really gets good towards the end as it becomes less mindless Jedi killing and there's actually emotion. The ending is fantastic.Overall, it's made its way into one of my favorite games off all time.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												The good:Surprisingly decent Star Wars storyPhysics engine that lets you throw things around with thte force like in the moviesThe bad:Poor controls (don't always respond when you need them, i.e. for double jumping over a chasm)Stun locking enemies (they stunlock you and you die)Annoying boss battles with an overabundance of quick time eventsTerrible auto targetting for force abilitiesUnskippable cutscenes for every levelNo quick save (only checkpoints, some of which are poorly placed)Relatively short game overallThe ugly:A contender for one of the worst console ports of all time (very poorly optimized, doesn't support resolutions over 1920x1200 in the options menu, can only switch between xbox controller and keyboard outside of the game, and if your controller gets disconnected you have to restart the game to get control back). Also REQUIRES virtual memory/paging to be turned on with no way to skip it (even if you have a system with 16GB+ of RAM).Conclusion: Could have been an awesome game, but it has a multitude of issues that will have you throwing your keyboard/controller in frustration. It's also very short for a AAA game with very little replayability. Not recommended at anything above a bargain basement price ($20 is too much even).

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												Rating: 6.5/10Overview: Third Person Hack and Slash The Good:+The story is pretty decent even if it feels ‘shoe horned’ into the Star Wars universe. The story does provide good context and keeps the game together. +Every level has a unique look and feel to it.  +Find collectables scattered through out the level to upgrade powers, abilities and combos. +Sound Effects+Cool force powers and effectsThe Average:The combat feels average at best. Even though you have a lightsaber and really cool force powers, none of it feels powerful or impactful. The enemies feel like canon fodder and the targeting systems is too unpredictable. Given that you can lift and throw many objects in the level it becomes frustrating when it targets the wrong thing. Sometimes when I wanted to throw my lightsaber, it would target the piece of debris rather than the enemy standing right in front of me.  Boss battles suffer because of the combat. What should be epic fights turn into frustrating experiences.   Levels are very linear and play out almost the same way every time making for a somewhat repetitive experience. Kill a bunch of enemies, move to the next open area and do it all over again. There is not enough gameplay variety or puzzles to mix things up.The Bad:- lack of graphical options - Changing audio does not effect CGI cut- scenes - Graphical and sound glitches, crash to desktop - Final Boss battle has a glitch forcing you to reload over and over again until you no longer experience the game stopping glitch  - Without spoiling anything there is a final section of a level near the end of the game that is incredibly frustrating. Conclusion:A game that has a lot of great ideas but fails in execution. What should have been an amazing experience feels frustrating. If you love Star Wars then you may get enjoyment from this, but there are plenty of other third person adventure games out there worthy of your time.

content:

												I played through the whole game on PS3 and remembered enjoying it. I saw it on sale here on Steam and couldn't help but pick up this "ultimate PC version." It's a terrible port plain and simple. Its poorly optimized and the game has just not aged well. You cannot even alt-tab out of it (the game will crash). Not to mention the Steam Overlay will not open or function during the games cinematics. Yes, this means no screenshots. The game had some problems my first time playing back on PS3 as it can get boring and repetitive. This on top of all these issues of the PC port and the game is just not worth it. I recommend trying The Force Unleashed II on PC as it will give you the games overall feel but with a better experience. Save your money, this was not the Star Wars game you were looking for.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												In a similar vein to many other reviews of this game i will begin by noting that the game has a few problems which i will get to but over all i liked it and found it to be a pretty decent game that despite its flaws does a great job of doing what it sets out to do, allow you to play a force wielding badass is a way that shows how powerful the force can be when utilised by somone creative.You play as Darth vaders secretive apprentice Star killer who for all intents and purposes seems to be one of the most powerful force wielders in the entire sw universe which is great fun to play. Graphics are great, if a little ropey and inconsistent at times. The controls are mostly really good but the camera can be a little shakey at times which results in the usual quick turns, or not, and a somtimes messed up targeting system, i will note that i played this with an xbox pad as i didnt think it played well with mouse and keyboard. The story is reallly great and in many ways the star of tthe show and it takes you to a great mix of locations from the sw universe, there are rp elements in that you can upgrade your powers and abilities as you level and there are holocrons littered throughout the stages for you to find and collect. On a negattive note its pretty unfinished and badly optimised for pc with stuttery cutscenes and most of the stages can actually be just run straight through, what i mean by this is that minni boss thype encounters can simply be ignored for th most part and you can really just boss rush most of the game.That aside its really fun and enjoyable, should take you about 5-7 hours to complete but ng+ is fun too. Dont pay full price as its getting on a bit now but its well worh a play if its on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												I first played this game on xbox but when I saw this game was for 5$ on steam, I could not resist.You play as Starkiller, Vader's apprentice who is sent on various missions accomplishing your master's will.The story is the main strong points of the game. The first missions you are sent on assassination missions and unlike assassin's creed, you actually feel like you are hunting down your targets. However this is a personal story, Starkiller, Galen Marek's story. And without spoiling anything, I'll just say that the story is worth while. However I have to point out some of the dialogue: its not always good, some of it would need to be re-worked. Why? Because it can create strange plotholes, and while still using different words it could all be fixed. Such as ( i don't consider this a spoiler because it is right after the prologue but i'll cover it anyway)  After the prologue Starkiller pulls the lightsaber out of Vader's hand. Next cutscene Vader says: "You were weak when I found you..." This doesn't make sense. It could have been: "Your training is nearly complete..." or "You are now stronger than you've ever been..." and this would have fixed some of the dialogue  By having better dialogue you can have a better story.Graphics. You know what? They're not that bad mainly because this is a third person game, you don't get to see the textures from really close. But yeah, there are some textures that are low-res.  WARNING: THE GAME IS LOCKED AT 30 FPS However it can be fixed with an fps mod fix on pcgamingwiki.com . I played the game with the mod: I can't stand 30 fps. I recommend using an xbox controller since this is a port.Voice acting is good. However one issue: I got a bug on the first mission where I could not hear Juno's dialogue. I tried to find a fix for it but nothing worked so far.  Turn on the subtitles so you won't miss any dialogueFinally the gameplay. This is where I both like the game and dislike it. First of all this is what I like: Combos, you can unlock alot of combos in this game and the animations for it are really cool! You have to memorize combinations of attacks and there are enough variations to keep you invested in your 11-13 hours play through. You can unlock different types of lightsabers which provide different buffs and you can choose the color as well. This is awesome because you are not force to use the same lightsaber and you don't have to look at the same colors are well. You can chose the buffs and the color independently of each other. The movement system, this is where the game falters. It is not fluid enough, not responsive: you should be able to interrupt while you're in the middle of a combo, because when you're pressing X,Y,X,Y and you see a missile coming straight at you, well prepare to rage alot. This is my biggest problem in the game: sometimes you can't avoid dying. Most of the times when I died I could not do anything because i was in an animation, I could not avoid the danger. It feels like the game forces you to die occasionally. When you are locked in an animation you can take damage and there is nothing you can do. The worst issue is when jumping: and you get shot by a sniper or a rocket, you fall down and for some reason you slide on the floor for 30 meters. The problem is that it is an animation and you are locked in it so no matter what happens you can't get out of it. Some levels allow you to fall off the map and when you start to slide, you know five seconds ahead that you will die. Hopefully you understand why it can get really frustrating. And you might have to redo sections multiple times, not because you played on a hard difficulty but because you were extremely unlucky.Loading screens? I have to talk about them because they're bad. They can take a while to load 10-20 seconds and the worst part: WHY ARE THERE LOADING SCREENS INSIDE OF MENUS?!?The enemies could be a bit more varied, I don't mind slicing through hundreds of grunts but the mini bosses need more variations. Some enemies are really anoying such as the purge troopers. You have a lightsaber, you should be about to slice through them without a doubt, but this is an overall complaint in the game: lighstabers don't really feel like lightsabers when fighting against tougher enemies. I don't like also how some types clones can resist my force attacks, isn't the point of the game to unleashe the force on them?So overall I really like the game even with its flaws. To me it is an above average game with many flaws but you can still find enjoyment in it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												TLDR – Third person hack & slash similar to the Jedi Knight series, but you don’t get any guns, and it’s more fast paced. The game takes about 10 hours to beat the first time through and doesn’t have that much replay value.  6/10Star Wars: The Force Unleashed is a console port that doesn’t seem to have been optimized for the PC (25 GB download!).  The controls are clunky (in some areas dangerously so) and the game’s menu screens don’t use the mouse. You navigate them with keyboard only, which is a clear sign of an incomplete console port.  Oddly enough, just navigation between different options in the main menu often has its own “loading” screens. The game’s story takes place between Star Wars Episodes 3 & 4, so it all happens a few years before the original Star Wars movie events take place. Darth Vader finds and trains a young apprentice, who he wants to eventually overthrow the Emperor with. Vader’s convoluted plan involves having his apprentice (named Starkiller) go around causing trouble and raising an army to fight Emperor Palpatine. It doesn’t make much sense to me if I’m being honest. Anyways, the moral is don’t trust the bad guys, they’re always stabbing each other in the back.You play the Sith assassin Starkiller in the third person perspective, similar to the Jedi Academy and Darksiders games, with your lightsaber being your melee attack, and the force as your ranged weapon. Lightsaber swings are very quick this time around unlike Jedi Academy, and your force powers are more limited, but they flow better in combat. All your force powers are offensive, so you don’t really have “buff” skills to power yourself up prior to fights (except the lightning shield which only lasts a few seconds anyway). Your most used attacks will be combinations of lightsaber swings and force push / force lightning. One of the noteworthy gameplay elements is the partially destructible environment in many areas. There is a lot of loose debris (or chunks that you rip off the walls) that you can use to throw at your enemies. Every time you kill an enemy you regen some of your life back, while your force power regenerates on its own (pretty fast too, so you can keep blasting). Along with the fact that you don’t use guns, this means that the only collectibles in the game are “force holocrons,” which can give you experience or lightsaber parts for customization. Each time you level up you get points to upgrade a few of your character’s skills or stats. Some holocrons give these skill points directly, while others give random bonuses. Holocrons are often hidden in out of the way areas or behind destructible walls, so throw force power around bountifully and be rewarded.Pros:+Expanded story for Star Wars fans, including the birth of the Rebel Alliance and an alternate timeline (DLC included in the Ultimate Sith Edition) where Starkiller gets all up in Luke Skywalker’s business.+Starkiller is extremely powerful, probably a lot stronger than any of the Jedi you have played in other Star Wars games. It’s good to be bad, and I’m considering changing my legal name to Starkiller.Cons:-The controls are often frustratingly clunky, especially when it comes to locking onto enemies for ranged force attacks. There’s also a section involving a star destroyer that might make you want to pull your hair out. It’s not that it’s a difficult section, it’s just hard to know if you’re doing it right your first playthrough, and it just drags on and on.-The game really is poorly designed for PC, the large download (compared to the sequel, which is like ¼ the size) and the odd menu format really stick out. Also, it might be a bug but I think you need an internet connection to launch the game. I lost my connection for about 15 minutes and found that I couldn’t load my saved game.-The boss fights can be frustrating because there really isn’t a tutorial on dueling and it feels like I’m missing something important (especially related to blocking).All in all, the game has significant problems but is worth playing through at least once for the story. Especially if you got this in the Humble Bundle and want to play part 2. I don’t think I’ll be playing through it a second time for a long while though. It just doesn’t bring too much to the hack slash genre.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												The question of, "How can we take our epic story and nice characters in to the most glitchy console trasition possible?" is finally answered. The story may not be too deep, but it is just the Star Wars feeling. It is also located in the Civil War time, not the Clone Wars timeline, which is a nice change from what the current Star Wars Universe gives us.But then there are the manymany things wrong with this game:The PC controls are very stiff, since my controller doesn't seem to be recognized by this game I played with mouse and keyboard. You can't aim your force with the keyboard, so you have to hope for the autolock. Almost unplayable. Once hit by a simple laser oder anything else, even a rock on the floor seems to be sufficient, you will be stunned for at least one second. Which of course happens again if you get hit in the meanwhile. I have lost countless battles against simple stormtroopers just because I could not move at all.Some other things that happened to me:- Getting should through a solid wall by two AT-ST, ending up in a stunlock -> death.- Getting killed during a cutscene.- Getting killed right after a cutscene, because I get replaced right in front of my enemy.- Falling of bridges because every melee attack seems to include a 2m step in front of you.- Getting tossed into a force field, stuck behing an object, therefore getting damage and die.- In the second half of the game I got no SFX from any other source than me. So all explosions were complete mute, and gunshots weren't traceable. Really annoying.The final thing is the locked camera in boss battles. Every bigger enemy locks the camera into place, so it's no longer a third person view but a bird kinda view. Except you cant look through objects you are hiding or stuck behind. Calculating an akle to strike back oder foresee a thrown objects path is almost impossible. Maybe this game is good on a console, it was fun as long as it was simple, but once you have to use advanced techniques, it got much worse.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												I wish there was a rating in between "recommend" and "not recommended" here. The "I recommend it" goes for when the game is on sale... if you can get it for like 2-3 bucks, like I did while it was on sale, then go right ahead. Here is the reasoning behind this:- The game HAS some things going for it. You do feel pretty powerful, and throwing around big containers and stuff, causing explosions, force-throwing them into groups of enemies etc... all that is FUN. It really is. - However, there isn't much depth to it. It's basically hack, slash and force-throw stuff, kill everything that moves, and do the objectives. I can imagine that rather quickly, even with upgrades and unlocking more powers or stronger versions, the gameplay will become dull. - The graphics are ok. Keep in mind this game is a couple of years old. That doesn't bother me usually, so I don't mind that the graphics certainly aren't up to date.- However, the performance is... ridiculous. I played this on a system that can, without problems, run GTAV, Witcher III, MGSV, Fallout 4, AK, AC Unity at good to ultra levels. However, this game is so badly optimized (which might explain the 30 GB!!!) that even on that PC, even today, the framerate has frequent drops. I don't even WANNA know how bad this was back when the game was new, and I find it rather unacceptable to have such a bad performance from a, what, six year old game on a modern, decent PC. It's not game-breaking, but it's annoying how badly this performs several years after its release.So, my verdict:Pros:- Decent SW vibe to it (setting, graphics, force powers)- A lot of fun especially early on to throw stuff, blow open doors with the force etc.- Decently down force control system (throwing items)- graphics are ok for an older gameCons:- Lack of depth, both to fighting and to the story- Saberfighting is basically just spam a button type slashing. Other games have done this better- Terrible performance even today on a modern system that can run much more recent and much more advanced games more easilyRating: 6/10 if at sale, 4/10 if not

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Pro:Looks decent for a 2009 game.You can throw things and people around. Con:Worst intro ever. You walk around at a languid pace, aiming at wookies and pressing E. Yawn.The "story" is an embarrassment.You're just some tool who goes around killing people, there's no character or motivation. You don't get to be 'evil'.Absolutely atrocious menus. You move through them using [ and ] (no joke).It's too tricky to pick up a specific object.It's also pretty much impossible to aim when throwing objects.The light sabre feels too weak.Force powers aside from throwing also feel weak.If you don't search for holocrons you will level quite a bit more slowly. Everything is 100% linear.There's basically nothing to the game aside from combat.Terrible boss battles, what is up with that static camera?ConclusionI really wanted to like The Force Unleashed. It gave the appearance of being a game where you can mess with people with force powers and be badass. Instead, it's a boring grindfest with dreadful combat, force powers that are interrupted as soon as you are hit and no personal input. This sits in stark constrast with Knights of the Old Republic. where you went your own path and could really mess with people (Zaalbar/Mission...). This game was the most disappointing Star Wars release since Episode 1.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
As a star wars fan it's enjoyable enough. The power fantasy and the story (even if it's not the greatest) is enough to keep you playing if you're into star wars. Otherwise, it's a mess.First of all... it's locked to 30FPS. There goes my interest huh? Well, not to worry, there's a fix.Only, if you use the fix, the game is more prone to chrashing (Which it slightly already is) and force gripping things will send them upwards when held. This doesn't happen in the 40FPS lock mode though. So I would recommend using that.Also,- Audio seem to be all kinds of broken. Music missing in places. No ambient noises in places. Background music loop not working right, causing the music to just stop. Even missing effects at some points.- Framerate problems at certain places. This is hardly a demanding game, yet in some places (epecially some bosses) there's bad slowdown in places, with the FPS dropping below 30. There was also a point when a portion of a boss was in slow motion for some reason (staying at 40FPS). And no it wasn't designed that way.- no combo breakers as far as I can tell. If an enemy starts a lightsaber combo and you get hit, there's no way to keep him from finishing his combo on you, unless it happens to have a very slow hit that allows you to speed away.Overall, it would be an average game in my books, if it wasn't for the glaring technical problems.With that taken in to account, I wouldn't recommend this unless you can get it for under 5$ and/or are a huge star wars nerd.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												**My hours played appear low due to a technical issue - you can read about this and other issues at the bottom of the review.**At the time of writing this review, The Force Awakens comes out tomorrow! I can't wait to see it. Since you're in the future, did you enjoy it? I'll bet you did. Is Luke a bad guy or something, what the hell is up with that? I hope he's in the movie for more than 5 minutes, or my future self is gonna be♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Anyway. in the spirit of Star Wars enthusiasm, and since my Star Wars game reviews seem to be more popular than when I♥♥♥♥♥♥on Call of Duty games, I decided to cross this game off my backlog a short 7 years after its release.So does it hold up in 2015? Yes and no.Right off the bat, you can tell FU lacks the polish of the other titles I mentioned. Or the polish of any AAA game, for that matter. The first level has you fighting wookies who jump around platforms and fall off of them regularly, or trip over their own legs and have trouble getting up. The stormtroopers on your side of the battle get stuck in foliage and shoot in the wrong direction. (I guess in that sense the game is just like the movies.)FU is a hack-n-slash in a similar style to Devil May Cry, Ninja Gaiden, Metal Gear Rising, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow, and God of War. Since I prefer those series based on gameplay, it's really the Star Wars branding that makes this game worth recommending to fans. The story is so-so, but the acting is well done and the characters are fun. Vader plays a central role and is voiced pretty convincingly, and the Emperor makes a few appearances. The show stealer is your sidekick droid though, who has been programmed to both help you and also cheerfully kill you in order to keep your senses alert. It's fun to have a friend around that's super excited about stabbing you to death. Another instance of good characterisation is a whacked-out Jedi recluse that has holed up in a junkyard. You fight him in a recreation of the Jedi Temple he built with trash, and you can Force-throw a scrapmetal version of Yoda into his face if you want. It's good stuff.The game's unfinished feel is in large part due to the physics engine, which is equal parts ambitious and poorly executed. You'll notice it in the first two minutes of the game, and it never changes. The wonky physics are a part of the fun factor though, since this game's MO is letting you create chaos by using a variety of moves and powers to overkill everything. It's not a tightly balanced combat sim, and I suspect that on harder difficulty levels it would lead to lots of frustration. Targeting enemies and objects is done automatically, so trying to grab one particular thing in a mob of action and then throwing it into another particular thing is oftentimes futile. Since the AI is generally stupid and your character vastly overpowered, it still remains fun to try out the generous amount of moves and combos at your disposal and watching the carnage ensue.This isn't to say that there isn't any strategy to the combat. Certain enemy types resist certain moves, so the game is pretty good at getting you to use your entire move set. It also rewards variety with bonus points, which in turn allow you to upgrade your character with new moves. In this sense it reminds me of the EXCELLENT and oft-overlooked FPS Bulletstorm (please go play that game, here, I'll make it obvious)*****BULLETSTORM***** ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, it's the bestwhich is all about being creative with your killing. The combat is a little bit too repetitive, and there isn't a whole lot else to do besides kill things, but the game's 10 levels are both large and visually varied, which keeps things just interesting enough until the end. Plus, the boss battles throughout are well done.It's a shame that the PC port is so bad. There is a single graphics option - high quality 'yes' or 'no', and 'yes' still looks poor. Texture pop-in is very close, the game is locked at 30 fps, effects are sparse and cheap, and movement feels stiff. The visual style is what saves the presentation, with environments well detailed, lots of color, and a nice costume change occurring regularly for your character. Star Wars games have had a bad habit of looking very similar to each other despite the movies' frequent tonal shifts, and aside from an early Imperial location typical of Dark Forces and virtually every other Star Wars game in existence, this feels like a visually unique product.One note about lightsaber combat: it's meh. There is a greater emphasis here on power usage, and I had a much better time with the lightsabers in Jedi Knight II and especially Jedi Academy.Taken as a whole in these modern times, The Force Unleashed just feels rough around the edges. You can tell Lucas Arts is out of touch with the genre - your character frequently "levels up", yet has no level to speak of. A level up just gives you some points to invest in certain skills. The quick-time events that finish off bosses and certain large creatures are repetitive, lack impact, and just feel sloppy. The sound effects and/or music cut out several times in the later levels.And the set piece design feels just as unsure. Take this example - an early boss fight occurs inside an observation deck on a spaceship orbiting a planet. At one point the deck tears off the rest of the ship, inverts and begins plummeting down towards the planet, as you and your Jedi enemy fall to the domed glass roof. You can see the planet underneath you and the glass begins to burn and glow as you enter the atmosphere while the Jedi is Force-throwing various objects at you. On paper this sounds like a totally epic set piece, but due to a whole lot of factors, just winds up looking dull, even compared to the original God of War's opening hydra fight from three years prior. Lucas Arts are not the masters of these scripted sequences, and it shows pretty painfully.Bottom line is this: there's not a whole lot of impressive stuff in the game, but I give it a light recommendation because it's a casual experience that remains the only Star Wars game where you can stylishly demolish everything around you with a true feeling of power.TECHNICAL ISSUES:This is a bad port. It's locked at 30 fps, and you can't vsync it by traditional means.I ran the game at 2560x1440, which required opening the config file and manually adjusting the resolution. I recommend searching for config.xml in Windows, since different versions of Windows seem to stash it in different places.I also used Nvidia's control panel to force anti-aliasing and texture filtering which apparently aren't great by default.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Introduction:Its the weekend before May the 4th which means its Star Wars weekend, and I’ll be looking at some of the Star Wars games over the next few days. The first being Star Wars: The Force Unleashed, it’s a hack and slash/platform style game that follows the story of Galen Marek. The story is based between the two trilogy and fills in some of the gaps in the story.Story:Galen Marek our protagonist is take by Vader as a child to become his secret apprentice, we meet him in the final stages of his training. The events that follow will change not only Galen’s twisted view of the world but also the course of galactic history. At least if Disney had left it as cannon, but never the less its a well written story and was written to be cannon at the time. So this means it ties in well and doesn’t try to change anything we know.Gameplay:The gameplay isn’t anything you haven’t seen before, its not going to blow you away. But it plays well enough and gives you an amazing feeling of power, Galen isn’t some bog standard Sith. He’s a Sith power house! he doesn’t open doors, he blows them to pieces with the force and that’s the same for all his powers. So no, nothing new and quiet repetitive but its amazingly fun too. What ever way you swing it, there’s something undeniably cool about bringing down a Star-destroyer down from the ground with just the force.Presentation:Now as with all older games, the graphic have aged. But there good, and the work that’s gone in to capturing Sam Witwer’s likeness is fantastic. And he’s was a great choice too as he’s a fan and it shows in his voice acting, he really did put the effort in. All in all its very well delivered and an enjoyable experience to play. The acting is good and the characters are likeable, but for me Proxy steals the show. Proxy is Galen’s loyal robot companion, but he is also programmed to kill Galen at any chance he gets. He adds a great amount of much needed humour to the story.See full review here http://cyberusuk.com/2015/05/01/star-wars-the-force-unleashed/

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Pro:Looks decent for a 2009 game.You can throw things and people around. Con:Worst intro ever. You walk around at a languid pace, aiming at wookies and pressing E. Yawn.The "story" is an embarrassment.You're just some tool who goes around killing people, there's no character or motivation. You don't get to be 'evil'.Absolutely atrocious menus. You move through them using [ and ] (no joke).It's too tricky to pick up a specific object.It's also pretty much impossible to aim when throwing objects.The light sabre feels too weak.Force powers aside from throwing also feel weak.If you don't search for holocrons you will level quite a bit more slowly. Everything is 100% linear.There's basically nothing to the game aside from combat.Terrible boss battles, what is up with that static camera?ConclusionI really wanted to like The Force Unleashed. It gave the appearance of being a game where you can mess with people with force powers and be badass. Instead, it's a boring grindfest with dreadful combat, force powers that are interrupted as soon as you are hit and no personal input. This sits in stark constrast with Knights of the Old Republic. where you went your own path and could really mess with people (Zaalbar/Mission...). This game was the most disappointing Star Wars release since Episode 1.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												I enjoyed the Force Unleased, for a Star Wars fan, the combat was pretty satisfying when throwing around storm troopers with my force powers and then brutalizing them with my lightsaber. Though I have no real idea if this game is considered cannon or not in the Star Wars universe, it did actually explain a few questions, I had about the original trilogy (though some of the questions I never asked in the first place).  Though in the same respect this game also doesn’t quite fit into the Star Wars universe without causing some problems (not getting into it, it’s a game). So if you purchase this game what do you get? You get an interesting array of force powers, some satisfying boss battles, generally linear level design, and some nice bonus content. The voice acting in the game is well done so no complaints there. Therefore, if you are a Star Wars fan I suggest you pick up the game and give it a whirl, I do not think you will be blown away by it, but in term of entertainment, you will enjoy it. If you are not a Star Wars fan, it is hard for me to say, “Sure buy it” because in terms of content you can find a similar experience elsewhere.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												The first sign that Star Wars: The Force Unleashed is a mediocre port comes as soon as you boot up the game: you can’t navigate the menus with a mouse. On its own, this isn't an awful fact, but it's an omen of bad things to come. Aside from resolution and brightness options, there are no visual options to tweak. There is no antialiasing and no way to enable it. And frame rate troubles will haunt your every saber swing. It's too bad that so little respect was shown for the platform--and to those that will spend money on this product--because the underlying game is rather good. As Darth Vader's secret apprentice, you slice through grunting Rodians with your glowing lightsaber, go head-to-head with slobbering rancors, and punt jawas into the distance as if they were pigskins. You might be lucky enough to avoid this troubled port's technical flaws and experience the full pleasures of The Force Unleashed, but be warned: Picking up a copy of this physics-heavy action game is one gamble that may not pay off.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2013
												I'm going to assume you have some knowledge about this game, regardless whether you have played it or not. So, spoilers. Deal with it.You are Starkiller, Darth Vader's secret apprentice. But you never really feel like a Sith. Nor a Jedi. Starkiller seems a bit of a badass in-between character, with skills that hint at both.The story feels quite engaging, if you are into Star Wars. If you are a fan, you'll gleefully smile at the references, appearances and the style of everything.I'm not an expert, but all the locations truly feel like they are Star Wars planets. And Starkiller's outfit design that comes with every level is a notable feature too.Gameplay wise, aside the quirks an old game is expected to have, the game runs smooth. The cutscenes have frequent syncing hiccups, but it's easy enough to find them on Youtube and watch them with Overlay.While I really want to say the controls react perfectly, they don't...not really. There are many moments where an attack animation can't be interrupted, especially with a dash. Leaving you at the mercy of your foe (and their heavy attack)  whether you'll be punted away.If you aren't being thrown around, though, you'll usually have proper controls.The quality of the game is pretty nice, especially since Patch 1.2 comes with an HQ pack (comes with the installation). It's not super modern looking, but it's still pretty nice.With the Sith edition comes many new outfits, even from characters that don't or make a single appearance. Such as Proxy, Starkiller's "assistant" and training droid, turning himself into a holographic Darth Maul to battle-train him.Which was a tough fight, I'll have you know.The real fan service comes in the form of extra missions.The first one is from the old Jedi Temple, providing him with a small and personal adventure (in the shape of the Jedi Trials), showing Starkiller his "possible" future.Which possible future you may ask? You might already know this, but the main story end leaves you with a Light or Dark Side choice. Save your friends from The Emperor, or kill Darth Vader, whom you already had beaten right before that (but who seems fine to do it all over again).This is where things get interesting for the fans. The Light side choice (defeating Palpatine) is the canon ending. With Starkiller saving his friends, allowing them to start the Rebellion, and him dieing in what I consider a sense of sacrifice.But the Dark Side choice is pretty badass in on itself. Not only do you replace Vader, but a little 'incident' (which I won't spoil for you) causes him to be gravely wounded as well. Resulting in him being assigned a pretty unique helmet with a breather that sounds a little bit like that of Vader. However, his design is much more designed for Acrobacy, and he also has kept his limbs, so there's that.By the way, everything is unlocked in the extra missions, including all the lightsabre crystals, except for a few skills in the Jedi Temple one.This is the point where the other two extra missions take place. You are now the Emporer's enforcer as Vader was. One mission takes place in Tatooine, where you hunt for two familiar sounding droids... This has you passing by familiar characters, such as Jabba the Hut and Ben Kenobi, whom you have to kill, twice, in succession. Yeah, something about that spirit of his... The second mission, and my personal favorite, takes place in Hoth during the famous assault on the Rebel Base. Starkiller has donned an outfit similar to that of Darth Vader, but built for acrobacy and flexibility. In my opinion, it looks ten times more badass than that of Vader. And I don't say this lightly.But the real fan climax comes when you fight Luke for the second time. What happens there at the end gives so much fantasizing juice. Makes you feel bad that Lucas Arts didn't design a whole game around Starkiller taking the Dark Side.The game is old, and it shows. But the story is strong and the gameplay is fun, but tough enough. It's been quite the trip, and I can't say I've really regretted it at any point.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Let's get straight to the point:The Combat, which should be THE selling point, is clunky where the transistion between enemies or group of enemies becomes tedious with the bad auto-targeting system and no way to change your target other than sway the camera in hope to get locked on the right one. Blocking is pretty useless as you can only block if anyhting you've been previously doing has finished it's animation. So no quick blocks while swining your saber. You just take the hit and do not swing your saber. IF you decide to block - that's pretty much it: you're locked into palce and cannot perform any other action or move around while the AI is waiting for you to release the block-button and hit you. It is also common to lose 1/3 of your health when you get stunned and the animation of you getting up has to finish playing before you can get stunned again(especially when you have a wall behind you). There is more but I wanted to leave all the things out that might just be me not being good enough for the hardest difficulty and focus on the core mechanics being bad.So yeah, go buy Force Unleashed 2, it's been a while since I played it but I do not remember having any issues with it.

Most notable everything you grab flies upwards... making something already a difficult to control dynamic, much worse.The audio is one of the worst portjobs too, music plays only from the left speaker, and many sounds are either silent, or incorrect. Then lets not forget the last two levels are utterly silent. Seriously guys?Do not buy.

												If you are a Star Wars fan, then you WANT to play this game, and you WILL play this game, and you'll LOVE it. Well... actually... part of it. You are also going to HATE it. A lot.This game could be so much more, but it fails on so many levels, I can't really recommend it. The only positive thing in this game the Star Wars universe. It's good to be in this universe, even if it is by this terrible game.Music/sound glitches; simple, stupid, sometimes incoherent story; a whole lot of QTEs; and below average boss fights. STILL, if you are a big Star Wars fan, you'll enjoy some of it. You are going to hate every problems with this game, but you STILL want to finish it...So I only recommend this game, if you are a big Star Wars fan. Otherwise, you should avoid this title...

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												I would like to say YES YES YES YES buy it now, but i can't for one HUGE reason the port. This game is fantastic using force powers is an absolute joy. Its nice to play a game that makes you feel all powerful, but the pc port for this is utter garbage. It is only available in the Ultimate Sith Edition which in and of it's self is fine until you look at the space requirements 30 gigabytes is excessive. it would be better if we were given the option of downloading the base game and the DLC seperately, but since its sold together in the Ultimate Sith Edition that isn't an option. also LOADING SCREENS BETWEEN MENUS WTF and they arn't short either. and when it comes to graphics requirements it ♥♥♥♥s up too. Granted i have an integrated graphics card so it's no suprise it isn't very powerful, but it is hooked into a core i7 mobile processor (bout as powerful as a Core i5 desktop) and technically runs the game at a decent frame rate (by which i mean 20-30 FPS), However anything beyond about 10 ft from the character doesn't render. due to lack of any real support from the now dead Lucas Arts this problem will never be fixed. so if you have an integrated graphics card, but you think you may have a shot at running it just forget it it won't work properly.
