number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												If you want more Star Wars after The Force Awakens, if you want to feel the power of the dark side by sending your ennemies flying, chocking them or electrifying them... then as a hack-n-slash initially released in 2008 on consoles, The Force Unleashed does it pretty well.  I trully believe the too many bad reviews on Steam hide the fun this game can be.  I owned the game on console and liked it then.  Also, I think that I have seen enough of he PC version to write this review.Strengths:-Your character is Darth Vader's secret apprentice-how cool is that?- his skins and idles are sick!-The story is an interesting (yet not necessary) part of the Star Wars lore-I like the control you have on the telekinesis power.  The physics when you grab people and they jerk around are addicting-The combo system and the various powers are fun and rewarding-Some graphics are nice for a game from 2008 and true to the movies-Action packed, no dead time besides the cut-scenesYou will find many exhaustive lists about the flaws of this game, but to me the main ones are as follow:Flaws:-Clunky controls/aim -Repetitive action-Quick time events were a big thing back then but they are not always a good thing-Besides faster loading screens (that improvement was really needed), the PC port brings little more to the table, thus remaining below expectations

Posted: December 28, 2015
												As a long time Star Wars fanatic, I would reccommend this game to anyone. But, I would not reccommend purchasing The Force Unleashed Ultimate Sith Edition from steam. The graphics are great in high detail and the gameplay is fairly simple. The downfall with this edition from steam is in game, it is almost unplayable due to the background motions and scenes during gameplay are distorted, making it impossible to look up at the sky or space. Random ships or obstacles will be duplicated ten-fold until you can no longer see. With this in mind, this is a great game and I still play it with the background bug, but if you want a clean, less buggy edition, I suggest buying it elsewhere.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												I was hoping this would be like the excellent Jedi Outcast or Jedi Academy games but it is nothing like them. This is a buggy console port with clunky controls, a god awful camera, and unsatisfying combat.The controls are bad with either keyboard/mouse or controller. General movement is much better with a mouse and the camera actually works fine with mouse, but doing combos and especially moving/throwing objects with force grip is easier with a controller (though still clunky). Force grip in this game is kind of important. There are always objects around you to grip and throw at enemies or grip enemies themselves. You also need to grip and manipulate objects to progress which is much harder to do with a mouse. Some moves and combos require you to press two buttons at the same time, one particular move requires three buttons, which are far easier to do on a controller. Also my mouse sensitivity became super high when I gripped light objects which made throwing them accurately next to impossible. So I'd recommend using a controller as it's less bad. However, with a controller that leads to the next problem...The camera. It's the worst. It doesn't work properly with controller. It consistently fails to rotate to where you're facing when you turn. You have to manually do it yourself ALL the time. Having to rotate the camera when you're in the heat of battle is annoying. Actually, having to turn the camera anytime is annoying. I don't know why it works fine with mouse but not with controller but it's irritating as hell. Then you get to the combat and it becomes repetitive and frustrating especially with the poor controls. Turning is more inaccurate with a controller so you'll miss your targets a lot more when using force powers. I said earlier that using force grip is easier with controller but actually focusing on the object you want to grip can be a challenge because you have to be looking right at it which is harder to do with a controller.  In later levels you will constantly face off against a bunch of enemies (at the same time) that can resist your force powers, snipe you, use homing rockets, stunlock you while everyone shoots you, and it just becomes a chore. You can get knocked down with a rocket and it takes like three seconds to get back up for some stupid reason and someone else fires a rocket right as you stand and you're knocked down again. Suddenly you don't feel like such a bad azz sith anymore. There are also quicktime events when fighting stronger enemies and bosses, because timed button presses are always fun and exciting and never get old. You can't save in the game. The game has a save button but it doesn't work. You only have checkpoints and sometimes they're poorly placed and right before a cutscene so if you die you gotta watch it again and again because the cutscenes are unskippable. Sound/voice is also missing from some levels. Even using the recommended fix doesn't solve it. I had to copy the sound files from the disc version of the game (don't ask me how I got it) and transfer it to the game's folder to actually fix it. Great job devs. Oh yea it's also locked at 30fps. You can download files to raise the fps but it causes issues with the force grip movement which is already bad enough. The 3 bonus levels you get with the Ultimate Sith Edition (accessible after you finish the main game and start a new game) aren't anything special. It's more of the same and the storyline is completely absurd for two of the levels. Just to give you an idea, in one level you have a saber battle with Obi Wan when he's a ghost. Yea that's a thing.This is another bad console port with underwhelming gameplay. Save yourself time and frustration and give it a pass.

												This game is one of the biggest letdowns i've ever had the misfortune of buying. Ever since the Force Unleashed came out, I've read the books and have 3 different versions for 3 different systems (nintendo ds, psp-3000, and the Wii). The other three versions I bought were pretty nice (+rep to those devs), but this looks like another rushed and botched pc port; which has become all to prevalent these days.Pros:     - None, all three other force unleashed I've owned are far superior in every way (Wii was the best)Cons:     - Horrible physics engine      - Numerous game crashing bugs (primarily in boss battles, which make them the worst timing)     - Can't move around in the Rogue Shadow      - QTE's don't always specify whether the button needs to be mashed repeatedly or just tapped once     - Enemies are FAR too difficult even on normal     - Save system frequently corrupted after trying to reload it     - 30 FPS frame cap, causes slow rendering and screen tearing (I have a GTX 960 so this shouldn't be a problem)     - Not holding to the actual book in many respects, like on the scrap planet you have to move an entire destroyer        but the "Ultimate" edition assumes that's too unrealistic i guess (even the ds version had the destoyer part lol, so                                     can't  blame it on system limitations)My advice is, get it on any other system, NOT on pc. 3/10

content:
Posted: January 24
 Game could not be fully reviewed for major technical issues: This title is a poorly realized and optimized console porting. The lack of quality in doing said port brought upon PC players a plethora of serious technical problems, such as:===- 30 FPS cap, can be removed by editing files, but doing so will majorly increase chances of game crashes.- No support for resolutions higher than 1920x1080. Can be forced via editing of files but it will likely break the interface and give problems during cutcenes and transitions.- No anti aliasing option, can be forced through driver, but guess, it will improve chances of crashes.- Consistent audio problems in various sections, i.e. audio coming from wrong sources, being disturbed, being in some mono / stereo likewise playback even on a 5.1 system.- Clunky and unresponsive control system makes performing quick actions a real pain.-  And most of all, overall game stability is crippled beyond saving. Crashes happen quite often, if i must speak for my personal experience, the game crashed 8 out of 10 times on player death, resulting in massive frustration and time waste. === AVOID puchasing for PC, Mac or any other computer-based OS.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14
												The Force Unleashed is a polarising game of its time. Duels and force powers feel excellent, this is easily one of the best combat systems that the LucasArt team have ever created. Sadly things become repeditive far too quickly. Most enemies and mini-bosses are recycled to no end and cheapen the gameplay. It's such a shame considering how impressive the artstyle and level design is in each area. It's easy to get bored quickly without anything new or exciting ever happening.The story is tacky and pointless, which is a real dissapointment for its premise and how on point other star wars games have been in this regard. The best way to enjoy this game is through the cheat codes, which allow you to play as almost any character in the entire movie franchise and force unleashed. As a sandbox game for combat and force powers it can give you some hours of fun. But these features don't excuses the plentiful amount of issues the game has. If you're going to buy it, the DLC missions are the best ones by far. They include interesting gameplay mechanics and great what if scenarios. If the game itself was more like the DLC offered we could have really had something special here.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												This is an action game, remiscient of Castlevania. You spend most of your time in combat and in jumping around and manipulating objects. You can learn may different combat moves, most associated with complicated button press sequences. I don't have great hand-eye co-ordination, so I'm not a big fan of action games, but thought I might be able to do this on the easiest setting. I was wrong. What makes things particularly frustrating is that when you save and reload, you do not come back to the same point, but to the beginning of the section. So if you die near the end of a long, difficult section, too bad - you have to do it all over again. Much of the time you die not in combat, but by missing a tricky jump, or being knocked off a ledge. After 8 attempts to cross the chasm halfway through the second mission, I gave up.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												This is a shining example of a console port done wrong. The controls feel awkward with a keyboard and mouse, and are often downright frustrating (Lightning goes through the legs of an ATST but you aren't actually hitting it), boss battles for some reason force you into a different camera perspective and are generally more frustration than fun, and there are way, way, way too many quicktime events. In fact, you can't kill most large enemies without executing one. They aren't difficult, but they aren't especially fun, either. Further, the characters are bland and uninteresting, the main character is a gigantic Mary Sue, and there are many ridiculous aspects (breathing and talking in vacuum, a shapechanging, Force-using droid??????) that make it hard to stomach. The enemy types are not all that varied; in fact, very few require you to change tactics to deal with them. In conclusion, don't waste your money.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												Badly designed junk. For a game as obsessed with looking cool and precise manipulation as this one is, it has to have a better camera and control scheme to work. The controls seem to want the micro-second pixel-by-pixel precision of classic arcade games, but the engine has response lag and the controls are way too sloppy to do things in less than one character height. The auto-target is ... bad is the only word, constantly locking onto things off screen instead of the foe centered in your view. The controls can only be adjusted before you start playing, and the tooltips in game use the default control scheme anyway.The camera is a kludgy mess. It pans around randomly, does not line up for you to be aware of the bottomless pit you're about to step into, and refuses to follow enemies even during boss fights. Boss fights get their own camera angle, altering the basic camera behavior from "behind the character" to "cinematic overview", without adjusting the control scheme for the altered perspective.Fights with large foes will suddenly become quick time events for "cool kills". Unfortunately, you're so busy with the timing that you can't appreciate the cool thing you're supposed to be doing. Thus, these "cool moments" exist in my memory as random button icons flashing on a screen.The story is bland, and spoiled by the "sat on main menu too long" in-game trailer.The characters are shallow and predictable.Bosses randomly, and with no indication of when, become invincible while fighting. This seems to last for three to five seconds, and is most common when the player begins to get a series of successful attacks chained together.TL;DR: Bad. Don't buy it. If you get it for free, don't install it.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												The game runs fine! A lack of settings may make it unfriendly to some older PCs, but most will be fine. I've got a 4 gig Nvidia GPU and a 2.4 GHz cpu and the game is running perfectly fine! I played it frequently on the 360, and the same old gripes still stand. Platforming is awkward as gravity has more attraction to your character than two rabbits in spring. Missing one jump might cost you a solid 15 minutes of gameplay. Terrible force controls also make for some accidental self-damage on occassion. Honestly, the draw of this game is in how much fun it is to be Starkiller. Ripping the environment apart to obain objects to chuck into Jawa's faces will never get old. It's not great, but it is fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												The reason why I don't recommend this game is because this game is from the old era of games where gimmicky combat was all about the player either being lucky or exposing some of the cheaper elements of the game in order to triumph. There are many other choices to make if you support consoles, but unfortunately as a PC user most of the third person action titles with a camera that isn't isometric seems far away from ever happening because of PC being a secondary platform, and because most PC gamers prefer using a keyboard. Games like dragons dogma, dark souls, skyrim, devil may cry, dynasty warriors, toukiden, and eventually God eater and for honor, seem to be the only few types of run around jump action titles that exist with melee combat on the PC genre. However, all of those games have mechanics that will actually support your playstyle, this does not.Some examples of these bad elements include bosses endlessly countering attacks, randomly losing 40 percent of your health from attacks, missing with your sith thunder attack, faulty attack priority, getting locked into enemy combos, slippery slopes while exploring, bad camera angles, cutscenes everywhere, and a throw system that trumps the combat system because of the ai. Granted, games of this time have always been full of gimmicks when choosing the hardest available difficulty, however, in action games, it's almost necessary to do so to enjoy the variations of combos the game has to offer. Though the ai makes a point to walk through half of your combo to the point where it feels like you're playing a dragon ball z game, and it's almost an implicit need to throw and blast everything rather than even try to punch anything. That's a big no no if you're trying to make an action game... it'll end up being like dragon age... where mages and archers destroy the game for any type of melee. Moreso with the latter. It's not a bad game though... the visuals, movement, enemies and effects are still a strong point, the visual fluidity and normal difficulty pacing in the game makes for some of the more fast and curious platform games I've played in the past and adds action from other games that lack the speed or traversal appeal that this game boasts. It's one of the main reasons I've bothered picking it back up despite already playing through most of it on 360. But despite how much I do like the game after I bench some of the more irritating elements, I would never recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a fair and honest challenge. Because let's face it, outside of exploration, the main reason for playing it is to kick butt Jedi style. Not kicking yourself for the game being too cheap to play how you want.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												The Force Unleashed is a miracle of bad game design. Poor explanation of controls? Check. A tutorial (for throwing stuff with the Force, at least) that comes after the prologue level? Check. Bosses- and regular enemies- that can block attacks, knock you down, use attacks that you can't avoid or block, and make you forget all those neat combos in favor of button-mashing? Check. Seriously, one of the later levels gives you two or three purge troopers (who can knock you down), an AT-ST (which can also knock you down) and an assortment of stormtroopers (who can't knock you down but will constantly interrupt you by shooting you). Any difficulty above Apprentice, on which I still got killed by the aforementioned spam, is unthinkably nightmarish during or after the second boss. Not that the second boss is ever anything but.There are also insultingly pointless quick-time events. You're given a surprisingly long window for each button press, and if by some perverse miracle you press the wrong button... either you can immediately initiate the QTE again or, if it's in a boss fight, you just get to press the right button. I failed to press X at a moment when doing so would prevent Starkiller from being fatally beaten in a saber lock... and I was just asked to do it again as the saber lock continued. Just let me kill the boss and watch the finisher or something. Sheesh.The camera is rather irritating to control, though in my experience that's nothing new. Some people have complained about the fact that most of the boss fights have  a fixed camera, and while I understand that it's annoying, I'm actually somewhat glad that for once I don't have to bother with rotating the camera.  You can lock on to enemies, though, so that's a plus.The game also only has three tilesets. We see Kashyyk in the prologue and in the story proper, we go to Felucia (how I hate Felucia) twice, and two different planets have the junkyard tileset. There might be more instances of this, though. I haven't finished the game.To try to tie together the disparate complaints in this review, let me tell you about my favorite area in the game: a certain open area on Felucia. It's a clearing with some islands of foliage and weird tentacles that react violently when you shock them (this is probably meant to help you clear out enemies, but it didn't seem too helpful to me), loads of obnoxious Felucian warriors, some large, explosive fruits surrounding the clearing, and not one, not two, but THREE Rancors.Quick rundown of Felucians: they have bone swords with forcefields that can block your attacks, they have forcefield shields that can block your attacks, they have shamans that can render them invincible, and they have another variant that shoot lasers at you from a staff. There are, as I mentioned, loads of them in this particular stretch of jungle, and they make it nearly impossible to take the necessary time to grab and throw fruits at the Rancors. They also seem to spawn continuously, though I could be wrong about that. Note this: the rushed, out-of-touch or downright sadistic people who made this game give the player an efficient means of dealing with the dangerous enemies in an area and then make that means essentially useless. I had to downgrade from Sith Lord (regular) difficulty to Apprentice (easy) to get through that area. At the point in the game I'm at the player is frequently pit against AT-STs, which are essentially Rancors that can consistently hit from a distance, and either not given any obvious throwables (not that they help against an AT-ST in firing range) or mobbed with stormtroopers.This is all very tragic, really, because TFU had the potential to be a good game. There are points in the game where I've felt like the overpowered Sith I'm supposed to be, but these are few and far between when all sorts of enemies can block my lightsaber, force push or lightning and then repeatedly knock me over.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												If you like action games with fancy wrapping and some plain fast action, maybe it's the Star Wars game for you. Despite its good looks and high initial potential and a rather good story, I concluded that it is not for me.Maybe I had too high expectations as a console fan friend recommended this one to me as one of the best Star Wars games around and Lucasfilm games always had an excellent pedigree in my book. I started that universe in a cockpit of an X-Wing ages ago and shot all the way through Tie Fighter and X-Wing Alliance. They were extremely challenging, more often than never, but they also were games of reason and consequence, higly addictive. Then I had some deep RPG experience with the amazing KOTOR games. I also had some strategy fun with Empire at War, not to mention the super amazing Republic Commando that is one of its bests in its category even since in my opinion.The closest to The Force Unleashed is Jedi Knight 2 and Academy that had much more depth, better controls on PC and just better overall game dynamics (yes I'm talking about a decade-old game). Damn, even LEGO Star Wars was bigger fun. Er, well, actually, that was fun. It is the fun factor where this game fails to deliver. There are issues with controls and camera movement that makes defeating simple obstacles and fights plain annoying at places. Not to mention certain long, annoying boss battles and the feel of repetition. On the long run, these together decreased the fun to the point where I just lost the inspiration to play it again after finishing the story. It could be much more but at the end of the day I can consider this one to be a moderately annoying, flat action game. With an ample of unused potential.The other thing that I did not like is just because of a little phylosophy. I am a demoscene musician specialised on ancient 8-bit machines like the C64 and I'm lucky to work with coders and graphicians who can pack an insane amount of content into tiny spaces: 64kilobyte or even 4KB (that is about the size of some text on a sheet of paper), running real-time on average machines pumping out 50+FPS. This is one of my fav 64KB PC demos, released in 2006 by demo group Conspiracy:


YouTube™ Video: conspiracy  -  Chaos Theory [HD] 

			Views: 76,575		

			C O N S P I R A C Y presents C H A O S T H E O R Y at ASSEMBLY 2006 /// Brought to you by: BoyC - main code Gargaj - synth code, music Zoom - visuals /// About the intro: Apparently we finished...		

Everything here, the visuals and music are generated real-time by 64 kilobyte of program data. That means the size of  text of 16 sheets of paper, one-side printed.That means, the great majority of the data and processing that you have in a game could be much much more efficient - but it's not efficiency that it is all about these days. If it was, your downloads would be much smaller and even the slowest machines could pump out 30FPS. The solution for better gaming experience was not buying faster and bigger computers but write more efficient program codes.Still, there are game developers who create artistically coded engines that are efficient. For example I really admire Runic Games, Bethesda or Valve for their game engines as they have awesome content / performance ratio. As for the measure, Skyrim with all the extensions installed, opens a 20+ square miles of gaming world and can give you 200+ hours of entertainment with as much as 9GB of data. Just Cause 2 creates 200 square miles of game space that you can roam and the game doesn't lose its sparkle after many hours. It uses less than 5GB space on your HDD.So, 25GB of data for a game that can be completed in less than 10 hours (and at least 2 hours of them are annoying boss battles) and completely loses the momentum afterwards? Gimme a f'n break...

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												I just rage quit this game. Not because its hard or I can't beat it. It's because now, no matter what i do, half the sound effects wont play. Surrounded by the empire, fighting off the silent blasters and inaudible tones of battle. All that is heard is the soft battle music and the quiet footsteps of my enemies. The first few levels were fan-♥♥♥♥ing-tastic but suddenly, without warning, this level can't be heard. There were numerous glitches and overall ♥♥♥♥-ups throughout the game none quiet as frustrating as a silent empire. I checked my settings. I restarted. I fought for rebellion and god dammit, they let me down. Do i like this game? YESDo I reccomend you play it on PC? NOI play this game a few years ago on the Wii of all machines. It played great but i think some levels varied quite a bit. I do know that a lot of the mechanics were tossed away from the Wii version. As is, the game feels like it's missing a lot. I leave it now as I did when first played it: disappointed. All though the idea of the Force being unlimmited is trying to beconveyed in the game, it doesn't deliver. Starkiller is great and cool but they didn't do him justice in this game. I would love to see this remade.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												I remember playing this back when it was released originally and i don't think i enjoyed it much back then either. While the story is somewhat entertaining and the graphics hold up very nice even to this day or finally i'd say, now that we have the hardware to actually run it w/o problem haha. Make sure to get a fps unlocked .exe though or your eyes will start to bleed.Now to the bad ... the game is very hard and unforgiving ... now .. not hard in a "oh you newb you just don't know how to play  lolol" , no , not like that, but in a "oh you didn't time that jump perfectly" or "oh no you actually can't jump here now you die falling down the abyss and then we let you restart from before the last boss battle ... again" kinda way. Also it has some weird difficulty spikes, which really make you wanna (or do make you do lol) ragequit sometimes. Actually, i got so frustrated about the stupid ways you can die in this game. Last time i died,  i was stuck and stun locked in an explosion and little by little all my life went away and i died .... and had to redo the  whole area again ...To sum it up :Combat is a chore.Boss fights are either♥♥♥♥♥♥easy (if you know which attack to spam lol) orBoss fights are impossibly hard (if you don't know which attack move or force etc to spam).Movement (and by that i mean jumping) is a PITA.Normal combat (i.e. not vs bosses) is either easy as pie or bugged as hell ,like not doing damage against something, without any indication of why ... and i am not talking enemies that can block blade attacks or are "immun" to the force, but enemies that are just not taking damage, period.Frustrating progression. It's just one big grind to reach the next cutscene (do yourself a favor and just watch them with a bik player lol).Feels like work ...do NOT recommend ...PS : played with a xbox controller

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												The Force Unleashed is a third-person hack-and-slash game that is about going from the start of the level to the end.You can upgrade your Force powers and get more abilites as you slay more and more enemies, but most of the time, the extra abilities and combos are meaningless. You can just run around pressing the same attack button over and over to kill most enemies. Press the Force Lighting button every so often for a ranged attack, and then use your Force abilities to clear the way to move on in the level.This game is neither deep, nor is it particularly fun. You would really only play it because you want to see story that essentially considered cannon in the Star Wars universe.5/10 "Mediocre"

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												So I bought this game because it was one of the few SW games I hadn't played yet. Heard some good things about it, and it looked decently fun. After all, to me it was Star Wars and that's all I really cared about. Oh boy if only I'd known what I was getting myself intoRight off the bat the first thing I bump into is a bug with the audio. Throughout the game the sounds are glitched and sometimes they don't play. I can get past this, save for the fact that there's no quality to the rest of the game. This has hands down one of the worst combat systems I've played in any other action game. Nevermind the button mashing, as I didn't expect something of the quality of DMC3 with this game. I just wanted a game that was fun to playBut it's not. The gameplay is terrible. The combat is slow and clunky, you get knocked down every single time and have to wait until your character clunkily regains his balance, all the meanwhile he can keep receiving damage. The force powers are underwhelming and they're awkward to use due to the terrible nature of the camera and the controls. The platforming is terrible due to how badly designed the movement system is as there is no proper collision detection and you just slide off round invisible surfaces as if this were a PS1 game. All bosses are gimmicky and a pain to fight. Since you fight them in arena-shaped areas, the camera view completely changes and now it sits far away from you. Instead of following your character so that you know how you're oriented and can properly move around, the game instead pans out and you have to clumsily move around completely disoriented. The targetting system for using your powers on bosses is completely useless and you have a hard time actually locking onto your target. The areas are filled with hazards that you need to constantly move around or else you're thrown around like a ragdoll losing huge chunks of health at every turn. Combine this with the terrible combat system and the clunky movement and you've got a recipe to disasterThe levels all have been a bore so far due to how you can abuse your force powers to destroy everything instantly, or whenever you're faced with overwhelming odds you can always just find a way to cheese fights because the AI is braindead. On top of that the game looks ugly and bland, and you can't even appreciate the cutscenes due to the aforementioned audio problemsOverall I wouldn't recommend this game at all. Luckily I got it during the holiday sale, but even then I still regret ever purchasing it

content:

												Great game overall. Ive enjoyed this game on Ps3 and now on Pc. Ultimate Sith edition gives you every DLC costumes and levels. Now you can unleash your force in 3 new DLC levels as Lord Starkiller, Emperors new right hand man. The game suffers from the same problems as console version. Nothing is fixed. So if you encounter some framerate issues, no, your computer is not to blame or some irritating battle clitches, its not your skills, its the game. If you can get past these issues youll have an enjoyable gametime. Not so storywise but it is awesome to throw your enemies all over the place with you Force. Play this game on easy and you can experience what it means to be a true Force badass or use harder difficulty to punish yourself. This game gets solid 8/10 from me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2010
												For any Star wars gamer, this game is an exciting experience. You begin as Darth Vader himself! A fantastic nod to the fan community, and many people who think Vader is badass, and march around in home made costumes depecting the Sith Lord to stunnning quality. Wait no longer, you will be tossing around troopers and Wookies at the drop of a hat, and later doing massive damage with force powers like lightning, and combinations of various powers which reach deadly levels, as Starkiller. Discover an epic plot masterminded by Vader himself, and help him achieve his goals...or do you have goals of your own? Customize your own lightsaber with various crystal colors, and even special crystals that boost force powers or saber damage. Fight a variety of enemies and take advantage of your environment in strategic and out-of-the-box ways. Every level plays differently each time with a sweet AI that provides a good deal of variety and unexpected turns.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												Its an okay hack and slash thats story has a fairly good ending that is cute but then again I think theres atleast two endings.The big problems are the frustrating enemy design that stun locks you sometimes to the point you lose half your health without having control of your character. This is why you should just play it on normal, alot less frustrating that way. Also the game is broken. Somewhere along the line things have gotten very broken. I think modern OS and drivers have made the game really broken. Not like "wont run" broken but more like sound dousn't work right, physics occasionally goes mad and other strange happenings. Its funny, I think it made the game marginally more fun because I like that sort of thing but I doubt most others will.Other issues are really just marginal. The games an enjoyable and decently good hack and slash game that dousn't feel just like another God Of War game and has a heavy impetus on physics. I ♥♥♥♥ing love physics in games, especially Euphoria.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Pros:- Story is interesting- Music score lives up to Star Wars- Using force powers is really cool- Graphics looks OKCons- Combat is very basic with very little combo options- Responce time is extremely laggy, resulting in deaths due to delayed responce- Many glitches and bugs, game was released flat out unfinished and was obviously not polished since release- Locked at 30 fps (there is an easy fix to get it to 60fps or higher but that brings in more glitches and bugs, for example setting the game at 60fps will cause you to force lift objects upwards causing you to have to revert back to 30fps in order to progress, plus locked fps on a PC game is an unforgivable sin no matter what)- Considering this is the next gen verion of the game its questionable that the PS2/Wii versions have more content, cuts clearly have been made (and I'm not talking about the extra DLC missions)- Loading screens are freakishly long even on an SSD4/10 overall, can only recommend this to Star Wars fans who love to collect games for the sake of collecting them or if they feel the need to invest in story, anyone stay away, there are far better hack and slash games)

content:
Posted: May 5, 2013
												Great game overall. Ive enjoyed this game on Ps3 and now on Pc. Ultimate Sith edition gives you every DLC costumes and levels. Now you can unleash your force in 3 new DLC levels as Lord Starkiller, Emperors new right hand man. The game suffers from the same problems as console version. Nothing is fixed. So if you encounter some framerate issues, no, your computer is not to blame or some irritating battle clitches, its not your skills, its the game. If you can get past these issues youll have an enjoyable gametime. Not so storywise but it is awesome to throw your enemies all over the place with you Force. Play this game on easy and you can experience what it means to be a true Force badass or use harder difficulty to punish yourself. This game gets solid 8/10 from me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												Jetzt geht es in die nächste Runde.Endlich kann man mal im Star Wars Spiele Universum die dunkle Seite der Macht spiele.Man schlüpft in die Rolle des Galen Marek, dem unbekannten und sehr mächtigen Schüler des Darth Vader.Ihr sollt für Darth Vader die Jedi, töten die die Order 66 überlebt haben.Auf dem Weg zu den Jedis muss man paar Rätsel lösen und immer wieder Druiden, Sturmtruppen oder Rebellentruppen umbringen.Die Steuerrung ist ungefähr so wie bei Assassin Creed. Zum Glück hat man dieses mal die besten Machttricks sofort in naher reichweite(das ständige F-Tasten drücken wie bei Jedi Knight gibt es nicht mehr). Zwischen den Leveln kann man in eine Art Trainingsraum seinen Kampfstil verbessern, und somit immer mehr und mächtige Macht Combos erlernen.Die Endgegner werden zuerst ganz normal im Nahkampf angegriffen.Wenn Galen den Gegner den Gnadenstoss geben will sehen wir immer eine Art Video bei den wir dann nur noch 3-4 Tasten drücken müssen.Im Add ons welches dabei ist, kann man durch das durchspielen die Endenvon Episode 4-6 verändern. So gewinnt vielleicht doch mal das Imperium.Genre: ActionEntwickler: LucasArts , Aspyr Studios Publisher: LucasArts Bewertung:8/10 ActionWir wünsche euch viel Spas beim zocken.Möge die Macht mit euch sein.Euer Pixelhead Team

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I liked playing this game, although there are upsides and downsides:+ the story was pretty good and  I was kind of curious what would happen next+ special lightsaber parts, but:- changing the Lightsaber Color actually only changes its appearance+ Style of the fighting system, but:- technique of the fighting system (Autoaim is sometimes malicious)-  Really bad recovery, if you accidentially get hit by a missile while enemies surround you you might actually diebecause you take damage even while lying on the ground and he takes ages to get up again- Button mashing suffices most of the time to kill most enemies, including some bosses+ Interesting Bossfights, but: - more or less trial and error, which seemed unfair sometimes so I had some difficulties against some and died 4 or 5 times until I got their pattern  Darth Maul, Fight against Vader where he stands in the middle and throws rubbish at you, same with the Imperator, and I also experienced some difficulty against the girl with the double nunchuck sabers (forgot her name, sorry)  , some of the other bosses were too easy where you can just spam one Combo to kill them+ the graphics were good (considering its age)+ original sound- bad trashmob AI- some minor bugs, like music not playing, standing on top of platforms where you shouldn't be able to get to, AT-ST's where you are able to stand on their feet and do infinite combos in mid-air- only 5h to play through on medium difficultyI still liked playing it! Would I recommend it? If you like Star Wars, definitely, even if you would only play it on easyto experience the story. But if you are looking for a technically flawless game with dozens of hours of gameplay and an insane fighting system, this game might actually disappoint you.I heard SW:TFU2 is better. Gonna play it now :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												It should be known that I played this game vigorously on Xbox 360, so in terms of storyline, cannon, and other non-machine related topics, I have at least 300 hours of experience in this title.Star Wars The Force Unleashed, is possibly one of the most entertaining Star Wars games I've ever had the pleasure of playing! It is not a game fitting for the avid lightsaber fight loving Jedi/Sith personality, as this game's name; 'the force unleashed', is quite literal. You get 'way' more options in this game in terms of using the force, than you do with lightsaber combat...Frankly, lightsaber combat in this game is more of a 'last resort' deal, or if the enemies are so weak/few that it honestly would take longer to beat them with the force.In terms of gameplay, however, the game is extremely entertaining, and thanks to the game's commendable difficulty curve, from Apprentice to Sith Master(last one has to be unlocked), the game sports an absolute TON of replayability, from alternative endings, to new lightsaber colors, to new unlockable costumes and entirely new characters, the game is one of those gems which has you coming back for more!In terms of lore, the Force Unleashed opens a new, previously unexplained gap between two movies, I believe its number II and III(not the newer videos). It tells the story of a rogue Sith apprentice to Darth Vader, codenamed simply as Starkiller, who works under the strict and vicicous tutelage of the Dark Lord himself, effectively hunting down exiled Jedi. However, as the story presses on, the young Sith apprentice begins, for varying reasons, to feel less secure in his apprenticeship to Lord Vader, and his life takes a complete U-turn when he meets his new ship pilot, Juno.The story is believable, as it fills in a lore gap to explain what happened in the space between movie II and III.Graphics wise, this game is on par with modern video games, and takes quite a bit of effort on your GPUs part to keep up the Framerate counter, however, it can easily be resolved by lowering the resolution, and unchecking the High detail box prior to starting the game, which pretty much eliminates framerate lag(Unless your computer is a potato with copper wires in it)Do I think this game, and its sequel, are worth adding to your Star Wars game collection? Without a doubt. This game's shere popularity, and Lore accuracy, makes it a 'must play' in order to get insight into a truly intense and entertaining part of the untold-in-the-movies story!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												I want to like this game. It has so much potential. And sometimes when you're playing it there are moments that are really, really fun. When you're jumping from Stromtrooper to Stormtrooper, your lightsaber combos are flowing beautifully, you're force throws are on point, you feel really powerful. The close you can ever feel to being a real Jedi.But unfortunately those moments are too far between. What could be epic gameplay is, more often than not, hampered by shotty targeting, bad camera angles, weird boss fights that block everything so you can't really use any good combos or slick moves, annoying sequences where you will get hit by an attack that knocks you down, and it takes your character so long to stand back up that you're hit by another one immediately, and this repeats until you die while you scream at your monitor. Seriously for being a badass Jedi, this guy stands up at a speed that would make my grandpa laugh. For every time you epicly force grab something and throw it at an enemy, there are three times where you force grab something and for some reason throw it in a completely random direction. Or when you try and force lightning someone, and for some reason you force lightning the air right beside them while they stand there and look at you like you're crazy.The game is difficult. But not in a fun way. I like a game that is a challenge. If I make a mistake, punish me (didn't realize how dirty that sounded until I said it out loud). But this game isn't difficult in that way. It's difficult in a lot of the enemies have slow, repetitive unblockable attacks that knock you down over and over and over again. It's difficult where the boss just randomly becomes invincible/blocks everything you have so you just have to wait for him to let you start attacking again. Really any lightsaber duel feels less like a duel and more like you using force lightning and just running away because that's significantly more effective than actually using your lightsaber due to the enemy blocking all your attacks and all of his attacks being unblockable. It has entirely too many jumping puzzles for a game with a bad camera and an erratic, unreliable double jump.Little things like that that should have never made it through any kind of QA testing.The DNA of a great game is there. But it needed another 6 months of polishing before release, at least. This is on the top of my "games that didn't live up to their immense potential" list.And that's not even counting how bad of a PC port this is. Straight port. 30fps. No extra graphic enhancements. Nothing to take advantage of being on a PC. Just seems lazy.I played the game all the way through because of those brief moments of fun. But I would say I only really enjoyed myself about %30 of the time, the other %70 I was just more annoyed and frustrated than anything else.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												When I first played this on the 360 I really had a lot of fun. I never understood the negative reviews and arbitrary hate this game recieved. That said, the PC, specifically the STEAM version has some pretty negative points that you may overlook, but I find pretty disheartening.First off, 2 levels lose their audio partially. All you can hear is your lightasber, powers, sometimes music and stormtrooper screams as you cut them donwn. The issue is within the files downloaded from the Steam server, as retail disc versions do not have this issue. It's been 6 years since release and no official fix has been presented. You have to replace the faulty files yourself from whichever source you can get.Aside from that, and I'm sure other reviews cover this, there's the issue with the visuals. The extent of graphics customization is limited to resolution and a check box for high detail, that's it. If you want to enjoy the gameplay, an Xbox 360 controller is a must-have. Mouse and keyboard is very clunky and I am not aware if there is any other third party gamepad support.As for the core game, it is fairly entertaining and challenging at parts. It does suffer from invincibility frames, enemies pulling off attacks that you cannot block and sometimes not even evade.All in all, it is playable and a very decent game, but the technical issues are not warranted for something you paid for.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Do NOT buy this game. It may have a half decent story and all, but the gameplay is enough to drive anyone insane. Boss battles require you to do repetitive cheap tactics rather than enjoy an awesome lightsaber battle, which was always a highlight in the films. Even the cheap tactic of force grip and throwing someone to damage/kill them is still not very functional due to the HORRIBLE targetting mechanics. You will end up not being able to grab anyone because you never get to target your enemy even when they're literally 4 feet from you. NOTHING about the gameplay is fluid. Skill is absolutely not a factor.Do you want to be a Jedi or Sith? Unfortunately you have only a one time choice and it's at the end of the game. It's not even obvious that there is a choice. Look it up and you'll see what I mean, no spoilers here.Want to force throw 3 large items at once? You got it!.. Want to hit the only enemy around with 3 said objects? NOPE! Aiming things you throw is almost random and unfortunately you have to do it to pick down the bosses so you can actually have a lightsaber fight when they're at about 5% health.The checkpoint system is terrible, the UI is bad, the menu/options screen is the worst I've ever seen.Want to skip a cutscene? Sure! Press all buttons.. nothing. Press enter though and you'll just open the menu to save your game!.. Handy feature that is.. Saving mid cutscene.I could go on for hours.. I hate this game, I play it for the story because I like Star Wars... Going in I wanted to be a Jedi, now I'm definitely turned to the dark side.Oh, yeah.. and the game is capped at 30 fps and 5.1 sound so enjoy the choppy gameplay and very poor audio unless you have a 5.1 speaker setup in your house.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												I tried really hard to enjoy this game, I really did. I'm a fan of Star Wars, and I enjoy action games that require skill beyond mashing one button the entire game so I thought this would be a great fit. To make this short, this game was a let down. Enemies can stun lock you by giving you a stern look, while multiple slashes with hot plasma and force attacks that could move a battleship do nothing to any foe stronger than the basic trooper. Dodgy keyboard controls add to the poor design choices, if you do play this game then a controller is highly suggested. What finally did it in for me was the final battle. Without giving anything away, I was 1-shot by the final boss when he stuck me between himself and a corner. To sum it up: Only get this game in a bundle or on sale, and don't get your hopes up too high.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Frustrating and stiff controls*, repetitive combat, one-dimensional characters, annoying enemies, unnecessary quick time events, artificially long boss fights. And knockback, don't even get me started on knockback. Very little time spent in between levels; you grind your way through a linear level, kill the boss, watch a brief cutscene and are immediately dropped into the next mission. Story is mediocre, visuals are pretty good by 2009 standards, but the textures can be pretty ugly at times. Almost too much of a reliance on mattes makes anything not in your immediate vicinity look flat and motionless. One of the better looking Star Wars games out there, though, but it's also one of the only recent ones.If you're a really big Star Wars fan, grab it during the summer sale. Otherwise, stick with better hack-n-slash games like God of War or Devil May Cry.*Note: I played with an Xbox 360 controller; however the controls were still frustrating and a horrible targeting system makes force grip a chore to use.

												Possibly one of the most frustrating games ever made. It is frustrating because you want to play it and actually enjoy playing it despite the issue with targetting; but when you get to the boss fights, it is almost unplayable in any enjoyable sense. Whoever thought of turning the boss fights into some sort of Mortal Kombat type side-view camera needs to be flogged, publicly. You have to keep track of where Starkiller is facing, there are tons of things he could target--and does--the only thing you want to target is the boss. Sure you can target lock, but get knocked down or otherwise disengaged and bam, you're off targetting something on a wall. The whole side-view cinematic camera nonsense was probably dreamed up by some space cadet muppet who is not a gamer. It honestly spoils the game. If I wanted Mortal Kombat, I'd buy Mortal Kombat because they do Mortal Kombat style fights scenes properly!

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												The graphics are awesome, the physics are great but this game fails in a crucial aspect -- the gameplay. It's monotonous, linear and after a while a tedious chore. The bossfights are outright idiotic -- suddenly, you no longer play a 3d person shooter but an isometric hack&slash with quick-time events to finish the boss. If you customized your key controls, the game still instructs you to press the default keys which is frustratingly confusing. And, as it goes with quick-time events, you get to watch a scripted sequence with occasional keypress which steals the rewarding feel of defeating the opponent all by yourself. The story is nice but all characters have dead eyes so there's less life in them than in Jedi Outcast or Jedi Academy. Also, Vader's got different voice actor.I wanted badly the negative reviews not to be true but they are. Buy/stick to Jedi Academy instead, it's a far better game at making you feel like a jedi.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												I remembered playing the demo of this game on the Xbox 360 years ago and having a favorable experience.  Game is on sale so why not, bad idea.  This is NOT that game.  It is not a bad game per say if you have never played another action game and you started playing video games in 1998 or so...  But by today's standards it is awful.  The first thing you will notice after you get to say the third or fourth level is that the camera gets caught behind things.  Then the play control, it is out of this world awful.  You do a button combination and it delays for a second.  Your character will take a while to set up his moves, but thankfully the computer AI is super fast.  Trying to levitate a rock to throw at a character, well you better have at least a second before.... too late the computer can instantly hurl rocks, lasers, or rockets.  Which leads me to ... blocking.  You really can only block when you know way in advance you want to do it, other than that it is pointless.  But when you are getting pumelled don't worry the game developers thought enough to allow you to keep getting attacked till you do a very slow get back up.This game is crap on the play control and graphics and this is 2015.  There are ton of other action games that put this game to shame.  One of the few games I will probably finish because the story is a little intriguing but the gameplay is godawful.

												I generally do not post reviews. I'm lazy that way.But this game... this game got me out of me shell and flaming like a devil baboon. It has clunky controls, broken/repetitive boss fights and an useless Save Game feature - why useless? Because you can't save. Nor can you load anything.After playing through the same missions three times because the game wouldn't autosave, I give up. I'm sorry for ever having bought, wished for and installed this shameful excuse for a game.I've been wanting to play this game since it came out. And it's not  even worth the bandwidth it used to download itself onto my machine. I hope you're happy, Aspyr & Lucas Arts. I can get budget cuts. I can get choppy graphics and subpar voice acting. What I can never accept is a publisher/developer delivering less than an MVP (minimum viable product). You could've modified Jedi Academy to fit the new story, made some adjustments to the gameplay and that would've been awesome. And cheaper for both of us.But you didn't. You did not...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												I'm not a huge fan of the yes/no system. Can this game be fun? Yes. Will it be frustrating? YES. Would you be missing out if you never played it? Probably not.There's something enjoyable about this game and getting to use force powers in an excessive way. I enjoyed it on my Wii and I'm enjoying it now.However, this game is not a very well made game. Level design is not good, enemies are either too easy or stunlock you until you die, checkpoints are not close enough together and you will ALWAYS be fighting the camera. I probably wouldn't play this without a USB gamepad. The controls are not tight at all and it's hard to get your character to do what you want him to do. You will fall off of edges a lot because the platforming is terrible. There are QTEs at the end of boss fights.Personally, this game feels like it has a spectacle-fighter sort of vibe. Except, it lacks almost everything that makes a spectacle fighter good. If done correctly, this game could have been amazing. The graphics are pretty good (aside from the cutscenes). But honestly, nothing dates this game more than its terrible control and camera issues.Overall, I think the game is fun, despite its shortcomings. I would probably only get this game at a heavily discounted price though. This is a bargin-bin game (which is where I bought my Wii version). It is good fun for that kind of game. But I find myself setting the game down at least once every 30 minutes because of how frustrating it can be. Unlike something like Dark Souls, this game controls so sloppily that you do not blame yourself, you blame this poorly made game.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												Honestly, I'd recommend sticking to the novelization instead. I quite enjoyed the book, and eventually gave the game a try. It's been kind of a mess; I spent as much of the story as I could get through not understanding what in the heck was actually going on, the actual gameplay's a generic hack-and-slash, and the sheer number of graphical and gameplay glitches made it borderline unplayable, on a powerful Origin PC that was actually able to run Arkham Knight at launch. Pop-in is atrocious and constant, cutscenes flicker oddly, and the 30FPS limit still comes with occasional slowdown. All of this would be tolerable if there was enough game to really keep you hooked, but in my case, there isn't. In my time with the game, it randomly crashed mid-level without warning and without saving very, very often. It's rather generic. Save yourself the trouble; if you want the story, get the book, and if you want to play as Galen Marek, get SoulCalibur IV or LEGO Star Wars III, really.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												Combat system has one hell of a learning curve. This isn't some button masher where you can just swing your lightsaber to victory. You need to think strategically about each move you make. Enemies can take a nasty chunk of you health away if you aren't playing correctly, and it's just a struggle until you actually start using the good force which aren't all that intuitive nor are they always reliable. Force push controls sometimes fly objects off in directions you didn't want, and the camera angles are just bad, especially boss fights. I would say that in this game, there wasn't a single boss fight I enjoyed. Every one of them was just annoying. As enemies can begin to block your attacks mid combo but you can't do the same to them....so if they hit you once they may as hit you 2-4 more times for a massive lost in health due to the ragdoll mechanics. I found myself stunned in ragdoll mode many many times due to be hit by an offscreen projectile...remember those camera angles I mentioned earlier?Story: 8/10Combat: 3/10 (camera angles, ragdoll physics, overpowered AI, and annoying stuns, just kills the combat system)I'd rate this game 4/10

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												I got some hours of fun out of this game. But this game have an insame amount of problems and there is so much frustrating nonsense in this game.The game is locked to 30 fps on pc. This can be unlocked which i did and it worked fine outside of some glitchy quicktime events. This still sucks though. The port has also screwed up some quicktime events royally and doing some of them with mouse and keyboard is insanely frustrating. The story is crap and the character interaction is boring at the best of times. The environments aren't all that varied and they are reused which kind of sucks.But the focus of this game is the combat and the combat can be fun at times. It is braindead but it can still be fun. But there are a bunch of problems which at times makes the combat extremely frustrating. The targeting sucks, locked camera angle sucks, quicktime event sucks, hits not registering sucks, hit detection sucks,invisible walls sucks and etc etc. In general stuff just didn't work as i expected them to and it just becomes extremely frustrating whenever something is actually challenging. People who like the license can probably get some fun out of this game and it is a nice touch that you get a bunch of different familiar skins to play with. But i would not recommend this game for anyone else.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												If this game would have been made today, it would be a great game. The fighting is fresh and cool and you have plenty of powers and abilities and combos to keep the gameplay nice and progressive. The problem with this game lies in the details.  There are alot of quicktime event, and they suck. The animations are great sure but quicktime events is a bad thing in itself and these are often hard to start because you are already spamming the buttons when it starts so you almost always fail the first time you try. Some missions are just painful, the worst was the mission where you have to bring a Star destroyer with the force but 6-7 tie fighter keep shooting at you, you then have to destroy them and continue destroying the ship(which takes a while) but the mission is very badly made and very very hard, way too hard in fact since more than half the time I tried to pick the ties with the force(you can only use the force to destroy them) it dosent work and they just pass through your grip and ♥♥♥♥ you up. Its a great game, but if you are easily frustrated like me, dont buy it unless its very very cheap and you dont mind getting stuck somewhere 4 hours while almost falling to the Dark side in real life.Tl;Dr: This game is so frustrating that I almost fell to the dark side playing it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												I tried really hard to enjoy this game, I really did. I'm a fan of Star Wars, and I enjoy action games that require skill beyond mashing one button the entire game so I thought this would be a great fit. To make this short, this game was a let down. Enemies can stun lock you by giving you a stern look, while multiple slashes with hot plasma and force attacks that could move a battleship do nothing to any foe stronger than the basic trooper. Dodgy keyboard controls add to the poor design choices, if you do play this game then a controller is highly suggested. What finally did it in for me was the final battle. Without giving anything away, I was 1-shot by the final boss when he stuck me between himself and a corner. To sum it up: Only get this game in a bundle or on sale, and don't get your hopes up too high.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Do NOT buy this game. It may have a half decent story and all, but the gameplay is enough to drive anyone insane. Boss battles require you to do repetitive cheap tactics rather than enjoy an awesome lightsaber battle, which was always a highlight in the films. Even the cheap tactic of force grip and throwing someone to damage/kill them is still not very functional due to the HORRIBLE targetting mechanics. You will end up not being able to grab anyone because you never get to target your enemy even when they're literally 4 feet from you. NOTHING about the gameplay is fluid. Skill is absolutely not a factor.Do you want to be a Jedi or Sith? Unfortunately you have only a one time choice and it's at the end of the game. It's not even obvious that there is a choice. Look it up and you'll see what I mean, no spoilers here.Want to force throw 3 large items at once? You got it!.. Want to hit the only enemy around with 3 said objects? NOPE! Aiming things you throw is almost random and unfortunately you have to do it to pick down the bosses so you can actually have a lightsaber fight when they're at about 5% health.The checkpoint system is terrible, the UI is bad, the menu/options screen is the worst I've ever seen.Want to skip a cutscene? Sure! Press all buttons.. nothing. Press enter though and you'll just open the menu to save your game!.. Handy feature that is.. Saving mid cutscene.I could go on for hours.. I hate this game, I play it for the story because I like Star Wars... Going in I wanted to be a Jedi, now I'm definitely turned to the dark side.Oh, yeah.. and the game is capped at 30 fps and 5.1 sound so enjoy the choppy gameplay and very poor audio unless you have a 5.1 speaker setup in your house.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												I am SO sorry I wasted money on this game.  It is the worst console port I have ever experienced.  First of all, play with a mouse and keyboard is fairly awful in many main battle scenes.  It asks you to press some random buttons at certain moments that not only ruin the experience but are very difficult to do without a game controller.  But the main killer are the boss battles that are played with a fixed camera position.  I thought the "side-scrolling" sections of the Arkham games were bad....this is a nightmare!  Now all 360 degrees of movement rely on the keyboard (mouse is useless for direction here) and while you are struggling to aim your attacks in the right direction, you are getting your butt kicked at the same time.  After the third one of these, I uninstalled the game.Oh and btw-- this game takes up an impossible 29 gigs of hard drive space!!!  That alone should have been a red flag that this was poorly ported.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Possibly one of the most frustrating games ever made. It is frustrating because you want to play it and actually enjoy playing it despite the issue with targetting; but when you get to the boss fights, it is almost unplayable in any enjoyable sense. Whoever thought of turning the boss fights into some sort of Mortal Kombat type side-view camera needs to be flogged, publicly. You have to keep track of where Starkiller is facing, there are tons of things he could target--and does--the only thing you want to target is the boss. Sure you can target lock, but get knocked down or otherwise disengaged and bam, you're off targetting something on a wall. The whole side-view cinematic camera nonsense was probably dreamed up by some space cadet muppet who is not a gamer. It honestly spoils the game. If I wanted Mortal Kombat, I'd buy Mortal Kombat because they do Mortal Kombat style fights scenes properly!

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												I got some hours of fun out of this game. But this game have an insame amount of problems and there is so much frustrating nonsense in this game.The game is locked to 30 fps on pc. This can be unlocked which i did and it worked fine outside of some glitchy quicktime events. This still sucks though. The port has also screwed up some quicktime events royally and doing some of them with mouse and keyboard is insanely frustrating. The story is crap and the character interaction is boring at the best of times. The environments aren't all that varied and they are reused which kind of sucks.But the focus of this game is the combat and the combat can be fun at times. It is braindead but it can still be fun. But there are a bunch of problems which at times makes the combat extremely frustrating. The targeting sucks, locked camera angle sucks, quicktime event sucks, hits not registering sucks, hit detection sucks,invisible walls sucks and etc etc. In general stuff just didn't work as i expected them to and it just becomes extremely frustrating whenever something is actually challenging. People who like the license can probably get some fun out of this game and it is a nice touch that you get a bunch of different familiar skins to play with. But i would not recommend this game for anyone else.

Ground glitches often occur and it's sometimes bad when you have to solve how to get holocrons.  Handling Force is a bit irriating. I use Xbox one controller and when use Force repulse by using RT. I can't Force push the object to a certain target which is a DAUM thing.  Boss Combat is S.H.I.T. yes literally. Boss be like I'll do my fight and you do your way but mine's gonna hurt in first priority. When you fight Vader or Sykwalker, stunned the opponent but it hits you so hard that you are tossed and especially the lightning ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t by Fallen Skywalker.  Don't get frustrated by the poor skill, the combat is hell. you can't react fast. The game is made to kill Star Wars fans. YOU GET TO CURSE A LOT IN 'SITH LORD' DIFFICULTY

content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Note: I've played through the Wii version, which is almost an entirely different game from the 360/PS3/PC version due to motion controls and an altered storyline. Most of my problems with the game are still the same.As many other reviewers have said, this is a game with more than a few flaws which makes it very frustrating to play. The ONLY reason I might recommend this game is if you are a major Star Wars fan, it contains some nice additions to the universe. Otherwise you can just skip right over this in favor of the Jedi Knight series, which are vastly superior.Pros: For when it was released, the game's graphics are not terrible, although they definitely should have upgraded the graphics for the PC version. Interesting story. It's certainly not the best Star Wars story out there, and contains a bunch of cliches, but it's still fairly entertaining. It also provides some more lore about the time between Revenge of the Sith and A New Hope.Now then...Cons: Combat. After playing Dark Souls and other more fast-paced hack-n'-slash games, I CANNOT play this game well, even with a controller. The combat controls feel slow and clunky, and there are too many minor issues which add up to making it rarely fun. Yes, it's fun to zap people to death with electricity or throw them halfway across the map, but when that becomes you most effective tactic because enemies will stunlock you in melee or get you stuck in lightsaber clashes, the game just becomes frustrating. I want to be a badass Sith warrior, not a cheap master of ragdoll physics and electrical conductivity. Loading screens in between menus. I can understand loading screens between levels, but between MENUS? Even though they're not terribly long, that's ridiculous. And I'm running the game off an SSD. Bugs. Many users report all sorts of bugs, from falling through the world to missing textures to straight-up CTDs. I've only ever experienced one CTD and one missing texture, which popped in a few seconds later, but that still seems horribly unpolished. Terrible port. The only option for tweaking the graphics I've been able to find is the checkbox for "High Detail". WTF does that mean? And why is the game locked to 30FPS? A textbook example of developers not putting even the minimal amount of effort into a port.All in all, unless you are a rabid fan of the series, avoid this game. I really REALLY wanted to love it, but I just can't.

Now I though that for some reason that this would be better than the ps3 version which I had (and though it was boring). Little did I know that even with unofficial files to help make the game more playable, the game is still broken.Most of you probably didn't have the same issue I had but I'm gonna say what issues I had.1. When the game starts up, on the battle of  Kashyyk, the audio started off EXTREMELY off balance. You could barely hear either voices or music thanks to the sound effects and this was all on normal settings in the audio option2. When facing the jedi as vader, the camera is locked away from where the battle suppose to be, making it difficult to actually see what's happening (I beat him, he's not ment to be hard anyways)3. This is more of the issue from the fps unlocker but some reason you'd constantly levetate anything upwards, making the use of the force annoying4. The break on the cammel's back, When fighting the jedi on the space station, the audio gave up and just died. Literally it gave up and no audio was coming out. I though there was something wrong with my hardware but it turns out it wasn't cause a cutscene to interrupt the boss fight played and there were sound.Yea, I rage quit afte that but after seeing this kind of problem, I should have known that playing this on the pc would be a bad idea to the point I'm pretty scared to see how the 2nd game (Force Unleashed II) would perform if the first game had this slew of problems.I really don't recommend this game to anyone unless you are covered in good luck to not run into this landfill of bugs.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												Honestly while i enjoyed playing this game around the time of the original release of the game (On my ps2 of which i played even up to when i bought this from time to time,which varied in content though the plot obviously was still pretty similar though didnt quite live up to my hopes for this game) There is a summary at the bottom if you dont want to read through the whole thing.Combat issues: I figured that i would give this a try see what was new with the ultimate sith edition,but honestly i felt especially with lightsaber combat it just wasnt very well done,felt almost like turn based combat in some ways (though admittedly that could just be minor lag from my computer) and seemed like i could only focus on one-two enemies at a time. This was somewhat irritating for ranged combat when i couldnt move and block when got a constant fire on me. (Minor issue that if timed right wasnt too bad,but still certainly took away from the smoothness of the game) Bonus mission issues: With the mission where you go to the jedi temple for trials,just felt underdone. You kill a few enemies on the way there but thats about it,wasnt expecting a ton of things but it was literally just go here,lift it up,do the same thing on the other side and walk acrossed,just keep the ball on line and a fight where you literally just had to use a simple maneuver to break through his guard and push him off the edge repeatedly and your done.This area was included in the version i had played originally and included various boss fights and added to the story such as one took on the form of juno for parts of the fight which starkiller reacted to accordingly. The little ending video i will confess i thought was great though and added to the story in a positive way towards his reluctance to completely relinquish his ties to the dark side and fear that vader would always have a hold on him and served as a vision of sorts towards the dark side ending to the game itself. The Tatooine mission was alright though lacked a sense of story to it beyond just that basic stuff given away at the start of the mission,the inclusion of proxy was unnecessary and did not contribute anything to the story as it didnt tell you how he got there,it was interesting to fight Ben Kenobi though.But with the Boba Fett fight again it just felt very easy. Then there was the Hoth mission,which was nothing more then a follow up to the Tatooine mission,and like tatooine it served as a "what if" but beyond that added nothing,you fight luke but thats really about it. None of them contained any real sort of puzzles beyond just paying attention to the game.Other Issues: The biggest thing i noticed when comparing this to the game i had played years previous to this was the difference in customization. the positives to this ones was the many variations of armor appearences though most were other characters that anyone looking to play through on a more story based gamestyle likely wouldnt use,but had a few custom gears that were pretty cool. As for lightsaber customization it still had the power crystals though they didnt feel very diverse or add any effects visually to the saber (Minor issue) the color crystals i was pleased with but there really wasnt too much they could do to screw that up beyond a rainbow crystal (A part of me just died imagining that) Biggest issue with customization was the total lack of any sort of modification to the hilt whatsoever.Overall this really just wasnt worth buying unless you had never played the game before and just want to see what force unleashed is. The side missions did nothing for the story and were just a couple bonus fights that took very little time to complete with the exception of the temple mission which as i mentioned there was a more extensive version included in the regular force unleashed i bought years prior to playing the sith edition. lost hilt customization entirely but there is crystal customization. The combat was not something i enjoyed very much though could still complete my objective without much trouble. Boss fights were done pretty well,though sadly lost a few in this version for the main story. This did however feature several various types of storm troopers i did not see in the regular. The game is adequate at best in my opinion and for every gain with this i feel there the loss of something as well.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												It's a port from a console, and it's not a very good one either.Default 30 fps lock, altough it can be modded to be 60 fps.Menu navigation is not supported for mouse, and the keyboard layout cannot be changed.Option menu is extremely limited, for changing the graphics you have to tick a single checkbox.Menu graphics are obviously meant for consoles, but for PC screens, they're way too huge. (And a pain to navigate)The game CAN get enjoyable at some parts, but most of the time it feels tiresome to play it. The sore need for a save after a risky, long battle can get especially tiresome, since if you die after the battle, you will be spawned back to the last checkpoint.This especially comes up when fighting bosses. Just about to kill a boss in your last breath, but only manage to die and start it almost all over again.Bosses are a spam to play, sometimes even outright annoying with the limited saving capabilities you have, and are sometimes even unfair. (ex. You can only hit the boss once per combo, while the boss can punch through your defences and ruthlessy spam it)If you like QTE's you might actually like this one a lot.TL;DR Game portrays you as a powerful jedi and falls on spam tactics and QTEs.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												If this game would have been made today, it would be a great game. The fighting is fresh and cool and you have plenty of powers and abilities and combos to keep the gameplay nice and progressive. The problem with this game lies in the details.  There are alot of quicktime event, and they suck. The animations are great sure but quicktime events is a bad thing in itself and these are often hard to start because you are already spamming the buttons when it starts so you almost always fail the first time you try. Some missions are just painful, the worst was the mission where you have to bring a Star destroyer with the force but 6-7 tie fighter keep shooting at you, you then have to destroy them and continue destroying the ship(which takes a while) but the mission is very badly made and very very hard, way too hard in fact since more than half the time I tried to pick the ties with the force(you can only use the force to destroy them) it dosent work and they just pass through your grip and ♥♥♥♥ you up. Its a great game, but if you are easily frustrated like me, dont buy it unless its very very cheap and you dont mind getting stuck somewhere 4 hours while almost falling to the Dark side in real life.Tl;Dr: This game is so frustrating that I almost fell to the dark side playing it.
