												I decided to get this game after remember the good times I had playing this on the WII.Pros: The levels are different from the WII version.Enemies randomly over.Great sense of nostalgia.Cons:Graphics are quite buggy. Be careful with those quick time events!Can... not... skip... any... cut... scenes...Terrible menu system. Remember: use the [ ] keys if you want to quit\ when in the menu.Force throwing object is hit and miss... quite literally >:(Sounds are missing from the last 2 levels (it is 2015 and it is still not fixed!?!?)The ending of the 2nd to last level is INSANELY HARD!!! You really need a controller for this partConclusion:Play this for the memories and for star wars enjoyment. If you hate bugs, then this is not a good game for you.

Don't buy this game, it can't be played in its current state, and it's very unlikley this issue will ever be fixed.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												In the broad spectrum of available Star Wars games that provide a Jedi/Sith experience, this game falls near the bottom.  The story is surprising good, gives a believeable bridge between the end of Episode 3 and Episode 4.  Familiar characters, interersting planets, decent diaglogue, and provides a story that you actually WANT to progress through.  But this is a video game, so it's not just sit back and enjoy and this is where the problems start. The gameplay itself is clunky at best.  Controls feel like you are playing from a distance.  The view and movement seem to work alright, but aiming any time of force ability is near impossible.  With how frequently this game requires the use of force manipulation, this is a serious problem.  It's difficult to aim any objects, and force moves tend to be useless unless aimed well which on any respectable difficulty tends to not give enough time.  The world itself, is wrought with bad physics.  Its very easy to slash an enemy off a ledge, but the game allows you to follow them off the edge with a mid slash.  It forces you to avoid ledges and high places (And there are MANY).  The lightsaber is unsatisfying as there are no "combos" to speak of uinless combing with the force.  Recovering from hits, explosions, or force moves takes longer than it should so in a multi enemy environment you have to be extremely conservative.  Boss fights are another point of contention.  Instead of the typical 3rd person view, the world expands and you are left with a 4th wall type view (similar to how the Lego games are played; small camera movement but its mostly fixed and you travel through a roughly round arena and move forward and back.)  Its an odd choice, and makes it even MORE difficult to effectively use the force against your opponent.   Boss fights tend to be hack and slash, finishing with a combo push X button X times, then push Y button, then quickly push Z button and if you miss the sequence you lose and take damage and do it again.  Very arcadey.  The upgrade system, despite trying to be a little more RPG-esque is limited.  You unlock points slowly, and you unlock skills to BE unlocked slowly.  Seems like you should just automatically unlock them as you go as it's a pain to pause, go to the menu (Forced to use the keyboard as there is no mouse support on menus), and select the skill you want to spend on.  Most of which seem more vanity items. I'd say with the option to play games like KOTOR for the RPGish style, or Jedi Outcast/Jedi Academy this game just doesn't compare.  Those games provide very pointed and well polished experience.  This game has serious view/control issues which translate to gameplay and force use being next to maddening.  The physics and level design is just unremarkable and worse than it should be.  Controls are ported which is unfortunate, and the menu system will drive you mad.  The story drew me in enough, that I uninstalled the game but ventured to youtube and found a full "movie" of the cutscenes and a little gameplay so it turned the game into a movie.  I'd recommend you do the same, the game just doesn't live up to what I was hoping for.

number of helpful: 16 of 34 people (47%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
-Disclaimer-Hey, Hey you... Yes you, the person who's about to thumbs down my review. Did you notice that I actually LIKE the game? Just because I didn't recommend the game didn't mean I didn't enjoy it.This game fell right between the lines of "recommend" and "not recommend" and that's a sign to me that most people probably would rather play something else. You're welcome to disagree with me, but at least comment to tell me why. -Quick Review-Ever want to blast people with "UNLIMITED POWER"? Like the idea of picking up stormtroopers and throwing them into the abyss? Have you ever wanted to try mixing lightsaber moves with various force techniques?...Then this... ....MIGHT... ...be the game for you? -Detailed breakdown review- Story: you play as Starkiller, Darth Vaders Secret apprentice. Star killers been put into a twisting story of nearly constant betrayal, being a spy and agent for Lord Vader tends to have that effect on you.Starkiller's soul purpose is to hunt down the enemies of the empire and bring them to justice, Starkiller learns various force and lightsaber techniques to assist him in his hunt. The story takes place after the clone wars, but before the first Death Star is fully constructed.You can play through the story in maybe 6-12 hours, depending on how much extra collecting you do and difficulty you play on. The game also does the cheap fork-story-ending, so you need to go back and make your choice over again, if you want to see both endings. Game Play: This is where the game hurts... sometimes literally.this game was designed to be played with a controller, but even with a controller the game is a mess, the camera is tricky, targeting is terrible, you need to spend a majority of the first few levels learning simply how to pick up the correct object (since it's linked to which way Starkiller is facing, INSTEAD OF MY CAMERA. Sheesh) To be quite blunt and fair, the controls of this game are a very good reason for people to steer clear and spend their money on a game they might actually enjoy playing. However this game did have great potential, and brought a lot of great concepts, but it definitely needed more work before it was released.To talk really briefly about the various attacks, you have force lightning, force push, lightsaber attack, and block. There are various combinations of these four to make up your combat type in the game. The game seems to prefer you supplement your lightsaber strikes with force moves, instead of going full blown Master Yoda mode.There is one final thing to say about the Game Play... Screw Quick Time events. They don't NEED to be bad, but they are in this game. You'll also have them memorized; it gets repetitious fast.  Achievements: There were achievements on the Xbox version, there might be achievements some time but as of now there are none (03/19/15). We should probably count ourselves lucky. However, the accomplishments, unlockables and extra's are still in the game so you still can obtain them, if you so desire. Price I purchased The Force Unleashed: Ultimate Sith Edition from a humble bundle, so naturally I suggest waiting for sales before purchasing. The standard price for The Force Unleashed on steam is $19.99. Not a fair price, in my opinion. I will be squeezing out more hours of the game doing the extra content. Conclusion: I don't know that I can really recommend this game for anyone who ISN'T already a star wars fan, if you knew nothing of the franchise, or just simply didn't care one way or another, this game is a skip for you.If you happen to consider yourself the avid Star Wars nerd/fan you'll probably be able to overlook the games follies and enjoy watching/playing/listening to the story of Starkiller.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update April 11, 2015:Here's the URL to see my review for The Force Unleashed IIAdded a Disclaimer

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												What can I say about force unleashed? This is a hard one to review because I have not been able to finish this. I'm not one to claim to be a great video game player. I play most of my linear style games on easy / medium settings and I look for more plot and direction of the story. A good story can often overcome some bugs and glitches or bad game mechanics.Not with this game. This is a bad game. Its not often I will say this but this is a game to avoid. When you are introduced to the story, there is so much hope and promise, But unfortunately the rest of the game gets in the way. The gameplay is unpolished. The mechanics are boring and repetitive. What looks like it could be a well thought out fight mechanic quickly turns into button mashing adventure of whack a mole, as computer controlled oponents constantly spawn and run at you. The AI is terrible as most enemies will stand there and take it. UNfortunately, The Enemy AI, being extremely weak is compensated for by boss fight mechanics that are repeitively annoying. We're not talking about, 5-10 moves that are varied up. Most enemy bosses will come at you with no more than 2-3 moves. Often will just stun / slam you into a corner or invisible wall (more on thos later!) and repeat that for 20 or so seconds while you watch in disbelief unable to even interact with your character. Many enemies have artificial buffs to try and counter you. They are extremely one dimension. SOme are immune to force. Some autoblock lightsabers. Some can't get shoved, some cant get electrocuted. it seems artificial and fake. The gameplay itself is extremely 1 directional. You follow the path forward at all points. This isn't necessarily bad for a platformer. I tend to like directed story games. But this one isn't good. You're often rudely interrupted while running for cutscenes that are abrupt and out of place. The paths look like you might have multiple ways of going, but you quickly find that they are just invisible walls and that your direction is set no matter what.The biggest offender though of the game mechanics? the overuse, constantly abusing you with QUicktime events. If it's a non standard enemy. So, Any AT_T walkers, rancor, or the like, which come more and more frequently as you progress, will end with a Quicktime event. You will do thousands of them. And they're not short either. many of them taking 20-30 seconds of watching you kill the enemy with some completely arbitrary, pre-scripted event that has nothing to do with the way you fight in game and acts as a complete disconnect to the battle system.Then you get to the worst boss battle in any star wars game I can ever recall. Perhaps one of my least liked boss battles ever. The Star Destroyer. Combine all that is wrong in this game, add in broken gameplay mechanics, incorrect instructions on screen and constant waves of enemies that are timed on purpose to prevent you from finishing this boss quickly, I just gave up.And just when you thought it can't get worse. it does. The Camera system is frustrating. it does not always follow you smoothly from behind and during many fights, you will find it swinging widly around, changing how your character responds to your button presses. Then Boss fights introduces brand new camera mechanics. It attempts to emulated a 1v1 side scrolling fighter, but horribly. The camera finds a fixed position off in the distance and just shows you the "map" you are to fight in. Except, the controls don't lend well to this view and you will find yourself runing into walls and posts and getting stuck with things in your feet between you and your foe, making most boss fights a fight against the camera, not the enemyThis game, with only a few hours played ahs become oen of the least enjoyable experience I have ever had in the star wars universe. My final rating is a 1/10 stars. or whatever rating you want to give it. I recommend reading the story on wiki instead of wasting your money, time, and frustrating emotional outbursts on just how terrible this game is. Avoid at all costs. I have deleted this game from my steam library. I never intend to play it again nor the second.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												One of the poorest quality PC ports available on Steam. Control and video options have to be set in a launcher outside the game, and the options available in-game are barebones, not even including an option for subtitles in-game, let alone cutscenes.Combat is unnecessarily difficult. The lock-on key is useless, and force powers are extremely difficult to aim. Lifted enemies and objects fly in crazy directions that don't seem to take any input from keys pressed or mouse movements. Boss battles add to the frustration, as bosses can shrug off force powers and lightsaber attacks with impunity, and often seem to be completely invincible during scripted movement and combat sequences.Even on my relatively nice gaming rig (GTX 680 x2, i7 3820 @3.6Ghz, 32Gbs RAM) this game suffers constant stuttering, and  odd split-second flashes of other scenes when using some force powers and lightsaber attacks.Just from a technical standpoint this game is a failure, but the ridiculous (and unfortunately canon) storyline only pushes this pile of garbage further into the "forgetful" realm of gaming. It's hard to choke down even as an avid Star Wars fan.-5/10

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												Well this is my first "NO" review. Since the beginning the game was a 6.5 for me...but i finish the game 100% so i could give an objective review.Playtime:16hours on "hard" (including the 3 campaigns of the sith edition, ~1h each).First thing you will see in this game is that this will consume pretty 30GB in your disc (SWU 2 will consume just 10)...One of the most annoying issues of the game is that you can't skip some cut scenes... but when you want to take an screenshot (or even push the volume key)... "BANG" the cut scene is gone... so... WTF? (i'm a screenshot fan so this is a "turn down").Graphics are amazing, and have a nice story... but i'll recommend this game only to SW fans... if you are looking for a good  and cool hack&slash game, just keep looking and save 20 bucks. game is too easy, you are more focus in the secrets than the enemies and "sith edition" doesn't have anything special more than those 20GB extra in your disc (3 campaigns of 50min each? come on).So why 6.5? here we go: -Graphics 10/10 (graphics are awesome, i had fun taking in-game screenshots)-Music 7/10 (music of all sw games... is that good? yes, but makes a hack&slash boring sometimes)-History 9/10 (to bad is not cannon)-Controls 10/10 (respond fine, but have to separate this from "combos/mobility")-AI 4/10(AI sucks like hell, enemies can stand in front of you without doing anything... on hard difficulty)-Difficulty 4/10 (extremely easy, on hard difficulty. enemies are stupid and main character is too OP)-Camera 7/10 (can get stuck a few times, but nothing to be worry)-Combos/Mobility 4/10 (even if controls are good, combos kinda sucks and mobility can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ your character can just layout in the ground while he's being shoot)-Menu 6/10 (simple that's good... but mediocre...)-Re playability 4/10 (the game is too easy, there's nothing special that lead you to play it again)Total: 6.5

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												Gameplay- The Force Unleashed's main goal was to make the player feel like they are a sith lord, being able to use different, powerful force based attacks. In that aspect the game delivers, but this all gets boring after a while, as combat is rediculousy easy, I'm sure anyone can beat the game without upgrading too much. Combat is not satifying at all, as you find yourself killing waves and waves of enemies without trying. During the second part of the game different variants of storm troopers arrive, in order to kill them you have to use a particular technique, this gets boring FAST. Most boss fights are pretty lame as well, as many of the bosses limit or restrict your uses of the force powers, or they require constant button mashing. This makes the boss fights boring and not rewarding, a good example of a well designed boss fights would be the colossuses in Shadow Of The Colossus, all the bosses were unique. Mr Freeze from Batman Arkham city would be another one, as Freeze adapts to your attacks, evades, and movements. It was a multi step fight with out lame QTE sequences or out of placed cutsences, which were everywhere in The Force Unleashed.Story- The story is mediocre, which is really sad because the Star Wars universe is very interesting. The main character Galen Marek is very dull, and has no emotions, a good comparison to Marek would be Connor from Assasin's Creed III, which is not a good thing. Other characters are not much better etheir, everyone just seemed so boring and unteresting. The missions are not much better ethier, they all feel the same, as you slaughter waves and waves of enemies. level design was flawed, as many of the levels looked very similar and were boring to play through. The Force Unleashed has two endings, both were terrible, the good ending being a little bit better than the bad one, but thats not saying much at all. In the end you find yourself not being able to make any decisions as the game does that for you, but it really does not matter as the build up and the characters along the way were boring and painfully average.Overall opinion- The Force Unleashed is game made only for Star Wars fans, if you want a hack and slash game, go ahead and buy DMC, it's much better than this. If you desire a game that explores the lore and mythos of Star Wars, this not the game for you etheir. The people that would enjoy the Force Unleashed would be hardcore star wars fans and people that want a easy game where you feel like a god. At the end of the day Star Wars The Forced Unleashed is a disappointing  game, it could have been great but instead it fell short, The Force Unleashed is not a terrible game, but it's not a good one etheir.Rating- 6/10 Average game.

												I'm a fan of Star Wars and I have played a lot of Star Wars games, This is one of the worst. This game is a Like God of War type button mashing combat game. I did a long time ago and it's awesome. Save yourself the time of trying to get through this horribly broken game.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This is with out a doubt, the WORST star wars game ever created. The storyline is trash, the voice actors are all incredibly annoying, and the camera angles are something straight out of the third circle of hell. Then theres the god aweful targeting system. Unless what your trying to electrocute is right in front of you, dont expect your character to pay much attention to what your aiming for. all of the movements in this game seem very slow, and it's at the point that the ai seem to fall over just trying to walk that you wonder if they copied the movements of a toddler learning to walk. Occasionally there is supposed to be sound, but it seems like the developers over looked that part. sure, it's not the biggest deal breaker, but if you're already flat out heated about something, it'll make you question the drugs you were on when you purchased this utter trash. If you have a high sensitivity mouse such as a corsair rgb or a deathadder, be prepaired to lower your dpi to its lowest levels. This is due to the stupid camera that occasionaly likes to hyper look ion the wrongest angle possible. Getting back to gameplay, if your character takes even the slightest hit, he will freeze, put up his hands and write ''shoot me, I'm open" on his chest. he will do NOTHING to attempt to save himself, but crawl shakily to his knees. Possibky one of the worst games I've ever played, and I played E.T

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												Do not get this game. Oh my god, no. I played this a long time ago as a kid and saw it on sale yesterday and thought "Wow, how cool! Ultimate Sith edition? Heck yeah i'm gonna waste $4.99 on this game!" I downloaded it overnight and played it today. I was more than disappointed.First off, the mouse and keyboard controls are slow and don't make much sense when it comes to the pause menu. The attacks are slow, and combat basically comes down to who can click the fastest. But that's not even the worst part of the game. The worst part is the background.When you first start you play as Vader, storming through Kashyyyk and slaughtering Wookies. Only you notice that something is off; You know that old Windows error and when the thing pops up and you try to move it, it just makes copies of itself wherever it was, making a long trail of error windows? Yeah, that's what the background does. It's incredibly distracting and impossible to play with. When you get to invading Ram Koda's space station and you enter the hanger bay, all you see are TIE Fighter wings. It just fills your screen because of the way the background glitches.Now it may be possible that this is a hardware issue on my part. Granted, I don't have the greatest gaming PC. But it meets the specs required to play it on the highest settings, and I figured since the game was fairly old my laptop could run it no sweat. Not the case in the slightest. This thing eats up RAM like nothing else. If there were someone I could contact to get my money back you'd better believe I'd get in touch with them, because I'm certain with this Winter Sale going on I could buy a much better game with that $4.99 I wasted on this garbage. In short, this game is buggy and hardly deserves to be called a game. Do not get this

												Honestly, one of the worst hack in slashes i have ever played. I beat it once before i ps3, rebought this thinking it was two, made a mistake. Regardless, i remember it being a very fun game, but i just replayed it and had a terrible timeIt is clanky. The lock on is trash. No combo depth. Pretty much no combos. The invinsibilty frames when you are knocked down, so you just keep getting knocked down over, and over without having a chance to get up. All the "Harder" characters just poise through everything and continuesly knock you down. you have to resort to the same moves. Trying to force grab a lot of objects gets you killed. The level design started nicely, but began to get boring as you see the same enviorments over and over. I personaly play a lot of hack and slashes, but this one is absolutely terrible. I lost on the same stage, the end stage in one spot, just because i kept getting shot with missles and couldn't move. I don't suggest this to anyone. I paid only 3 bucks, and regret even spending that.

												I'll keep this short.The force unleashed is an absolutely brilliant game for the first run however doesn't have much replayability, any complaints about how the game is bad by people who are replaying the game are likely because the story is horrible to re-play to the point where you find yourself noticing the smallest details wrong with the game. which is why even though I found the same issues this is a bad review not because of those issues but instead because there are No Graphics options.Allow me to restate that actually. there are three graphics options.BrightnessResolutionHigh DetailAnd High detail is a freaking tick box.Essentially because of this if you buy the game and have some kind of graphical issue, well you bought the wrong game and if those three tiny options don't fix it for you too bad, you're on your own.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This is a review of the extra DLC included in the Ultimate Sith Edition, as I’ve played the main game on a Xbox 360 back in the day and decided that i would finish up the game's DLC on pc. This review will only cover the DLCs, if you like me haven't played them and are considering buying this game just for those, otherwise check out the other reviews for an overlook at the core game.Before we go into the DLC, i have to say, this game has only and i mean ONLY! 1 single settings for graphics and that is a tick option before you launch the game “High Detail”, that’s all, you can set your resolution but you can’t tune the game to run as good as possible with your hardware, before anything make sure your hardware can run this game, because there is no options to help your system along. Second BIG complaint is that the game is locked at 30 frames per second, this can be unlocked with a hack you can easily find online if you search for “force unleashed fps unlocker” this would have to be launch separately, I’m unsure if your time played would be recorded on your steam profile.If you’ve played this game on consoles, you would have gotten accustomed to achievements and such, this port has none of those, there are even cheat codes you can use to unlock the costumes in-game, I can’t see why you would bother collecting everything on pc as there is no meaningful reward. I’ve played with a Xbox one controller, I’ve heard terrible things from people using keyboard and mouse, so be sure you have a controller ready, I do not know if you can use a PlayStation controller, you’ll have to look that up yourself.And one more thing you’ll have to be aware of, this game has to, frustratingly so, it has to load in-between menus, now I don’t just mean from main menu to game menu, I mean every. Single. Time. You change any menu, if you don’t have a fast storage device, consider the awful long loading time you’ll have to go through in-between menus.Now with all that out of the way I will now start with the dlc. Most of it is pure fan service, if you like fan service then this might be for you, if you don’t like main characters appearing randomly then this is defiantly not for you. There are a total of 3 DLC missions, each on a different planet with a different nostalgia setting. They all are about 15-30min all depending on how well you get around the level and if the game doesn’t bug out on you, which did happen to be me on the Jedi temple mission, I had to bend a bridge upwards, but the game just wouldn’t respond. I had to respawn, not once, not twice, but three times before the game would even react, this was without the fps unlocker.The first mission gives you all the powers unlocked, absolutely everything at your disposal, the second mission however takes a step back for whatever reason and starts the mission with most of everything unlocked, you can still level and unlock skills, but the menu loading didn’t make me feel like that was worth my time and even it was, the last mission had everything unlocked anyways so there isn’t really any reason to wait around the loading screen.The enemies are tedious at best, if this DLC was meant to make me feel like I was the “Ultimate Sith” then I have to take my hat off, it did no such thing. Constantly I felt like the enemies were designed to block my powers and the annoying amount of snipers on each level only made me feel like I had to run past all the enemies instead of fighting them to avoid getting frustrated.Each mission ends with a boss fight, featuring one of your beloved Star Wars characters fighting you, I didn’t enjoy any of them, they feel like they only were there as fan service and not the good kind, this is some of the worst fan service I’ve seen in a long while. Be prepared for a lot of the iconic Star Wars scenes recreated with poor enemies and poor puzzles in them, talking about iconic, the iconic Star Wars rolling text in the beginning of the movies is also in some of the missions, unskippable though and they aren’t particularly interesting either.My favorite mission out of the three was the very last one on Tatooine, you’ll meet plenty of familiar faces in this mission and even a silly boss fight at the end. I liked this mission the most because of the variety of locations you’re in, don’t get me wrong, you’re still on Tattoine, but at least it doesn’t look like the same corridors with the same enemies.My conclusion is this, if you are really into Star Wars to the point where you’ll take anything with that name stamped onto it, then this DLC is for you, if you want a quality product that you can be proud to show off to your fellow Star Wars fanatic friends, then this is not for you, heck even if you just like good games, this is defiantly not for you either.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												The game's main selling point is its physics engine. It combines Havok, Euphoria (of GTA4 fame), and DMM to rather remarkable results. And for those of you who don't know, DMM is a more in depth material modelling engine. The idea being that you get objects which bend and break like their real world counterparts. Glass shatters, wood splinters, metal bends, and plants swing. And it's remarkably effective. Often it adds to the wreckless destruction your jedi powers leave in their wake, as all sorts on the sidelines gets caught in your wrath. And at other times, it's used to open doors. Two layers of steel blocking the way? Not a problem, just punch it out of the way!However it's not an open ended game. It ultimately has you navigate a linear path, which is fine. But in order to do this, it has to put up immovable barriers to keep you there. Which rather horribly juxtaposes all that dynamic damage they have going on. In fact, in order to make sure the game's still completable, there's a lot of indestructable level geometry. The only bridge across a chasm won't break, for instance. But next to the impressive DMM magic, it feels astonishingly cheap. At times, that damage engine can just feel like a gimick you get brief glimpses of, as some areas make very sparing use of it, so the game falls back on raw gameplay for enjoyment.Which brings me to the biggest problem I have with this game. The levels feel very drawn out and artificially lengthened, and get tedious quickly. Especially as fighting enemies isn't particularly fun. The infantry type enemies don't pose any real threat, leaving you only with the choice of which force power or lightsaber combo to kill them with, coupled with how cruel your sense of humor is. The boss fights are more interesting, with moves like blocking suddenly becoming useful, but even those drag on enormously.On top of that, there's a few issues with the PC version. It's locked to 30fps and the lack of detail leaves a lot of the game looking rather bleak and apocalyptic in ways it's clearly not supposed to.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												I'll somewhat reluctantly say no but I am on the line and wish there was a middle choice. If you like Star Wars a lot and see this on a good sale, I say go for it. I found myself skipping a lot of little battles as I found them repetitive and the combat system wasn't intricate enough to compel me to stand and fight all the time wave after wave. Beat the game in 7.5 hours.Instead of playing this, I would just watch the story recap on YouTube and play Force Unleashed II instead which stands up to time much better and has pretty much all of the cons fixed.Pros:- Star Wars universe game- Force powers are fun to mess around with - physics sandbox- Story isn't amazing but it is compelling enoughCons:- Graphics are fairly dated- Same as above but CGI/cinematic scenes are super weird - the face animations in particular are bizarre to look at- Camera control is kludgy and very dated- Blocking doesn't seem well integrated and there is no countering that I found- Fights become repetitive with limited lightsaber combat options- Throwing things with the Force often doesn't go the way you would want it to

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												The force unleashed is a game that promised much but delivered little.  It fully has the potential to such a fantastic game but it falls way short due to production issues.  The game is rife with glitches, making you encounter 2-3 at least on each mission, which gets extremely annoying by the time you're halfway through.  Combat itself is extremely enjoyable, coupled with leveling up in a sense to develop new skills.  The biggest disappointment is the lack of a true Good/Evil/Neutral system...the options are fairly obvious which would be fine for an older game, but just detracts from a game as new as this one.  Overall, it's enjoyable to a mediocre degree, but not a great addition to the Star Wars universe.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												So much wrong here. The controls feel like you’re spinning round an action figure rather than somebody with any weight. You find yourself being constantly being thrown around like a ragdoll and most of my deaths seemed to come from being shunted off a platform, resulting in a frustrating return to the last checkpoint. Actually the platforming in general is just annoying. The game sticks to the Star Wars universe’s famous lack of health and safety regulations, so any false step will send you plummeting down a chasm. The camera is less than helpful here and there’s an obscene number of invisible walls placed seemingly at random (jumping towards a bridge, hitting an invisible wall mid-air and sliding down into the mouth of Sarlacc was a particularly ignoble end). The story is nonsense with a painfully bland protagonist. You are meant to be uber powerful but even your force powers are unsatisfying to use, when using force grip it feels like you are wobbling an object in to place rather than showing any mastery. The only time you actually do something impressing is in the numerous quick time sequences with pop up to disrupt any sort of flow in the game. Oh and that Star Destroyer sequence from the trailer.. it’s one of the most of the most painfully terrible bits of gameplay I’ve experienced.

number of helpful: 12 of 27 people (44%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												I just came back to this game after a year's hiatus and got an abrupt reminder of why I stopped playing it in the first place. I just about had an aneurysm out of sheer rage while trying to finish a level I gave up on before. Lemme put things in a list.Story: Well, it's not terrible. I've seen worse writing plenty of times. It just isn't very grabbing to me. Don't take my opinion on this, though; I've never put much thought into the backstory of the Star Wars franchise.World Design/Graphics: About what I expected. Looks like a Star Wars game. Some of the expressions and character models look like they were made in Garry's Mod, but it's bearable.Physics: RUN. RUN FAR AWAY. The physics engine in this game is just god-awful. Platforming is a pain; accurately judging a jump is like trying to throw a ball whose density is constantly fluctuating. Some of the terrain is horridly rough, with smooth ground being un-walkable in random spots. Of course, none of this helps while fighting. And speaking of that...Combat: The control scheme for fighting isn't too bad. Basic combat maneuvers, such as jumping, slashing, lighting, and dodging are all on natural-feeling buttons. The AI, however, is an absolute NIGHTMARE. Enemies will constantly gang up on you, slapping you around like a pinball in combos that are infuriatingly hard to get out of: blocking and dashing while being hit are impossible. And when the guys right next to you aren't hitting you, the ones halfway across the map are picking you off with impossibly accurate potshots that must be either swatted away by the auto-deflect feature (which has about a 2% success rate) or deflected manually by holding the block button, meaning you can't do ANYTHING ELSE. Which leads to you getting beat over the skull by all those guys right next to you. Crowd control is unlocked about halfway through the game, and DUMPS your force energy gauge. No spamming the "Get away from me!" button.My reccommendation: Steer clear of this game. It's not worth the pain and suffering.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												A MESS!!! WHAT A MESS!!!I pity those who bought the retail pc game some years ago, or those who have paid 20 bucks for this BROKEN mess; hell, I've bought this for less than 7 bucks and I regret it, lolTFU was supposed to be the super-satisfying, amazing LucasArts game of the post-06 HD generation, and hey! I'm sure the game was kind of great for consoles (mostly Xbox) but this pc "port" is an insult, an INSULT, pure and simple.List of offenses against pc gamers: a motion blur glitch which ruins the backdrops and severely affects gameplay in medium-hard difficulties (currently unfixable for many graphic cards), the random crash to desktop (fortunately not that common), lack of configuration options other than resolution (yes, believe it or not it's true), pause menu straight from the xbox (doesn't support mouse), limited save options (you only have ONE save file for EVERY walkthrough you may attempt, that means you won't be able to randomly replay your favourite levels once you've finished the game), 29 GB (!!!!)  for a 07-08 game that, if properly optimized, shouldn't have been more than 11; LACK of DLC for the pc version; the list goes on and on...and last but not least: shame on you Steam, this pc port isn't even worth 5 bucks, and you know itlol, do you still want to purchase, install and play this game?? you've been warnedthe game itself (the console version, I mean) is ok (6,5/10, maybe a 7): serviceable hack-n-slash, varied force-powers that, once mastered, are truly helpful, nice sound design, etc. The levels usually overstay their welcome, though. The story starts very strong but nearly collapses with a twist that is forced and makes you feel confused and full of questions...the story tries TOO HARD to be relevant to the events of the New Hope (yes, it smells of rotten retcon)...My advice= buy this on a sale and go for a quick "easy level" walkthrough, because what the hell, it's Star Wars; and then stick with Jedi Outcast/Academy and all those solid gold mods out there. Of course, if you own an Xbox by all means, IGNORE the pc port and buy the proper console version if you really need to play this game.RIP LucasArts, indeed

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												No wonder there were so few Sith lords.  If they had to suffer the misery of The Force Unleashed, I'm sure they would turn their light sabers on themselves.  This game was so bad that I could not finish it, which is saying a lot.  I got to one of the final battles, and apparently my mouse sensitivity was not high enough to win the fight.  Yes, the game allows you to set a controller to the "lose" position.  But I had lost interest in the game long before that point.Imagine a whole galaxy of mindless foes to dispatch in creative and entertaining ways.  Got it?  Ok, leave it to your imagination.  This game will in no way match whatever enjoyment you received from your creative musings.  Instead, this game provides an opportunity to grind you way to the Sith Lord Hall of Fame with such unenjoyable features as:  braindead AI, braindead AI that's immune to your powers, Quicktime Events, backtracking, and jumping puzzles!  Hopefully you will get more enjoyment from this review than from the dreadful game that inspired it.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												What shines in this game is not the action, but the paused moments on the diverse worlds where the art direction shines brilliantly. If you must play this game, i do recommend playing it on easy mode and just breezing through it as you swing your glowing wiffleball bat at enemies until the next story beat. The combat is not its strong suit, its unremarkable and often very disempowering for whats supposed to be a very empowering demigod force wielding character when he is picked up by enemies like a small child and then tossed around like a rag doll and almost every single enemy has a means to block or outright be immune to basic light saber attacks, so for a majority of the time you will not be actually using your light saber. It requires mana to use combo attacks, so you will be hindered in the amount of combos you are allowed to perform over time, meaning it does not incentivise you to perform them. The horse isn't dead enough yet, because I have to talk about how awful the targetting system is, because a large amount of boss fights require you to use force powers at key moments and target flying objects that may or may not be trying to kill you, they rarely respond to targeting. You will be doing those sequences multiple times, over and over, in frustration and just wanting the ride to end, but it doesn't end, not yet, oh no, there are more QTE's to get through.

												i dont know how this game has so many recomendations, i feel obligated to tell people what its really like, hopefully it might save someone some money or time.first off, im a huge star wars fan, i started playing x-wing in 6th grade and played every star wars game since then. this game is absloutely trash, just unfinished, bad controls, glitchy graphics, etc.there are quick time events, but you cant watch whats happening, which is usually cool becuase you need to look at what button to pres next. who in their right mind thought that having a fixed camera during a boss fight is a good idea? not to mention the boss fights often spam moves like a 7th grader playing mortal combat. also its a platformer with not resposive controls is a recepie for frustration. if you like star wars do not subject yourself to this, you will regret it. from now on i will no longer play star wars games just becuase its star wars (and lucasarts which when i was growing up made incredilbly inovative products) i will take everything they put out with a healthy dose of sckeptisism. its really a shame, i just started re-playing the original dark forces, and its crazy how a game thats more than 15 years old is above and beyond this game.was there anything at all i liked? while the first level you get to play as darth vader and kill a ton of wookies, its quite fun, and sometime (in between combat) where the graphics look pretty nice

number of helpful: 18 of 40 people (45%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I am not usually one to hate on things, but this game is just bad, very bad...and here's why:Let's start with the list of "would be pros" (things that could be good about the game if the execution wasn't so terrible): - Fun combat system. Great, so many combos to use...if it wasn't for the fact that you will never use most of them. Especially the longer, most powerful combos are useless - weak enemies will be dead long before you finish them and strong ones will interrupt them 99% of the time. Also most of the stronger ones have superior power on melee range, so you'll just end up pouring electricity into them from safe distance until it stops being funny.   - Oh, wanted to list something more, but just realized that 'tis a part of the cmbat system as well. There is not really anything else in this game than combat anyway. So, okay - using the things lying around to fight. Sounds fun, right? Just tearing a block of metal from the wall with the Force and smashing it into your enemies. The hell it does! But it takes so long you cannot use it. First you have to target the object (more on targeting later, that's the stuff of nightmares). Use the pull ability on it, the slooooowly float it around, direct it on the enemies and release...there you go! Oh, damn, why am I lying on the floor with half HP gone? Something must have gone wrong in the process. The thing is you cannot move while doing this so you'll probably get hit by a missile or five before you get to the carnage part. Did I mention getting knocked off your feet interrupts the pull? So this one's a no go.That's it, my list of "what could have been pros if better executed" is officially over. Now for the cons:  - Characters. They have no character whatsoever. And their behavior makes absolutely no sense. No thinking being would act like that.  - Story. There is a story? Must have missed it. Kill this, kill that, kill something more. Oh, the Dark Lord betrayed us? Let's kill him as well.  - Enemies. They are plain stupid and predictable. If you don't try to use any of the longer combos or never stop to chuck some debris around, you will pretty much never get hit with anything that hurts. Which basically limits all the abilities and combos to using 3-4 things (out of dozens) over and over again. - Boss fights. The camera turns into a 1990 abomination during those. And the winner of our "worst thing about The Force Unleashed" contest is (without any competition to speak of) the targetting system. You have no crosshair, no cursor or anything to pick a target. You just look in the general direction and hope the game picks the one you want. Normally it's pretty much a 50/50 thing, so it is still playable. But during the boss fights, with the atrocious camera, targeting becomes nothing short of abysmal. Most of the fight you spend running in circles around your enemy in a hopeless strive to target him/her. Mostly you hit things just by accident - when you aren't even trying to. Blocking their abilities is even worse, because you often have only around half a second to target them. I consider myself a patient person - I don't have a problem with repeating something I did wrong many times over until I get it right. Well, I'm also very stubborn, so I will keep trying even if it meant dying for the whole day. But this...this almost made me quit the game a couple times. Not because of the dying, but because I knew I didn't do anything wrong, just the mechanics are atrocious. Now that I've finished it I wish I rather quit. Not worth the time even if it was free.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Product received for free
												I feel like this game is good, but it's missing a lot of things.Pro's of the game:-It's Star Wars, and it's still The Force Unleashed, even if it differs from the other versions.-You get basically all of the extra outfits and DLC (Afterall, it is Ultimate Sith Edition)-It has a lot of fun features. You just run around, slice everyone up and use different force powers to unleash chaos. I feel like it can be challenging at times, but depending on what difficulty you choose, it's never unmanagable.-I imagine that most computers, even potato computers can run this on at least low settings.Con's of the game:-Ported. The controls aren't very smooth, and using the force to throw people into eachother or do complex stuff is sort of hard.-Capped at 30FPS unless you use mods-No windowed mode. You can only play it in full screen-They took out a lot of the content from the other versions. For example, I don't think the levels with the Jedi Temple exist. Also, they either changed some of the levels or made them different. They replaced a lot of the enemies in the other versions as well. There aren't Navy Commandos, or medics, or really a whole ton of the same enemies from the PS2 version. Also, I might be wrong on this as well but it seems like there are less collectibles to find, such as the Lightsaber crystals.-Graphics aren't really extremely good, even on high settings with "High Detail" mode on, but it was made a little while ago.Overall, I'd say it's a fun game but don't buy it for the full price. I recieved this for free from a friend, and I wasn't dissapointed but it was a slightly different experience than what I remember on the PS2 version.6/10

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												Writing here on 05 Dec 2015.Everything is wrong with this game, avoid it. Spoend your time and money on a cheap excellent indie game like Invisible Inc. Don;t waste your time on this game, go play something else.* Combat is repetitive, just hack and slash. * No skill required in combat.* No story, * No character progression.* No loot to collect.* No weapons dropped by enemies.* No weapon pickups.* No loot in destroud boxes or objects.* Linear path, just follow the dot, no alternative routes.* Console port with no PC specific additions. Framerate loecked at 30 frmaes per second (fps) is a disgrace to PC gamers.* No tradeables with other NPCs.* Pre-rendered video, Full motion video cut-scenes.* Bland levels with lots of brown, dark brown and dark colors. * Repetitive scenery.*(Enemy) difficulty increases by increasing the number of enemies.* Enemies rush up to you and all you have to do is cut  'em down.* No skill based combat. If your upgrade for 'skill points' was not right you'll take much longer to defeat an enemy, whereas with a game for example Metal Gear Revengeance one could defeat an enemy on skill.* It is totally possible to speed run through whole sections/levels, avoiding combat.* Gfx is horrible console ported, even for 2008 standard. A digrace to PC gamers.* Plays like an arcade coin-up game, but the endless version. * DirectX9 game not compatible with my LG 3D displays. * Horrible framerate, only 30 fps. According to Steam forumsa this was how the game was designed to run, framerate locked.* Played with a wireless XBOX360 controller on PC.Don't waste your time on this, go play something else. I have invested a lot of my precious time in this game. I knew I shoul've played Invisble Inc, or Endless Legend or  Withcher 3 instead... but now I'm this far I might as well finish this.

												Force Unleashed?  No.     Force mildly unrestrained, YesPoor to decent game with average force powers.  If your looking for a Jedi game play Jedi Knight: Jedi Outcast. Was hoping Force Unleashed II would be better but still have not got it to run correctly.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												This game is disappointing. I played this game on the PS3 and Wii. If you have a console, buy it on the console (even on the Wii it's a lot more fun). This is a terrible port to the PC and I'm very very disappointed. Cons:-Locked on 30fps-Loading screen for everything-Loading takes a long time-Only singleplayer (on console there was a fighting mode)-Feels choppy due to the frame limit-Shift + TAB Steam overlay glitches during cutscenes-Very boring when playing with Keyboard and Mouse-Repetitive-Awkward Camera position during boss fights-Background graphics look like crap-Why can't i play as Juno Eclipse?Pros (as experienced from this PC version only)-Not so awful visuals for a third person game-Decent physics-Good storyline-Good character development and amount of characters-Cheat codes-A lot of costumes-A lot of force combos-Many different map design and you go on a lot of different planetsOverall this game is not so great on the PC. You can play with a controller, but still, you're playing with 30 fps so why not play this on console instead. Besides, you can go to gamestop, get a $5 pre-owned Force Unleashed instead. If you don't own a console and you want this game, just don't get it at full price. I got mine for $6.60 instead of $20. If you think youre computer can't even play this game above 25 fps, then I guess it's ok. But I built a gaming PC just so I can play a crap port on 30 fps.

number of helpful: 15 of 34 people (44%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
 Star Wars The Bugs Unleashed: Ultimate♥♥♥♥♥♥EditionAs many others, I got this game with the recent humble bundle. If you are one of the unlucky ones who got it prior and payed more than 5 bucks you pretty much got ripped off.At first I was really looking forward to playing this load of crap game, as I am kind of a Star Wars fan. But already after the first hour into playing this, I already got extremely frustrated. Apart from several bugs concerning  the audio , which sometimes cuts out the music and some of the SFX during a mission and never comes back again ever, even after restarting the game and on several occasions happening  the cutscenes , as the game randomly crashes to desktiop after some and last but not least  the ragdoll system , which had me glitch out of bounds on two occasions, when a Purge Trooper grabbed me and slammed me not into, but through the ground below the world, where I was stuck, forcing me to quit and reload the save, because there is no "restart from last checkpoint"-optionthis game features some ♥♥♥♥ing infuriating gameplay-designchoices:There are absolutely no invincibility frames. None. Meaning, when you get hit by an enemy attack, which leaves you stunned for a solid second, you will get hit again by another enemy within this peroid,without you being able to defend yourself at all. If you're unlucky, you will be combo'ed to death several times when you face more than one or two enemies at once.Many attacks by the bigger enemies you will encounter, like Rancors, are unblockable. They mostly cannot be interrupted and are really nearly impossible to avoid when you go at them with your lightsaber, leaving you often times with cheesing the fights and abusing the poor AI to get them stuck on terrain and Force-Lightning the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them over and over again, as your only option to carry on with your sanity intact. All of the boss battles feel really unpolished and imbalanced. There is little feedback on how strong your opponent really is and especially on the later bossfights, you will be twoshot by an unblockable counterattack. Not to mention the incredibly stupid "bossfight" against the  Stardestroyer which you have to pull down from orbit singlehandedly with the force  in a ridiculous minigame in which you have arrange the analog sticks as shown on screen. Not only is this as silly as it sounds, they also give you the wrong directions, so you have to try around for at least 30 minutes to find the right spot to finish this♥♥♥♥♥♥off.Needless to say that these design flaws don't add to the enjoyment you will get out of this game, as it just feels clunky, unfinished, unresponsive and poorly playtested (if at all).Furthermore we have another great example of a crappy PC port. There are basically no graphic options and the game is locked at 30fps, it does feature mouse and keyboard control, but you have to edit the keys in a seperate launcher.The only reason I finished this, was my interest in the  story, although it wasn't particulary well written and the hope, that I will get some sort of satisfaction out of it, without having thrown away 10+ hours of my life.TL;DR: Crappy port, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s of aggravating bugs, infuriating combat mechanics, okay-ish story with flat characters. 2/10 would not play again.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												*Review note, I have played through the entire game on Xbox 360. This is about the PC version*Subpar graphics, awful video options menu (Brightness, contrast and Gamma), you'd expect a developer with at least ten to fifteen years experience on the PC would make a better PC version. It feels like it was developed by howler monkeys, with no hands and typewriters.Also: pressing start to skip a cutscene minimises the game and returns to your Desktop and upon opening causes a multitude of bugs including text crawls being buggy as-well as varying audio and graphical glitches.  In light Force Unleased as a game it's OK. Nothing really special, has a nice physics engine. (Which Lucasarts spent heavy time marketing it)  but aside from that. Character animations are meh, animations are stiff and robotic, etc,etc.I do like the extra content such as the added campaigns though.However, as a PC gamer. I can't recommend this ever. It's one for if you own a console.

Compared to the game released that year;take a peek on Prototype; It's just a letdown..No, buy this at your console PS3 or Wii, or don't buy it at all, you'll not regret it tho.6/10 SWTFU : Loading Simulator.edit (after finishing the whole story)- It's still a no, but not a big no, it's just.. the story is great but it's so so compared even to SW animation series. It's like there's a big hole in the story.. if you finished you'll be getting what I mean, if you're not bored to death beforehand.- The idea of "finishing blow" is good, but it's just become a standar QTE because it's so repetitive and have a little variation. And for the big boss it's just a single variation for finishing blow.- We like lightsabers, we love to have all colorful gems and crystal in it. but.. can we have another type instead the standart like the one in the movie ep 4-6...hey but, if I can use a short-bladed lightsaber, or a longer one lightsaber, or! the one like a police baton just like one of the boss in game. I would be so happy.TL;DR9 hours to complete, if you think you have a 9hours spare lifetime to see a so so story of Star Wars, you can give it a shot.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Star Wars always needed a hack and slash game. Force Unleashed was the game we needed, and deserved, after a 5 year hiatus from Jedi Knight. Ignoring, of course, that it has no multiplayer. That's probably a good thing, though, considering how wonky and broken saber duels were in JK2 and 3.Sam Witwer, the dude who voiced Darth Maul in Clone Wars and also Rebels, and also Crashdown from Battlestar Galactica 2003 (and unfortunately the protagonist in the upcoming PS4 zombie game), plays Galen Marek i.e Starkiller, Vader's secret apprentice. He finds Marek in the beginning of the game and raises him as his own, then uses him to apparently infiltrate/create the rebel alliance. TFU is kind of a Sith power fantasy where you go around beating the hell out of Jedi masters, falling in love with an imperial officer, and pulling Star Destroyers out of the atmosphere with your force powers. But it's awesome.The combat in this game is unfortunately not as complex, or at least the moveset not as large as you would hope for after gems like Ninja Gaiden or games like God of War. You get your standard Force powers - crush, push, pull, mind trick, lightning, and you get to develop those skills by putting points in to them by earning points and by finding Holocrons, which also lets you make some sort-of-combos. You also find saber crystals throughout the game which change your saber color and change what passive effect the saber has when used. Combat eventually gets boring as with all games that have combat, but on the bright side you get to toss Stormtroopers around like toys, or kill those walking trash can droids. Graphics, considering they are from 2008, are as good as you can expect from a console game that's 8 years old at this point. The PC port doesn't appear to have been given any special attention, though - even maxing out the graphics still shows that they used the same low-res textures for most of the game.Unfortunately, as a GFWL game, this is one of many titles that didn't get the Steamworks treatment and never will. No achievements,  no workshop, none of that. It also has a fair share of technical problems and I can't even get mine to work on Windows 10 properly, not to mention it would crash at random on Windows 7 when it had nothing to do with performance.I'm sure it's overpriced right now, so I really wouldn't recommend buying it if it's anywhere over $10.

Enemy types usually progress as follows: 1. Run-of-the-mill goon 2. Guy that strengthens run-of-the-mill goons 3. Bigger, more powerful run-of-the-mill goon with different colour scheme 4. A whole group of these bigger, more powerful run-of-the-mill goons that effectively jump on you and take turn ♥♥♥♥ing you in the♥♥♥♥♥until you die. What makes it worse is that this all-powerful sith apprentice you play as takes 10 minutes to get up after being knocked down, so when swarmed by these big groups of enemies you'll often have no chance to actually fight back. You don't actually feel like you have control of what's going on due to the bad controls and horrible game design.The only things good about this game are the lore, the character design, and some of the locales.Avoid this game if you can, you'll just end up bashing your keyboard or controller into oblivion.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												The Force Unleashed is a game where you take... hold, on, let me start over, I've already ♥♥♥♥ed this up and called it a game. The Force Unleashed is a franchise-themed BDSM simulator where you play the part of a hapless consumer who pays a monolithic giant to hold you down against the floor and violate you repeatedly.The Force Unleashed is a great example of what happens when none of the developers communicate in any way. First you have the nerdy tech people like myself who start drooling in their trousers when they think of all of the things you could do with a physics-heavy engine designed around the use of Force powers. They brought ground-breaking technology like Digital Molecular Matter, which allows materials like metal or wood to deform or shatter in dynamic, realistic ways when you do something like Force-push them or slam a stormtrooper into them, or Euphoria, an AI engine which allows those stormtroopers to reach out and grab on to nearby objects in a vain attempt to stop you from flinging them around like a screaming hackey-sack. Unfortunately, the tech people never communicated with the rest of the team, so their fancy tech doesn't really get used at all and the engine is essentially wasted. The tech people also didn't communicate with REALITY, and actually told the general public that the game would only be released on consoles because PCs weren't powerful enough to handle their physics engine. Somehow this didn't stop them from releasing the game on the Wii.Next are the level designers, who were busy constructing their linear set pieces. Apparently they were too caught up trying to make outdoor environments feel like narrow hallways to speak with the tech team, and didn't even find out about the fancy Digital Molecular Matter system until just before release, the result being that there is about one conspicuously-placed object that actually uses the system in each level. We can also see that the level designers didn't actually watch the films, because in The Force Unleashed the Death Star consists entirely of an interlocking grid of gigantic hangar bays.The gameplay designers were apparently never told that they were working on a Star Wars property at all, and so they worked from the offset under the model that every enemy should have exactly one weakness, and that each enemy should have a different weakness, apparently not knowing that your character is always holding a ♥♥♥♥ING LIGHTSABER.Let's look at this lightsaber issue further. One of the core game design problems faced by every team designing a Star Wars game that includes lightsabers is that the lightsaber quite obviously should be a one-hit kill weapon, but unlimited-use one-hit kill weapons don't usually make for the best game design. Therefore, the designers always have to find some way not to let lightsabers effortlessly carve through all opposition, either by encouraging ranged combat or by limiting the damage of lightsabers for gameplay purposes. TFU, however, is set between the three Star Wars films and George Lucas's parody prequels; we see claerly in the films that no one has lightsaber-proof armor. In TFU, every later enemy has a sword or shield or armor that is completely 100% lightsaber-proof. In TFU the only difference between a lightsaber and a pointy stick is that a stick doesn't require batteries. Well, I suppose there is also the fact that a lightsaber never gets dull; I wish I could say the same of the gameplay.It's ironic that in a game where it seems that 100% of the effort went into graphics and gameplay, the gameplay is really quite terrible. As previously mentioned, the lightsaber is really quite useless and you are only able to kill enemies with Force powers. While this doesn't sound bad on paper, in reality each enemy is only weak to exactly one thing, and so for the most part combat alternates between guessing which power is going to kill a new type of enemy, and long sections of fighting that same type of enemy over and over and over in the same exact way. Wait a minute, I thought this game was supposed to encourage creativity? The only enemies you are given true freedom against are the hapless standard stormtroopers, who fart their blasters ineffectually at you until you go barelling through them or pick them up with Force grip and bash them around a bit. Since the basic stormtrooper is the only opportunity you have to really have fun with grip and push, they are actually given quite a lot of durability, so you can sadistically bash them back and forth between two walls like a future serial killer swinging a squirrel between two trees by the tail. This is fun at first, but if you aren't actually a future serial killer, after a while you actually start to feel bad for the poor stormtrooper who was just doing his job until you decided to smack him around like an unwanted baby at a post-delivery abortion clinic.Of course, making you scream in rage at all of the enemies who are immune to ♥♥♥♥ING LIGHTSABERS wasn't sufficiently sadistic for these developers. As the game goes on, you start running into more and more enemies whose primary weapon is a homing blast that knocks you over, and whose rate of fire is exactly equal to the amount of time it takes you to stand back up. By the Death Star, when you are fighting gigantic killer robots and stormtroopers with cloaking devices who all somehow disappeared from the Empire's arsenal before A New Hope, you will be facing thirty enemies at once who all have a homing missile that knocks you down for exactly the length of time it takes to fire another homing missile, and you'll start to feel like the cheerleader who told the entire football team to have their way with her at once. The game turns into a screaming ragefest of dodging around endless hanger bays killing a single stormtrooper every thirty seconds when you happen to have the luck to land directly behind him between jumps, until by the end of the nightmarish ordeal you are a heavy drinker and need 5 years of therapy.If you aren't convinced that the "game" design is balanced around sado-masochism, consider this: if you die, you retain any experience and abilities that you gained before you died, despite being taken to the last checkpoint. The game is actually designed so you can grind through the torturous end sequences by dying over and over.When the developers realized that gaming PCs are in fact much more powerful than an XBox 360, they released a 30-gigabyte version of TFU for Windows. If you happen to like to customize your games and are fool enough to change any of your keyboard controls, you will be enraged at the boss-fights (which consist entirely of quick-time button sequences like some strange combat-themed DDR) because the keys they tell you to press on-screen are the original keys, not whatever you rebound your controls to. Maybe the screen is telling you to press WQAD and you actually have to press EWSF. I emailed the company about this and they actually told me the onscreen controls were all hardcoded and to consider using the default controls. Well, you gigantic♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ if you didn't actually want me to be able to change my controls, you could have done the sensible thing and not let me change my ♥♥♥♥ing controls. Instead, each boss fight for me became a repetetive pattern of reaching a quick-time button sequence, writing down what keys it said to press, translating those keys to my actual controls, memorizing what I really needed to press, and then beating that sequence and making it to the next sequence to start all over again. Wait a minute, does that sound familiar? Now I'm just studying for a test. If I wanted to study for a ♥♥♥♥ing test, I'd be at school instead of trying to squeeze two seconds of fun out of your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ video game.The only saving grace for The Force Unleashed is that it is only a few hours long and thus won't waste as much of your life as the prequels did

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												TLDR: glitches make you get stuck in the floor and environment, forcing a game restart, force powers are often unresponsive, camera is erratic, combat is frustratingly bad, constant knock downs that use ragdoll physics to keep you down for a long time, and poorly implemented boss fights, some of the worst I have ever seen. These are just a few of this games problems that bury it far into the dirt.One of the worst games there is on steam and one of the worst games I have ever played period. The only reason to bother with it is for the story and with the cutscenes being available on youtube there is no reason to buy this terrible game. Bad gameplay aside, I wasn't able to finish it because of its numerous technical issues. On the last level you fight 4 waves of elite soldiers. 1 wave would have been plenty, but for some reason at this point they decide to flood you with them. It is one of the worst stages I have ever seen in any game because as soon as it starts you get knocked down over and over again. Most of the time there is no way to even dodge it because there are about 4 different types of enemies firing at you from all heights and angles that all have knock down shots so you stay on your back most of the time. You can't stop and fight because the second you do you go into a knock down loop and are lucky to get out of it. The knockdown in this game is particularly bad because it takes its time letting the ragdoll physics take over and ragdoll you around on the floor until your guy does a Shawn Michaels hand-spring back to his feet which is also very slow.So since I couldn't do this part without dying from staying on knock down lock down, I lowered the difficulty to easy so I could take less dmg and just get the game over with. Since about half way through the game I had started to rush and just try to get this mess over with. I lost any urge I had to keep looking for skill point cubes and just went into hurry mode long before even the last level. So with the bad guys gone on this level, you have to use force pull and open some grates to jump down into a lower area. The problem here, like many other parts in the game, is that the force powers don't always respond right. So I couldn't open the grates and started jumping around. I got completely glitch stuck in a part of the floor that was raised a little and had to exit to the main menu and select continue game. It started me back at the beginning of the level so i would have had to defeat those 4 waves again. I just alt+f4'ed right the ♥♥♥♥ out and uninstalled this immediately. It wasn't the first time I had gotten stuck in the game in a place where I should'nt be able to but did because their quality testing on this game was non-existent. This was just the final straw.About 3/4 through the game the sound also started messing up. I came out of a cutscene and only half of the sound effects were working. I restarted the game and it fixed it but on the next level it started it again so I just played until the last level like that because at this point the game was just so bad that I didn't care.The boss fights are also some of the worst boss fights I have ever seen. This is I assume supposed to be a casual game for any and all Star Wars fans but the only ones who are going to be able to beat most of the bosses are people with a♥♥♥♥♥♥load of skill and patience. Any casual gamer or kid playing this has no chance of beating most bosses unless maybe they put it on easy. The boss fights were poorly conceived and even more poorly implemented.I could go on, but this game isn't worth another thought. I recently bought both games on sale for $6 each and this was a complete waste of money. I am just hoping that Force Unleashed 2 is better than this awful waste of time and money.0/10 because of game breaking glitches, sickeningly bad boss fights, and overall poor gameplay in every area.

content:
Posted: February 20
Force Unleased ReviewMy hours logged for this game are not accurate. I played the game offline while I was on vacation. I originally played it on the PS2.OverviewThe game itself is a fairly solid and fun game... with a little bit of repetition in the gameplay and levels... you can expect to see most of the enemies you will encounter within a couple levels and encounter various types of them throughout the game as it escalates. The PC release of the game has some issues... some that specifically I will go further into detail later in this review.StoryThe story is the best part of the game. If you can deal with all of the PC issues of this port and you are a Star Wars fan then the story is definitely one worth getting through. You play as a secret apprentice to Darth Vader and it has some nice tie ins to the original movies... It takes place inbetween episodes 3 and 4 respectively. This edition also contains several other add ons to the original and while fun and some cool levels they felt tacked on to the story and unessential.GameplayThe gameplay is pretty fun and from the first level (which I will not spoil for you but has a very cool playable character) where you really see what kind of power you will harness in the game to the later levels where you are a finely tuned killing machine is fast and rewarding. I played through on the hardest difficulty setting which I would not recommend... It is not well balanced and some parts are almost entirely reliant on luck... although playing on the normal difficult level after felt like a breeze in comparison. This is a game that you are supposed to feel like a bad♥♥♥♥♥and it really keeps upping the ante with the abilities you gain access to in an RPG style of progression that rewards you for exploring and playing well.Graphics and AudioThe graphics while dated are not terrible but are plagued with some issues I will go into detail. Overall the cutscenes are pretty good though. Like I said previously there are some audio and visual glitches in the game when it was ported. The audio cuts out partially in the last two levels (and also in earlier levels for some dialogue in my experience). These nearly ruined the experience for me as it was very removing from the game which at first I was really enjoying and I got caught up in trying to remedy this. There is a slight patch someone made (unnofficial) on the steam forums but it may or may not work correctly. I still experienced some slight problems and was never able to repair some visual glitch that happens almost every time I use force push (which is fairly often) Also occasionally I would find my character caught on invisible objects or have enemies spawn in randomly out of nowhere due to me clipping into an area where I was not supposed to be for a battle and I am unable to view the enemies nor navigate to them to kill them and thus wind up being killed by blaster fire from an invisible enemy. ConclusionI cannot recommend the PC version of the game to anyone who can get the console version. The Devs have all but abandoned this at this point and there is no hope of the problems that are hurting this otherwise decent game of being fixed at any point. While it is a fun game and I enjoyed playing it there are many better games out there today. If you are a big fan of Star Wars than by all means pick it up but do so  with caution and you may want to consider waiting until it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												I realize this game is kind of old now but I really have to say, THIS IS A HORRIBLE GAME! The lack of control while in combat is atrocious. I can't aim and even when surrounded by enemies, frequently attacks will "miss" even if force attacks like lightning are literally surrounding them. Since you aren't totally in control of aiming, targeting objects and enemies can be rather ineffective and ruins the whole purpose of having awesome force powers. There is a loading screen every time you view an option or abilities screen, and when you go back even if you aren't changing anything. Also if you are in the middle of an attack or if your enemy in attacking you or you are getting up from being knocked down and also sometimes while in the air, control is taken from you and you can't move or attack. This leaves you open to getting killed quickly even from full health in a few seconds. Example: You get knocked down and as you get up, you can't move, before control is given back to you allowing you to dodge, you are knocked down again, and again until you are dead and you have no chance to move or defend yourself, and if you do, the attack might miss or go through your enemy anyways and you get knocked down. I don't even feel like I am even playing most of the time. And the there are the issues of poorly programed platforms you are supposed to stand on and the game decides your character can't stand on the bridge you need to use to go forwards and you slide of to your death making you have to do the whole area again. This is such an insanely awful game. The story isn't even all that great, in my opinion, either and I love Star Wars. The second game was much better, I finished that one. The story still kinda sucked though and some of the voice acting is not that great, especially general kota. It will sound like he is asking a question when making a statement. I am glad this came in a bundle of other games I much enjoy or I would be upset I paid for this.

												If you're a fan of being stun-locked and killed off by normal enemies, these enemies often spawned by bosses to make your day terrible, then this is the game for you.If you're a fan of having less than 10 unique enemies to fight in the entire game, then this is the game for you.If you're a fan of bottomless pits that can set you back several minutes of progress time each, then this is the game for you.If you're a fan of QTEs for every boss fight and "strong enemy" as a requirement for them to die at all, then this is the game for you.If you're a fan of wonky physics magic, then this is the game for you.If you're a fan of shallow RPG mechanics and grinding, then this is the game for you.If you're a fan of awful voice acting and writing, then this is the game for you.If you're a fan of Peter Molyneux's idea of the player's actions influencing the story, then this is the game for you.If you're a fan of soundtracks made up of like three different songs, then this is the game for you.If you want to play a good game then... well, honestly ♥♥♥♥ off, what are you doing here looking at something from Star Wars?People say this game is vastly inferior to the sequel, I say those people are stupid, it's clearly the same game.
