number of helpful: 2 of 21 people (10%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 9
												Easily among the Worst Games I Have Ever Played. Yes, I meant to capitalize that. It's not a terrible game in the sense that some old beat 'em up you like is a terrible game, but it's fun in a mindless, nostalgic kind of a way. No. This is just a HORRIBLE game. The opening crawl is unskippable, a flashing silhouette of the game's unspeakably charmless protagonist reminding you to be patient as you watch a three-sentence lead-in fade into nothingness. But your journey is only beginning, young padawan. You'll then take control of Lord Vader, arriving on Chewbacca's homeworld of Kashyyk to kill a "Rogue Jedi," whatever the frig that is. Vader stalks through the forest planet at an absolutely mercilessly slow trudge (no, you can't sprint), blasting force pushes that knock down literally everything into terrible, splintering masses of pre-realist-destruction, or slashing through the exact same model of Wookie (Wookiee? Wooky? Am I even a person anymore?), over and over again, until your eyes melt out of your head and chastize you for using them in such an unclean manner. And I won't lie - there's something that gets very "No Russian"-y about mowing down innocent creatures that have literally no chance of stopping you, made all the more surreally disturbing by the fact that it's the same model, making the same dying animal sound effects. When you reach your quarry - a miserable, scrunched-up octogenarian spouting off "the force has corrupted your mind" cliches like they're going out of frigging fashion - the "boss fight" is literally just force throwing him at absolutely ludicrious distances and velocities, then waiting a few seconds until the old turd dusts himself off so you can do it again. Rinse and repeat several hundred times until you've knocked his health bar to a squinch and you get a prize! Nope, not a gun materializing from your screen and blowing your brains out for being so dreadfully stupid as to sit through that, but A QUICKTIME EVENT! Once you've "Pressed E to Run the Old♥♥♥♥♥♥Through," you stumble across the last thing you expected to find in Star Wars: a young innocent that Darth Vader senses that the Force is strong in! How the 80-year-old man you just piledrived through Kashyyk City Hall sired a child on an alien planet with no females in sight is beyond me, but then again, so is how dozens of people got paid to make this steaming pile of what I can only assume are the liposuctioned remnants of George Lucas' neck fat. A few dreary cutscenes later and you get some semblance of a tutorial, narrated by a robot assistant that, by its own cheery admission, is programmed to kill you (no follow up to the threat of death by the droid, incidentally). After another mercifully brief and utterly confusing cutscene where you're introduced in earnest to Vader's moody protege-and-I-guess-step-son, "Starkiller," his spaceship's pilot, "Hot Australian Girl," and a rebel commander-or-maybe-Jedi-or-who-cares, you arrive on a bigger spaceship to - not even joking - kill a rogue Jedi. How rogue he has gone, I don't know, because when you show up there, everybody is shooting everybody, including you. Yes, Stormtroopers and "Militia" alike, further clouding the murky narrative you just spent between $3 and $50 on. But hey! At least you're in control of the protagonist, and more importantly, you can run (even if it is actually just a dash move that you have to keep jabbing at the key for until your finger considers launching an armed insurrection). And run you shall - through the boring, console-optimized landscape of low-poly environments and splotchy textures and the same three models of enemies. Fortunately, there are loading icons every few yards to punctuate the inanity of your experience and remind you you're not actually stuck in a time loop, flickering in and out almost imperceptibly as a horribly engineered game tries to cope with the fact that a system might be able to accommodate more than a few hundred linear feet of lifeless, repetitive environments. Combat is awful - take everything you've grown to love about titles like "Arkham Asylum" and then forget it. This game drinks the tears of games with good combat, lavishing in them like a Thomas Harris serial killer and dancing nude to an 80s synth pop song while you huddle, terrified and apalled in the corner, rocking back and forth wondering what went wrong that lead you to this point. "I should've listened to my parents," you'll think as you press the slash key to slash, over and over again. Get bored of slashing and want to run ahead? Nope, the genius developers have thought of that with an old trick from 1993 called "invisible walls." You can also force-throw things in an attempt to break up the monotony, but whatever eye♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥they hired to design these environments apparently snorted so much meth that they made literally everything throwable, so more often then not you're throwing one of the forty-six throwable objects on screen you DIDN'T mean to throw. Oh, and the selection is camera-agnostic - meaning that you'll have to align your character's bearing, not the camera's, to select the thing. But all of this has a silver lining - I got so fed up of looking for whatever object I was supposed to force-throw to complete a *cough* "puzzle" that I ended up quitting the game, uninstalling it, and vowing to really rethink my life choices. Which I will get to just as soon as I wrap my head around how an army of infuriated nerds hasn't found Haden Blackman and bludgeoned him to death with their limited edition copies of this game.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												A great game. Force Unleashed takes place between episodes III and IV, following Vader's secret apprentice, "Starkiller."Having played this game on the PSP, I was dissapointed by the console version. The PS3/360 version of the game had many parts cut out, severly shortening the game. So far as I can tell, the content in the PC and PSP versions is roughly the same.The only issue I have encountered so far is distant objects and the environmental backdrop. Distant object simply do not appear, making it difficult to prepare for large fights or see where you're going. The environmental backdrop looks like a shmere of color, fanning out in a strange pattern any time something passes- such as a star fighter or debris falling from the sky. While this issues cause some minor difficulty, the game still runs perfectly fine, meaning only some of the visuals are effected.Bonus campaigns, skins, abilities, and lightsabers are also available. Even with the visually unappealing graphics bugs, this game is still worth a play!Edit: This game just lost some major points with me because 1) there are still parts of the game missing- the PSP version has much more content- and 2) the Star Destroyer scene- everyone who has played knows how *****ing impossible that can seem- is pretty much unbeatable if you have the same graphics glitch I do. I litterally cannot see the Tie fighters as they fly in, and the Star Destroyer is marked only by three large glowing exhauses from its engines. Now, in the PSP version I can pull this thing down in no time because I CAN SEE IT. Here, I have no clue what the angle of the ship is, so I can't make the proper adjustments, and we all know who faulty the on-screen button display is.8.5/10 for PSP6/10 for PC because of graphics issues

												Hmm. Well now this is a tricky one. On the one hand, the combat is refreshing and well played but its also annoying, and if you press the wrong button you can't cancel it. The enemies are interesting and well placed and paced, but their attacks are not so. Sith Master difficulty especially, purge troopers, jumprtoopers and the snipers will just mess you up. Bosses... Bosses are varied, Kazdan Paratus easily being the most difficult of the game, if you include DLC then it's probably Luke SKywalker. Shaak Ti is ridiculously easy. Also the story - praised, and rightly so. Gets a bit broing as you cant skip most cutscenes, which can be annoying, but otherwise well-executed, well made and very interesting crated as the bridge between 3 and 4. In conclusion, despite some MASSIVE graphical errors and sound desyncing, some annoying and frustrating moments and overall shoddy block system... I suggest you get this gameCOMPLETONISTS NOTE: how much do you like stress? completing this game 100% on sith master hurts a lot, but explot the ai a little and have good twitch refleexes and you should be fine :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Star Wars the Force Unleashed is the ultimate Star Wars Game. I'm sure that at some point during a Star Wars game we've all said to ourselves "Why the ♥♥♥♥ can't I just throw this guy off the edge of a cliff with the force?", well, now you can ACTUALLY DO THAT.This game lets you use all the force goodies from the movies, plus a couple new ones, such as creating a force shockwave and imbuing your lightsaber with sith lightning.The combat is fast paced and dodge-oriented. You get health for killing any enemy, but be careful; on higher difficulties you can be torn asunder by blaster fire very quickly.From a story standpoint, this is a game that takes place during the "Dark Times", the period between episodes III and IV where the last of the jedi were being hunted down, and the Rebel Alliance hadn't been formed. The game takes you through the deaths of most of the remaining jedi, and shows the origins of the Rebel Alliance, as well as Vader's plan to overthrow Emperor Palpatine (supporting his actions in Episode VI).

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												6/10This feels and plays like a reskinned Dynasty Warriors with a few new mechanics added. The lightsaber use and combo is reminiscent of the aforementioned games, but there's a few new bits that are truly great. I personally love this game, because I enjoy crushing storm troopers against the wall, or smashing the airlock and watching rebels get sucked out. It is, however, incredibly repetitive, and the novelty gets old. I pushed through the glitchy physics, the ugly levels and the poor performance because the AI was very responsive and fun to destroy, and the force powers were just fun to use. The levels are very linear, however, and the port is very poor. The camera controls poorly, and the control scheme is terrible (but if you change it, the QTE prompts don't change). Overall, it felt like a quick cash-in (even though it wasn't), but was still enjoyable FOR ME, because I love this crap. Not everyone does.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												I don't quite get the hate for this game. As Star Wars fan fiction goes, it's a superbly written interlude between episodes 3 and 4. That being said, jarring narrative jumps and several characters that get severely short-handed smack of forced cuts due to a rushed development schedule. Interestingly enough, the bonus missions that branch off from the dark (and I mean seriously ♥♥♥♥ing dark) ending are some of the best parts of TFU. Gameplay is serviceable, although the boss fights are a glitchy mess. Definitely play on easy to enjoy this one, or face getting stun-locked every three seconds and having to fight a Jedi while the camera is busy admiring the scenery over in the opposite corner. Highlights: Bringing down a star destroyer with your bare hands (yap), exploring the gooey insides of a Sarlaac and giving Darth Vader a fierce wedgie. Three out of five poorly held lightsabers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Finally finished this little gem of a game which I put off playing for sooooo long.First of It has some issues, but nothing really game breaking (for me anyway). I loaded this up set it to full hd 1080p graphics are all set to the max, xbox 360 controller supported sat back and played away like a good little Jedi. The game ran perfectly with no major issues at all nothing game breaking, maybe a few random bad bits of level design but nothing that can't be avoided in the first place. The combat was good, a little stiff and sometimes sluggish especially when standing back up after being knocked down and then getting knocked down straight away and to have that repeat 3 or 4 times is very annoying, but not game breaking.I had an issue on the last level of the game where my sound was missing i could hear slight lightsabre effects but everything else was missing, but this was cured when i downloaded the fixed files from the forum and took seconds to do and was easy to do.The game itself is alright nothing spectacular it reminded me of Devil May Cry meets Star Wars, its a lot of hack and slash but with force powers and cool lightsabres. You dont use any pistols or ranged weapons other than force powers and throwing of the lightsabre, so dont expect to use rifles etc because you cant. There is a basic but effective leveling up system for your character and the force powers, you can also collect crystals for your sabre to change colour and to add perks to your weapon. These can be found through the levels and by completing various challenged throughout the game.The game can be frustrating and sometimes lacks proper intruction but nothing major i found and completed all objectives/side missions and enjoyed doing so. One thing I would recommend is that you take breaks when playing this game i spanned it over 3 nights playing for a couple of hours at a time. I did that because its repetetive the same enemies over and over some with added powers/abilities and the odd mini boss before the inevitable end level boss.That brings me onto the next point i had, Bosses, they didnt seem very tough at all, in fact i found the mini-boss battles with the AT-ST and others that wont be mentioned were a lot tougher at points during the game. The bosses seemed to be over in a few minutes and a lot of them were defeated the exact same way as the previous one but because they were so short i wasnt too fussed.Now the music, the music. What can i say we all know what the Soundtrack to anything Star Wars is gonna sound like and this game does not fail in providing us with the well known star wars classics. They really do make the game feel more epic than it actually is, i was enjoying my lightsabre massacre with the epic star was soundtrack playing in tempo to the slaying of many, many clone troopers. I would say the soundtrack alone made me enjoy this game more than i should of.Graphics - I was running it in 1080p as stated earlier with everything set the to max. It ran perfectly not graphical issues at all it looks quite nice for an old'ish game. The only issue i had was the terrible camera angles in various parts of the game but once again not game breaking.Overall -  There is little in the way of storyline to keep you going it was ok the cutscenes were great, music spot on, graphics were good for the age of the game, QTE was a little annoying with little time to react to some. The only issue i had was with the sound glitching out on the last level but i fixed that so overall i give this game  7/10, could be better but could also be a lot worse, if you are a Star Wars fan and you also like Devil May Cry hack and slash action then this might be the game for you, just dont expect next gen gaming physics or graphics, but what you do get is a few hours of fun.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Why did they not continue this franchise with a new installment every year?!  This game has good graphics for the release date: 2010.  The controls are tight but at times a little slow to respond.  It's a great hack and slash style game with plenty of force powers.  I wish the boss fights could be a little more in depth and complex. The only bad part in the whole game is when you have to use the force power to bring down a battle cruiser.  Youtube that part because the gameplay of that fight seems a little glitchy and it is easier to beat if don't follow their instructions for that particular fight.  They really should have continued this franchise with an installment every year.  The second game in the series improved much upon this one.  Had the series continued it would have been truely amazing by now.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												First off I'm a star wars nut. love the lore and the movies etc yadayada...I for one love this game for what it is. You play as Vader's secret apprentice and live by far one of the ♥♥♥♥♥iest lives in the galaxy. I wont go into any details for spoiler reasons. I will say I do love the story because of how snugly it fits within the canon of the universe, aside from never being mentioned Starkiller and his adventure could easily be part of the offical lore of the setting.Now onto the game itself.First off this is clearly a port from the console, it feels WRONG on a keyboard and probably for that reason, fortunately if you have a controller you'll be right at home. Being a port (and a fairly lazy one at that) it's got it's share of odd bugs, fortunately none of them are too horrifying, aside from some noticable pop in on the larger more busy worlds and some textures you won't have alot of visual problems. But you will notice the occasional physics bug where a person suddenly goes mach 2 in any given direction.Speaking of physics the havok engine is used for maximum lulz here. it's WAY too easy to just pick up like a trash can and knock everyone over, the second you touch them they go ragdoll and collapse and act llike they've forgotten how their body works its pretty entertaining. That being said it obviously makes your force powers seem ridiculous in comparison, take that and the fact that more than half the time your enemies will be utterly helpless against the power of the force and you can really feel like a tiny god at times.All in all a fun game but it's fairly dated at this point and as I said before a is a lousy port. still pretty fun

												Fear = AngerAnger = HateHate = SufferingFear = The Path to the Dark SideGotta find myself something to Fear then!!It's a really good story for all SW fans, though i'm only part way through the game. my only complaint is that the controls/combat doesn't seem as fluid as it should be to allow for proper utilization of all the mechanics the game has to offer. it's hard to feel like a hardcore force wielder kicking butt in the middle of a fight when i'm having a hard time getting the character to throw the right item at the right object/enemy. having to stop to aim and fire force held objects takes time that interupts the flow of potentially awesome combat. this all seems fleshed out by the sequal to a much greater extent, though.The camera work is mildly tricky.The voice over work is usually well done.In the end it may seem like i'm not enjoying the game, but i am. i most definitely love the dark side of the force

Posted: August 27, 2015
												I played this game on my Wii when I was younger and it seemed much more fun back then. Nevertheless, I find the game to  be flawed in only a few ways.Flaws: The controls to PC have been ported horrifically and the menus are difficult to navigate because of this. There are also a few sound and texture glitches with Juno (the character's Orthopox 13 if you will) when she's trying to give you instructions. Sometimes when she says something, the audio doesn't kick in and you can only know that she's talking if you have subtitles turned on.Other than those few unpleasantries, this is a very enjoyable Star Wars game that is lore-friendly and loads of fun if you've ever wanted to be an all powerful Sith Lord.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												It's nice, i've already played the game enough times on console, obviously the issues of this game range from the narrative, to the gameplay, to even the freaking sense that the story may or may not add to the canon, it's all in good faith tho, the main thing, and the main complaint that a lot of pc gamers are having, is that this pc version it's quite bad, it's not as horrible as say something like Arkham Knight, but it's pretty bad, luckily, fixable.The first problem it's that there's a framerate limit at 30fps, you can disable this by downloading a patch for the game in pcgamingwiki.The second problem were some visual glitches that were frankly, annoying. I solve this by editing the config file and enabling clothe psysics, also something that you can do by following the instructions from pcgaming wiki.And finally, apparently there were some levels that were missing sounds, and even music, i manage to fix this by downloading another patch for the game also on pcgamingwiki.The point that im trying to make, besides the fact that you can find basically every fix on the internet, it's that the game definitley needs some work done, and it's a damn shame because im sure plenty of people won't even realize about this fixes until they have refunded the game, or just get sick of the issues, at the moment i haven't experience any crashes whatsoever, and after every fix the only problem i encountered it's the 30fps affects the cutscenes and there doesn't seem to be a fix for it, but whatever, im pleased with the actual game running at 60fps, and it looks great, i definitley recommend it, if you can get it on a sale, and if you can bare the ten minutes that it will take you to fix the issues that developers should have already fix in the first place.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Excellent game!  Ive heard many of the bad reviews have been stemming from people who are playing this on a keyboard.  You are a tool if you do that.  This game is meant to be played with a controller and always has been.  Now onto the game.  Its a full-on action game that does HUGE justice to how powerful the force actually is.  You are given numerious ways to eliminate your enemies via hack n slashing or using force powers/objects in the environment.  It has a light RPG system for you to upgrade your character.  I like the that you can also learn new combos to add in the mix.  You are tasked with hunting down the remaining jedi spread across the galaxy.  This leads to the game taking you to varied locations throughout the universe.  For example the games 1st level is a TIE Fighter factory which is pretty sick and then you travel to a world that is used as a trash can.  A junkyard world if you will.  The only knock I would say is that the targeting system is a little off and controls take a bit to get used to but when you do; you will feel like a god.  Runs silky smooth on Windows 7 x64.

Posted: December 31, 2015
												DO NOT BUY THIS! The force unleashed is a great game, probably my favorite star wars game, but oh god... The PC port is AWFUL. Cons-Skybox has been removed, so not rather than clouds and stars, you get black hall of mirrors that overlaps everything on the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ screen.-30 FPS cap. I have a not so good computer, but i can run older games pretty well, and when i look directly at the ground to avoid looking at the sky long enough to see my real FPS, I can only get 30. Although i know i could cap off around 50 or so.-Controlles. "Oh, you thought you were navagating menus like a normal game? no no no, use the arrow keys, and press enter to select, and it only works sometimes. And thats assuming the menu options even load!"I cannot stress enough that you should go get a ps2 and play this, but not on PC. The game is only 5.99 right now but i feel like i should be paid for downloading it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Having made it to the end I really cannot recommend this game at all.I have read that a lot of people gave up before the third level - which is understandable - but if you continue on there is actually some game to enjoy.You get used to the controls after a while and work out how the force powers work to actually enjoy using them, but it is overall ruined by insanely badly done boss fights the like of which I don't think I have seen in over 30 years of gaming.The developers seemed to hate the player and while bestowing them with playable sections they had to punish them with the bosses.I rarely need youtube videos to help me play games but I looked up nearly every fight as it was so tedious to try to work out what you were doing wrong.And having seen how to do it they then rarely presented a challenge as it was just spamming their weakness until they died.Ignorance of game mechanics when you haven't been taught is no great weakness on the players part it is the failure of the designers.I also - which I never do - looked to see if there was an infinite health cheat just to be able to play the game without the tedium of dying and starting again.  Sadly there wasn't and I consider having even looked really bad.I got it in a bundle and if you can then try it but don't expect too much.  Definitely don't buy it even on sale.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												I don't quite get the hate for this game. As Star Wars fan fiction goes, it's a superbly written interlude between episodes 3 and 4. That being said, jarring narrative jumps and several characters that get severely short-handed smack of forced cuts due to a rushed development schedule. Interestingly enough, the bonus missions that branch off from the dark (and I mean seriously ♥♥♥♥ing dark) ending are some of the best parts of TFU. Gameplay is serviceable, although the boss fights are a glitchy mess. Definitely play on easy to enjoy this one, or face getting stun-locked every three seconds and having to fight a Jedi while the camera is busy admiring the scenery over in the opposite corner. Highlights: Bringing down a star destroyer with your bare hands (yap), exploring the gooey insides of a Sarlaac and giving Darth Vader a fierce wedgie. Three out of five poorly held lightsabers.

												Bad console port of an amazing game and contrary to what is said this game does have controller support for Xbox360 controllers.-The camera is awkward and the aiming of force powers and lock-on is awful, but it was for console and this game is around 8 years old so what do you expect.-The graphic options are preset so you can't mess about with resolution so prepare to deal with old graphics.-There is no actual in-game tutorial, you simply learn as you go through on screen pop ups when you acquire new skills.-Although when you load the game up it asks what resolution you want to play in, it lies and you can't really change it.-The plot is amazing-Using force powers is awesome-Being able to combo enemies with a lightsaber that you can upgrade is brilliant-The environments are varied-The enemies are varied and can be challenging when first encountered but when you learn thier move set they're not                      too bad to take down, however when you're outnumbered by 5 enemy types trying to take them down is still a real challenge.# It's a million times better than "The Force Unleashed 2" which plays like a fricken DLC to this game.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												This title's plagued by the obvious flaw of a Star Wars game in the Rise of the Empire Era. It's got retcons like no other game I've seen, other than SR4. The core gameplay is good. Jump into the air, slam into the ground and take out a squad of Stormtroopers. BUT there are parts that are plagued by awful, awful. AWFUL design choices. Like the bit where you have to bring down a Star Destroyer? Not possible, even on the lowest difficulty. NONE of your force powers have any effect on the TIE fighters. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
TL;DR: over-the-top force powers do not save a lackluster story and poor level designIt’s called the Force Unleashed because you’ll get to use force powers in full overdrive. That means force blasts that push entire armies over cliffs, lightning that electrifies everything, and super high force jumps. The pinnacle of the game is crashing down a Star Destroyer into a planet using nothing but the force.  If this is enough to win you over, you will definitely have a blast playing this game. The force’s not the only thing unleashed though: the illogical over-the-top story and level and gameplay design are all over the place.The story’s decent, you hunt down hidden Jedi as Darth Vader’s assassin. It’s a pretty dark story, with a predictable redemption arc. Most Star Wars games offer you a light and a dark choice, here confined to a single choice as to which final boss you fight. It would have been much more interesting if the story had followed the dark route, evidenced by 2/3 of the 3 DLC (included in this edition) following the alternative dark ending.The biggest problem is the ambivalent nature of the game. There’s some dark nightmarish stuff, definitely unsuited for younger players. You get to kill legions of enemies, but to keep the age rating in check there’s no blood or dismemberment:  the gameplay is a tame, almost cartoony version of God of War, which contrast heavily with the dark story.While all the levels are good looking, they’re plagued by some odd design issues. You’ll repeatedly fall, jump, or get pushed to your death in one of the game’s many abysses, sending you back to the last save point, forcing you to replay part of the level. Often irritating, especially in connection with the unskippable CGI scenes. The many legions of enemies are too easily defeated, the only challenges posed by the game’s Jedi bosses. Those boss fights are generally fun, but all come down to using the same tactics, and are often plagued by a second adversary: the camera.In short, it’s fun to play around with the force powers and to fight iconic bosses, but the gameplay and level design are not good enough to make you want to come back for more.There’s far better games out there where you can play with the force, the Jedi Knight series chief among them. 6/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Star Wars - The Force Unleashed: PLayed through from 4/29/2015 - 5/3/2015Star Wars - The Force Unleashed is a capable hack and slash romp through the Star Wars Universe. The story is told picking up from the end of Episode III and fills in some of the abyssmal gap between the prequel trilogy and the original trilogy. Some fair plot twists and some darn good storytelling make this a game worth playing for any Star Wars fan. There are several familiar character cameos and some nice subtle tie in's from both trilogies. All of the characters are very well voice acted and the story elements provided me with the majority of the incentive to get through the title. Light Saber combat is fluid and fun against most of the weaker to medium foes. However, the larger enemies and boss encounters end up being an excersize in discovery and repetition. That is, you find the bosses weakness and continually exploit it until victory is achieved. I found myself spamming force lighting for most of the game to this effect.The control scheme did not translate well to the mouse and keyboard. I would recommend a gamepad for this title. Either a 360 or PD3 controller should do the trick. Force Grip and throw seemed to be fairly useless for the most part as my inteded throw destination was often overwritten by a completely random direction. Similarly, in the boss fights the camera postioning becomes fixed and I often found myself tossing lightning around the arena rather than at my enemy.Some simple custimization options let the player make small changes in the protagonists appearance which is a nice touch. In the end I would give Star Wars - The Force Unleashed a 6/10 for a casual non-star wars fan for the poor combat dynamics in the boss fights. I would award it with an 8/10 for a Star Wars Fan for a spectacular universe expanding story and tie in with some serviceable lightsaber combat.

												Amazing game! Has an awesome story that fits right in with the existing one for the main Star Wars series. It is extremly fun with awesome visuals and very well choreographed cut scense. You trully feel like a Jedi/Sith Lord while fighting against hoards of enemies.HOWEVER: This game was not ported over very well for the PC. I HIGHLY recommend using a contoller with this game. Even then I feel that Lucas Arts know how to make an amazing story with epic fight scenes and doesn't know how to make a decent platformer, as climbing and jumping from platforms is very frustraiting. Fortunetly the main game will not ask you to do that very often, it is only when searching for collectables that this becomes a real problem. Another issue is that boss battles can be frustraiting and tedius, with almost all of your attacks being blocked and bosses using unblockable moves. However even with these frustrating moments I still had a a lot of fun in this game.Overall, if you're a Star Wars fan you should love this game! And even if you're not this is still a very fun/awesome game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												The Bad: Medicore, frequently repetitive gameplay with often unresponsive controls and a very cool Force throwing system with utterly impenetrable aiming mechanics (At best, you can move the object/individual you're trying to throw vaguely in the direction you intend it to go in, and hope that it lands somewhere in the vicinity. More often than not it just drops straight down, or goes flying in a completely different direction...I'm still not sure why.)Occasionally hairpullingly frustrating when there are massed ranged troops, some of whom have weapons that can stun you or knock you back, leading to instances where you get chain stunned and take an enormous amount of damage with little to nothing you can do about it. I'm assuming that in these instances you're supposed to use your incredible Force powers to hurl some of the random debris that sits around every environment in the game into the groups of your enemies but the aformentioned uncontrollable aiming system makes trying to hit anything that you're not locked onto an exercise in futility, so the debris mostly gets in the way (you can also Force-grab enemies, but in some areas the debris is so thick that half the time Starkiller ended up grabbing random detritus and violently throwing it out of the way of his foes like some sort of telekinetic custodian clearing away trash in mortal fear of a personal injury lawsuit) so you're reduced to wading into the thick of your foes as best you can, Force-dashing along the way to avoid the stream of rockets, electric rounds, etc. that are being shot at you, and then flailing about with your lightsaber.There are a number of simple combos that you can use in combat, but after about halfway through the game most of the enemies have shields that block your Force powers until you do enough damage to them, at which point they're almost dead anyway, so in practice you wind up spamming attack a lot.Now and again you'll come across a larger enemy (Rancor, AT-ST, etc.) and that'll be cool the first few times, but after the third or fourth you'll realize that you can kill it by popping out of cover, zapping it with a full bar of Force Lightning, then popping back into cover and waiting for your mana to regenerate (which it does almost instantly) until its health is in the red and you can run up to it and kill it with a quicktime event. The combination of this, the aformentioned stunlock issue, and the Force-blocking shields mean that a squad of Stormtroopers in 'Force Unleashed' is generally much more dangerous to you than a pair of Rancors.Possibly the crowning achievement of the game's bad design occurs near the end of the game, where an event that should've been an incredible, 'holy crap' experience is instead reduced by an actively deceptive onscreen prompt and poor controls into an exercise in absolute, controller-throwing frustration.The Good: Absolutely spot-on voice acting (Vader sounds like Vader, Palpatine sounds like Palpatine, all of the new characters are on point as well), a very strong story, and gameplay that is often fun despite itself. It has its (many, many) flaws, but the core mechanic of Force manipulation is enough to sustain the game. Almost every level has some sort of awful. hilarious thing you can do to your foes, from dropping an Ugnaught into an active carbonite bath, to slowly pressing a Jawa against a laser fence, to throwing a Stormtrooper through a window and into a stream of flaming railgun exhaust (or into the vast void of space, or into a Sarlacc's mouth, or...) to just plain hurling them against the wall until they stop moving. The Force Push also figures into this, and the first time the stars align and you chain it into a combo that targets a cluster of unshielded troops, hurling them screaming off of a platform, it will be absolute magic.If you're a Star Wars fan (and honestly, who isn't?) I'd grab it, but I can't recommend it to someone who isn't attached to the mythos and is just looking for a good game to play.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												I have also played this game back when it released on the xbox 360. Star Wars The Force Unleashed is a very fun, but messy game. It requires a few mods to make it run well on the PC (60 fps, better textures) but it can be worth it if you are willing to invest the time and work. The game runs about 10-12 hours if you want to do everything, about 7-8 hours for one playthrough on the medium difficulty. It should be noted that there is a glitch in the Steam version of the game, where the final 2 levels lack any sort of sound effects. Again, this can be fixed with a mod, but this problem has been around since at least 2010 and has never been officially fixed.Is the game good? Yes, but it requires a little effort on the part of the player and it is by no means worth 20 dollars almost 8 years after it's release. If you can pick it up for $3 during a sale and are willing to put a little work in to getting it running, then it can be a worthwhile experience.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												This game is decently good.  If it's on sale, I definitely recommend it.  The historical context is an interesting possible back story for the Rebellion, but the personal romance portion of the plot is not well done.  The graphics are good during combat, not as good during cutscenes.  The walking is awkward, and the cutscenes don't display your customized lightsaber and outfit.  The game is short, but the gameplay still gets repetitive.  Blowing things up with massive force powers is pretty awesome though.  Overall, The Force Unleashed is not as good as games like Jedi Academy, but it's still a fun thing to play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 19, 2010
												A great Star Wars game that makes you jump and squeal like a rabid fanboy as you throw, zap and annihilate everything that comes in your path. Unfortunately you need a computer that can run crysis at a solid 60+ fps in order to atleast get a smooth framerate with this game. Why? Because this game is the worst PC port in the history of video gaming (in my opinion) you cannot adjust shadows, anti aliasing, dynamic shadows, video quality etc. The game only gives you the option of choosing the resolution and "high quality" (on/off). Force Unleashed has a 30 frame cap, which means even if you can play Crysis 2 at 100+ fps, this game will be locked at a solid 30, which is a damn shame. Aside from that, the game is fun, always entertaining and with all the hidden unlockables AND the extra DLC missions (what if Vader died and Starkiller took his place) give you a taste of an alternate Star Wars Universe. Overall, a good game, only ruined by shoddy porting.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												The Force Unleashed is a great game, if a little akward to control at times.  The game really shows how badass jedi/sith can be, and is great for stress relief.  My only two complaints are that (1) the game can be difficult to control in combat (you feel knockback way more than some enemies, and can easily get stun locked at times), and (2) the DLC (included in teh Ultimate Sith Edition) feels very separate from the game itself.  The DLC isn't added into the game itself, to allow you to continue levelling up and such in new missions, but instead are three new options when you start a new game, providing you a pre-levelled character to use.Overall, though, it's a great game, and definitely one I'd recommend to all Star Wars fans.(PS, if my low game time seems suspicious, it's because I put most of my time into this game on my console, and only recently purchased it for Steam)

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												This verdict is contingent on how strongly you feel about Star Wars. If you're the kind of person who gets really upset at George Lucas' meddling with the original films and reads the expanded universe books, you'll find some stuff to hate. If you're less invested and just enjoy the movies and games, you'll probably have a lot of fun with this one. I can appreciate The Force Unleashed as a game, but I don't like how it handled some aspects of the universe. I did have a lot of fun, though, and to a lot of people that's what's really important. I hear the console versions have a few less problems, so it's probably better to play it there.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2012/02/star-wars-force-unleashed.html

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Ok, I've not put many hours into this game, but I think I can already describe it to you.It's a Star Wars game. I'm a big fan of the franchise myself, so for me this game it always was a must-have in my collection.The story is simple and a bit cartoonish (not even close to the level of depth of the two KOTORs), but it's not so bad.***Minor Spoiler ahead***You are Starkiller. Darth Vader has adopted you after killing your father, because the Force is strong in you. He has trained you for Jedi-killing, until one day the Emperor discover your existence and cast away.So you will be a dark jedi for the first part of the game (in which at the moment of the review I actually am), but I sense, as the story progresses, that you will find the light... Kudos to the writers for letting me play as Darth Vader in the beginning (a big wet dream of mine) and taste the evil as I kill the good guys.The graphic is excellent and the combat system, which is the core element of the game, is ok.The music and the sound effects are perfect.The urge for writing this review came for the really bad things you will find.First of all I think that every bug I encountered depends on a disappointing PC port.-The game is buggy as hell. I think no game other than Alpha Protocol in my library have forced me to restart the pc more than this one.You will find yourself frustated a lot during the course of the game because every now and then it crashes without a motive.-In some cases you will fall between the layers of the level. In that case you are forced to restart the mission (if you don't have a previous save).-The boss battle are terrible. It's the first time in a game that I actually hate to be in a boss fight. The force system depends on you facing the item/character you want to use your powers on. In the boss battle this is a nightmare. The game loses the over-the-shoulder view and becomes a fixed third-person view in which you see yourself and the stage (like the Scarecrow parts of Batman: Arkham Asylum). I often couldn't face quickly the boss, and this is a game in which speed is essential.-The sound is perfect but something has gone wrong, because I can not hear the voice of the actors during the cutscenes (which are crucial to the understanding of the story and actually well-done). So I have to play with my headphones and this actually solved the problem.(???)Coclusion:Star Wars The Force Unleashed is a beauty. It's really fun to play, good to watch and hear. It could have been a perfect game, if not for the bad PC port and some questionable gameplay choices.If you are a Star Wars fan chances are you already have this one in your collection.If not ask yourself if you want to play a really good game with lots of bug and glitches.

												Do I recommend the game? Easy answer: Yes, when it's on sale. It's a typical hack'n'slash game set in the Star Wars Galaxy, if you like one of them, go ahead and buy the game! I'm playing this on a asus laptop on highest settings and I had no bugs, except a sound bug.This bug means, as it seems to be a general bug, the sound fx is cut off in some stages, that means you don't hear the rockets when they're shot at you, which can get a bit irritating and frustrating, but okay.Sadly Disney didn't accept the story to produce their own series, but it's still interesting.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												I first got this game on PSP. Yeah... I completed it, and I think I enjoyed it. This was before I became a "Gaming Connoisseur". A little while into the future, my father bought me two games for my birthday; Quantum of Solace, and The Force Unleashed, on Xbox 360. I was so annoyed that my father actually had the audacity to buy me games. I played up to the Felucia level on the 360 in The Force Unleashed and stopped. Why did I do that? I was cutting my nose off in spite of my face. Quantum of Solace, which was actually a good game, and The Force Unleashed were traded in for some other crap game, I can't remember which. I feel very guilty for the lack of gratitude I showed my father. Mostly because The Force Unleashed is an enjoyable game, except for the obvios heavily criticised flaws. One annoying flaw is that when you get close to edges of land mass it kinda sucks you off the edge, which makes the platforming annoying. Keyboard controls are alright though, which is nice.

Nice try, no cigar.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												It's a very nice addition to the Star Wars universe. The story is nice, the characters are good and the graphics are really nice, but you don't have access to the "advanced" configurations, limiting you to choose between low, medium or high graphics without changing things like texture quality or anti-aliasing. It has an FPS cap on it, but there are mods made to cap it higher or uncap it. Gameplay is good and combat is pretty decent, but the force usage is clunky. For example, if you grab a trooper and wants to throw it at a wall that is in front of you, there's a high chance you end up just throwing him up the air, because it's weird like that, but when it works as intended, it's really satisfying. Overall, it is a pretty good game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												This is the coolest "Be a Jedi and kill Stormtroopers" game this side of Jedi Outcast. If you want to do that, this game is a must buy. Lifting up an explosive barrel, infusing it with lightning, throwing it at a squad of Stormtroopers, lifting up the survivor, then gently dropping him into a bottomless pit, is a delightful experience that you can get in very few places. That said, it's not a spectacular game. When it came out, I would have recommended it, but playing it again now, all I can think of is how much I wish it were more like Arkham City or Shadow of Mordor. I'm spoiled by fluid combat systems now, and this is very much a hack slashy spammy game with much less thought in it.The story is okay. It works. I'm a big Star Wars nerd, and there's stuff here to like and dislike.Also, this is a pretty shoddy PC port. The settings are limited and you have to change them in a separate launcher, because the in game menu system is a straight copy of the already clunky and limited console version. I've had several random crashes while playing it, but otherwise have had no performance or control issues.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												TL;DRIt's a good game, but there are quite a few problems with it. Buy it at a reduced cost, if possible.The full review contains MILD SPOILERS. Caution advised.Star Wars: The Force Unleashed was one of my favorite games on my old PS2 when I was younger, and decided to pick this up after feeling a bit nostalgic. This is actually a port of the PS3 / Xbox 360 versions of the game, which disappointed me somewhat, though it's the same game for the most part. (It may just be nostalgia, but I find the PS2 / Wii version better than this version)The Story is good, probably 6.5 stars. It's nothing spectacular, but it gets the job done. Taking place in between Episodes III and IV, you play as Galen Marek, the son of a Jedi, turned Vader's Apprentice at a young age. Now known as Starkiller, your training is almost complete, with the end goal being to help Vader overthrow the Emperor. However,  Vader kills you in front of the Emperor, in order to "Gain his trust." After being brought back to life, Starkiller feels a little betrayed, and tries to get revenge. The gameplay is absolutely where the game shines. While it does fall into that same problem that every Star Wars game has, where lightsabers geel way too weak, it's still fun when you don't think about the fact that they're supposed to cut through just about everything. Starkiller is also a master of the Force, however, which is what makes this Beat-em-Up different from other Beat-em-Ups. You can pick things up, throw people and things, shock them, throw your lightsaber, push them, everything you'd expect from a Force prodigy. The boss fights are quite a lot of fun, and regular combat is great hoards of Troopers and Rebels alike. The game suffers from a few major problems, however. The level design is not very good. It asks for some way-too-specific jumps for the game's floaty physics engine, and failing generally results in instant death. Quick Time Events are very frequent, and break up the flow of combat when you fight larger enemies, such as Rancors or AT-ATs. Load times are ridiculous, and far too frequent. Lastly, the game has a 30 FPS cap, though there are fixes for that available on the Internet.(Also the Star Destroyer mission is atrocious. The PS2 / Wii version may be better simply because it's not there.)Overall, I'd probably give the game a 6 / 10. Above average, but not by much. Pick it up on sale, if you can.

												This game is decently good.  If it's on sale, I definitely recommend it.  The historical context is an interesting possible back story for the Rebellion, but the personal romance portion of the plot is not well done.  The graphics are good during combat, not as good during cutscenes.  The walking is awkward, and the cutscenes don't display your customized lightsaber and outfit.  The game is short, but the gameplay still gets repetitive.  Blowing things up with massive force powers is pretty awesome though.  Overall, The Force Unleashed is not as good as games like Jedi Academy, but it's still a fun thing to play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Star Wars the Force Unleashed is the ultimate Star Wars Game. I'm sure that at some point during a Star Wars game we've all said to ourselves "Why the ♥♥♥♥ can't I just throw this guy off the edge of a cliff with the force?", well, now you can ACTUALLY DO THAT.This game lets you use all the force goodies from the movies, plus a couple new ones, such as creating a force shockwave and imbuing your lightsaber with sith lightning.The combat is fast paced and dodge-oriented. You get health for killing any enemy, but be careful; on higher difficulties you can be torn asunder by blaster fire very quickly.From a story standpoint, this is a game that takes place during the "Dark Times", the period between episodes III and IV where the last of the jedi were being hunted down, and the Rebel Alliance hadn't been formed. The game takes you through the deaths of most of the remaining jedi, and shows the origins of the Rebel Alliance, as well as Vader's plan to overthrow Emperor Palpatine (supporting his actions in Episode VI).

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Back when this game came out, I only had a Wii, so I got the Wii version because I was stuck with it. In my mind I thought it was fun, though wish I could do some things that were in the PS3 and 360 versions that I couldn't do on the Wii Version. But later on I no longer cared until I heard of the Black Lightsaber. So years later I get it on the PC with DLC included, beat the game and in the end I said words that no one would probably ever say. "I think the Wii version was better." Now bare in mind I'm not exactly stating that EVERYTHING in the Wii version was better, but what if I told you that there are missions that could of been done in the Wii Version that wasn't included in other version. And this is before DLC, for example the Jedi Temple, you literally go to the Jedi Temple 3 times during the normal campaign of the Wii version. To know that people had to wait for a DLC release, it's hard to say if it's a good thing if you had to pay for it. You even return to Cloud City twice in the Wii Version. Also another disappointment was knowing you couldn't change the hilt of a lightsaber. Look I know there's always going to be differences between the actual game and "down-graded" ports of them. But the "down-graded" felt like it received more love, with more levels, more customizations, more costumes, I do believe there are more costumes on the Wii Version, if not now no doubt post DLC. Now I'm not saying this version is BAD, (well on a level with the PC version there are tweeks needed) the game is still fun, I still enjoy it. I'm literally just surprised to know that Force Unleashed on other platforms but Wii (and maybe PS2) was lacking a bit. Now this game is still fun as I said, the story is good, the gameplay is good, levels can be short at times but are worth exploring for unlockables. The only TRUE negatives I have is Raxus Prime imagery and some sound errors which may require online help for fixes. Despite those this is a good game to check out even now.

Posted: August 25, 2014
												The Force Unleashed is a great game, if a little akward to control at times.  The game really shows how badass jedi/sith can be, and is great for stress relief.  My only two complaints are that (1) the game can be difficult to control in combat (you feel knockback way more than some enemies, and can easily get stun locked at times), and (2) the DLC (included in teh Ultimate Sith Edition) feels very separate from the game itself.  The DLC isn't added into the game itself, to allow you to continue levelling up and such in new missions, but instead are three new options when you start a new game, providing you a pre-levelled character to use.Overall, though, it's a great game, and definitely one I'd recommend to all Star Wars fans.(PS, if my low game time seems suspicious, it's because I put most of my time into this game on my console, and only recently purchased it for Steam)

												To all the people above or below me hating this game, well let me tell you something, this game is beautifully presented, even though the game was originally released on console, it's controls on the PC are is to master, and sure at times in the game you will get stuck but have no fear if you are great at finding "shortcuts", or if you are good at finding out problems easily unlike the haters of this then you will have no problem at all with this game, and the combat and movements are fantastic, and if you are wondering yes I have played the console version therefore I know this game, even though I haven't played this game for a couple of years I easily remastered it and soared right through it with no problems at all, so in summary: If you want a beautifully presented game great movement and combat then get this game I highly recommend it, this was the best use of my left over money.10/10 would definitely play this game again and again and again, etc.P.S. When you get at a part of the game where you have to double jump and then force dash then just put your left pinky finger on the shift key, your left middle finger on the W key, and your left thumb on the Spacebar, it worked for me, also to the guy who said at the beginning of the game Darth Vader moves like a glacier, please next time read the controls before starting cause you can move faster with the shift key to force dash to move faster, there's another tip for you!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I really like this game, there is so much in it. You can choose from many "costumes" - play as a Luck Skywalker, Stormtrooper, or Qui-Gon Jinn. Levels are sworming with low-lifes just waiting to feel the power of the Dark Side. There is bonus for almost everything. You can grab some crate, or enemy and throw them in front of each other; you can use lightsaber combo with lightning in it, and finish it wiht force push, just to grab your pray and crush it into the ground. Some of the "world" parts are aslo avaible to grab and throw. Sometimes you have to bend objects with your power which is very cool. You can also use lightning to enable some devices. I like the way the "secrets" modify gameplay. If you find that special place, you also obtain holocrons. You can use them to modify your lighsaber, your force powers, combo technics or general skills. In this version there are also 3 new scenarios (with new costumes). The Hoth, Jedi Temple and Tatooine. Jedi Temple is beyond my skill right now, I'd get killed every single time after 2 min. They all are ok and fun to play. There is also database - you can read about all equipment and objects used in the game. If you like star wars because of details, you'll find them. Models are done with great detail. My favorite for now is Darth Sion. I was very suprised when I've found out that you can choose dark lighsaber colour. It's almost like ancient saber used by leader of Death Watch. Game should be played with controler such as Xbox 360 for example. There is only sigle player mode, and autosave after checkpoints. May the Force be with you :)

												While my initial impression was vastly negative due to too many technical annoyances:- Bugs and crashes- Save system is a joke- 30fps cap- Very minimal customization in the game options- Highly unoptimized for the PCI can't say I didn't enjoy the game at all as a SW fan. Environments are varied with good amount of detail. Enemies are quite tough and can be frustrating. The game can also get very dull at times, but they do offer some character customization. The big selling point the story itself is pretty mediocre for the most part. Despite the flaws I still feel that any Jedi Knight fan can have fun experience on most part if being aware of the shortcomings beforehand.BEGINNER TIPS:- Play with gamepad- Apply the 60fps fix- Don't play on hard with 1st playthrough- Don't forget to apply a power crystal like I did.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												Don't get me wrong, I love this game. You get a feeling of real power as you run around smashing wookies into walls, slashing your way through ranks of terrified stormtroopers and electrocuitng the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of some poor rodian who happened to be wandering around the area you landed in. The  customisation with lightsaber and outfits is a nice touch though i found myself going with the default costume for the majority of my playthrough.The story line is simple yet compelling, and isa  fine addition to the star wars universe as it explains the origins of some major factions... HOWEVERIt is also one of the buggiest pieces of crap I've ever bought- you dash into a wall and get stuck clipped halfway through, some enemies are literally unkillable for some reason and have to just be left behind if theres no bottomless pit to chuck them into. Like many people I have talked with anything in the near or middle distance doesnt render properly and leaves a horrible lagging effect of my character and the fixed background (even with my juicy computer)- I ignored this ad decided to play anywa, untill i reached a certain leve which required you to interact witth something very far away- which i could not do as i had literally no idea which way it was pointing so i could line it up with a bizarre arbitrary direction. This also ties in with a questionable control scheme, as a console port the controls are never going to be stellr but these go beyond anything I've seen in a while- and I play Assassins Creed on PC!Overall, I'd recommed this game on one condition-its not the pc version. Hell, get the PS2 version i first played this game on, it's better than this sloppy port..

Star Wars The Force Unleashed™ Disclaimer : Bought this ON SALE! for 2,99 EU So keep that in mind when reading this review,And have not watched any of the movies (Spoiler)Okey , where to start. This game is quite fun , it has not to many mechanics so far (2-3 Hours) And the game starts abit wierd , you start out as being Vader, Who wouldn't like that?But anyway , The game starts you out with no tutorial, nothing at all baiscly , so first level you just gonna spend your time killing stuff and walk very slow...damn i hate that part.______________________________________________________Okay here is where the game start itselfStory : The story is about wiping out all Jedi (of what i played thats whats the story has comed to).And I really like the story, not going to say anymore, dont really wanna spoil the game for you._______________________________________________________Fighting System: Its a free flow fighting system with a lightsaber. its quite fun but at the starts its quite the sameNothing much you can do in combos.You level up your Jedi with 3 different pointForce PowersForce CombosForce TalentsThis Force powers can make you push you enemies away,Throw lightsaber,and very nice attacks.Really love it!And the boss fights! Holy! i Fing love them, they have some mechanics i love, BUT one thing ppl might not like is "Q-T-E" is on bosses.In my opinion its fine and makes the game shine!there is so much i wanna say but i wont cuz you need to play the fights to understand! Review might get updated after i finished the gamefor the 3 eu price YES!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												This is one of those games that you know isn't good, but you love it anyway. It's crashed on me plenty of times, the framerate tanks in strange places, it's locked at 30 frames, the sounds are pretty bad, the story's disorganized, some of the player models are really strange looking (Juno Eclipse, mainly), quick time events, plenty of bugs, the settings are in a startup menu, wonky controls, and plenty more.Even through all of this, this is still one of my favorite games. Ever. I have never played a Star Wars game that better captures the feel of the Force. Flinging your enemies across the room, throwing explosives at them, holding them in the air as you repeatedly toss your lightsaber into them, electrocuting people, throwing boxes at TIE Fighters and blowing them up. Even the basic lighsaber combat is fun, bouncing between enemies. Tie the two togeter, and you get a combat system that looks and feels fantastic. It feels great to find new ways to absolutely demolish your enemies. I don't even slightly feel bad for paying the full $20 for this game. It's so much silly fun, you feel like a true Sith.Buy this game, and experience the true power of the Dark Side.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												This game has an amazing combat system, but the action is constantly interupted by quicktime events every boss or big enemy you fight. This breaks the flow of the game entirley too often which is upsetting since the rest of the combat is so good combo wise.         The controls feel ok sometimes, but a lot of the time you don't feel in control of the character. You push buttons, and he does whatever, but it feels very synthetic and loose.           The camera and targetting system is hard to control. The enemy AI is absolute garbage, the enemies aren't hard, once you find out there weaknesses you can just spam till it dies, which is upsetting because the combo system is awesome and really satisfying, also the storm troopers are pathetic as they shoot at you till you get close enough to cut through them like a piece of paper. The games crappy AI turns the whole thing into trial and error, get killed by a bunch of enemies, learn how to beat them after 5-10 tries, rinse and repeat for the whole game. Not very compelling.           The port isn't good either, This game runs on a constant 30fps and no way to bring up. But the most annoying thing is the frequent crashes.            Pretty disapointing because I really wanted to like this game, but I found it waaay over hyped and non-compelling. For a person wanting a decent hack n slash, play this game.            Die hard Star Wars fans wanting a compelling, challenging masterpiece that controls like butter and has satisfying gameplay overall, this game is not for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												First I would like to say that this is a great game, it had some potential to go into bigger and better things, the ideas presented in the story and direct correlation to the cinematic universe before Disney declared this non-canon was fantastic.However, the ideas they present for the story I feel are just scratching the surface, I saw potential for further development between character relations and the development of the main character himself, world exploration, a bit more intricacy in combat similar to that of Jedi academy to add a layer of strategy when approaching a foe or boss, rather than just the hack and slash/force *insert technique* anything in your way. I understand it is meant to  be reflective of Starkiller's raw power and while some of the quick time mini-games result in some excellent finishers, there could have been so much more.The game does go through some backstory however it is only if you are willing to read through their character profiles but the vibesand expectations you get off reading them just don't seem to show through the gameplay, take Juno for example, her backstory involved her joining the empire to finally gain some love from her cold-distant jerk of a father, however non of that contempt shows in the story not so much depth and when  Starkiller and Juno kiss I can't help but feel nothing towards it at all because between missions there is very little interaction between the two or anything will lead up to it IMO. Same with Proxy, your friendly neighbourhood training droid bent on killing you that you keep as your companion, so much more could be done with that.Replayability is worth tackling at more difficult levels but you are more likely to go through it again just to find those elusive saber crystals, the black saber crystal is awesome beeteedubs, but as of yet even though I have not fully leveled nor collected everything I just can't bring it to myself to revisit the levels again.Don't get me wrong some of the levels are interesting but then you have to revisit some of them again  and even though you get to  go through the stomach of a SARLAC there's just some wasted oppotunity to explore the then extensive world Star wars, I feel anyway.Overall I am a little underwhelmed by this game not worth it's price since I finished the story easily w ait for a sale if you wish to buy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 30, 2012
												A great part of the Star Wars extended univserse, The Force Unleashed is between the prequel and original trilogies. You play as Darth Vader's apprentice, Starkiller (yes, like from The Force Awakens) and are part of the Dark Side for a period of time before things change and you become aware of your past.This game is not a great port, and could have used more work but is definitely a very fun game. It gets a lot more hate than it deserves and I do not understand why. I love the original Star Wars trilogy and think this game does the Star Wars universe more justice than most extended universe material out there, aside from Marvel Comics, Republic Commando, and Knights of the Old Republic. As an action game, it's a solid title, and as a Star Wars game, it's a must play for any fan, and the physics are an absolute blast to play with.And with the two endings (Light & Dark side), there's plenty reason to come back for more.+ Great action+ Interesting story+ Great for Star Wars extended universe+ New and old characters+ Sam Witwer+ Collectables, including lightsaber color crystals+ All the extra costumes+ Story DLC for if you get the Sith ending+ Havok and Euphoria physics+ Using Force powers is feels more... powerful than ever before+ Familiar Star Wars locations+ Great soundtrack and ambience+ Sound effects from the Star Wars film franchise+ Varying enemy models...- ... that all operate in the same way- Very glitchy- Not many graphics options- A very rough port that didn't have enough work done on it- No DLC for light side ending- Changing costumes takes you to previous checkpoint

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Now is the game perfect? Hell no. The controls are difficult to handle and the gameplay is eratic. Sometimes enemies will continually hit you with no chance of you getting back up. Really, this is a console game, even with controller, it's still difficult to handle. But once you get combat down (which is a chore) you will feel like a badass. This game not only looks great, but if you are a star wars fan (and hate Disney for ret-conning EU) than this game's story will satisfy, even if you aren't, it is pretty well written, voice actors clearly know what they're doing, and overall it fits nicely in the Star Wars universe. Reccomend if you have a controller, if not, it's still worth a go. And for the price, it isn't asking for much, especially with the various other DLC campaigns.EDIT:This game is probably one of the most recent and best examples of star wars combat, except for one major MAJOR flaw... The lock-on mechanic. You know how in the Batman Arkham games whenever you threw a punch, Batma would automatically hit a nearby enemy? It's said that Arkham Asylum came out the same year as this game, and if this game somehow managed to incorporate that one little addition of code. That made it so that not every bad♥♥♥♥♥move you made completely missed an enemy, but immediately locked onto an enemy? This game would have very little issues and be out-right perfect in my mind. But it's not, and that's a shame.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												If you want to break a controller then this is a good way to do it. There are many redeeming qualities in this game and they make it worth the money and time. Just... Just bear in mind that there are a lot of problems with the main campaign. Glitches, clunky controls, broken mini bosses, and one of the most unforgiving "extra hard" modes you'll ever find are the most prominent issues you'll find. The mechanics, however, are very satisfying and you do feel challenged while maintining the sense of power that should come with being a Sith assassin. What's more he DLC levels remove basically all the frustrating elements (aside from DLC being better than the main game). Be you a casual player, an rpg completionist, or a star wars fan; this game is worth your time and money.

												Force moving things aren't very good with the mouse. You end up throwing something in completely the wrong direction due to some sort of aim assist. You also have to lift up the mouse a lot when doing puzzles that require moving something with the force. The gimmick gets old after the first time you do it and would be better off if you only had to hold the button down.Boss battles against Jedi/Sith are grindy. Forcing you to unbalance the enemy, then spam damage while he's down. Repeat about 20 times till you get to a quicktime event. There's also a quicktime event where you hold down some buttons for 10 minutes to "force pull" something, with breaks that you have to force throw things to kill them. Remember how force throwing is a pain to use? You could also try to throw the enemies into each other, except you can't reach them unless they're right on top of you. Nevermind the fact that you are trying to force pull something miles away the entire time.There is a freaking LOADING SCREEN to enter any submenu. Want to upgrade your powers? LOADING SCREEN. And the menues ignore the mouse cursor like a typical console port.[Spoilers ahead]......The ending was lame. Typical "if you kill the emperor, you can't be a Jedi" plot armor BS.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												Greatest game EVER! OK, I played this game on my Xbox 360 as a kid when it first came out, I've completed it on every difficulty (except the the hardest one you unlock after completing the game once - the Emporer/Darth Vader are rediculously hard). But now that I have the ULTIMATE SITH ADDITION, I get access to so many new skins/costumes, multiple extra levels and more. I've also just discovered so many new combos since I was too young to really remember them when I first played it.The combat is so fun because there's so many awesome moves you can do - you really feel like a sith (alough you can't do the Force choke). The level design puts you right into the Star Wars universe on multiple planets from the movies (and new ones) with a good selection of enemies including one's you've seen and one's you haven't. It is set after order 66 and before episode IV which means you get to see characters from both the prequels and the original films. You get to see the remenants of the Clone Wars and the rise of the Empire. The story and cinematic cutscenes mixed in with brillilant John Williams original Star Wars themes and the awesome new Force Uleashes theme makes the game feel as if it is a new movie. And the story has a few twists and turns to keep you intruiged and alert. The levels are quite long and gameplay can get repetitive but for me, because of the vast array of abilties, every time I pkay I discover something new. There's also two ending to the game which adds to relay value, Jedi Holocrons to collect in each mission (and other secondary objectives to complete), not forgetting this Sith Editions' extra missions which I have yet to play. You can customise the colour and crystal type and upgrade unlocking new combos. There s only 10 missions in the main game (the first of which you play as Darth Vader but cannot replay for some reason) but they all take time and have a difficult boss at the end.Overall, may not be for everyone but definitely for Star War fans and action gamers alike. Also, there's some pretty hardcore gampley in here as wel, especially when you fight the bosses!

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Star Wars: The Force Uleashed is a fairly average 3rd person hack and slash set in the Star Wars universe. The story is, while a bit bland, fairly good overall and goes in-depth into the events between the 3rd and 4th movies in the Star Wars franchise. The game features a set of force powers and effects the make the player feel like a powerful badass apprentice to Darth Vader - flinging stormtroopers out of ship windows, shocking them with lightning, and slicing/skewering them with your lightsaber all work to support this feeling. But this is where the game stops being good, at least on the PC port.      The default controls for the PC are clunky at best, making the "god of war style" combo system this game touts difficult to pull off at times. The flaws in the controls are made even worse in instances where precision is needed - precision that makes the difference between beating a level and yelling at your scream in frustration as moves that you would like to pull either dont go off or miss your intended target entirely (leaving you open to a brutal counter-attack as well).  This is particlarly evident in the boss battles (take your pick which one). The game stops being a behind the shoulder 3rd person beat em' up and jarringly shifts to a 3D isometric "Mortal Combat Style" fight, where you cant gain an advantage or effectively perfom combos becuase you're not really sure where exactly you're hitting (and even if you do hit, the bosses have a very annoying habit of countering or blocking everything you do). In one particular level you are supposed to bring down a star destroyer from space and crash it into the planet you're on. This task is borderline impossible due to the horrible controls and lack of  any precision aiming available to you.     The poor optimization is also evident in the jarring loading screens randomly placed in levels, and before and after the "high quality" cinematic scenes. Poor audio syncing also results in the cinematics being a pain to both watch and listen to. Sometime in the beginning of a level you will see yourself standing at the starting point for a few moments, at which point the screen goes blank and THEN the beginning in-game level animation will go off. Also, the music and sound effects for the game tend to cut out at random moments (even during 3D cinematics) and will not return unless you restart the game entirely.     Overall I only recommend this game if you're a Star Wars fan, and even then I'm not sure I can say its a good recommendation. 4/10

Can rip Star Destroyers out of orbit, cant throw purge troopers or small walkers. Will update once I get my hands on a Xbox controller.

												Awesome game! Great story, voice acting and, of course, gameplay! (And I'm not just saying that because I'm a Star Wars nerd...) I love how STarkiller is portrayed throughout the game, and how is is a metaphor for how there is always good in you, no matter how badly you've been brought up, or how "sith" you perceive yourself to be. The hours of fun, exciting and exhilarating gameplay are great to fans of the franchise hardcore and not. I reccomendd this game to everyone as it is awesome!Because the game is a standalone (unless you're counting TFU2) , you don't really need any prior knowledge to get what the story is (probably because the characters of Darth Vader, The Emperor, Princess Leia and such are so rooted into the pop-culture of today).This game is a welcome attribution to any gamer, Star Wars fan or not!!!
